PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Herron (from 1,052 citizens) and Senator Patterson (from 628 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Forests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

Intensive logging, most often to feed a voracious woodchip industry is underway or planned for many high conservation value forests. These forests should be protected by the commitments of the Commonwealth and State Governments under the NFPS.
These forests include:

PETITION.PARA: Coolangubra Wilderness and other areas of the S.E. Forests of NSW along with rainforest and other N.E. areas of NSW including Wingham, Mistake, Richmond Range, Chaelundi, North Washpool, Barrington and Dorrigo.
The Southern Highlands, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness of Tasmania.
The Karri and Jarrah forests of S.W. Western Australia.
The Errinundra Plateau and other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: We request that the Government act urgently to protect our precious forests by utilising the Commonwealth's legal and constitutional powers, including:

PETITION.PARA: Refusal of export woodchip licences
Powers to control corporations
Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate
Protection and effective funding of areas identified for their World Heritage values.

PARA.TAB: Genuine and effective action by the Government to protect these and other old growth and wilderness forests is critical. A comprehensive plantation strategy rather than exploiting native forests is the way forward for a truly environmentally responsible timber industry. We further request that the Government take effective action without further delay.

PETITION.TITLE: Mifepristone
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned showeth:

(1) That the trials of the abortifacient drug Mifepristone (RU486) are against the public interest in that they use women as guinea pigs for trials of a drug which causes death to the unborn future citizens and adds undue risk to the health of women.
(2) That when RU486 is used with a prostaglandin it exposes women to a disproportionate risk of pain, bleeding and more serious complications.
(3) That when RU486 is used as a `morning after pill' its effect is abortifacient in that it stops implantation of a human embryo, a future citizen, in the womb.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will legislate to ban the importation and use of RU486 in Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Breast Cancer Research
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia:

PARA.TAB: (a) deplores the fact that six Australian women per day die from breast cancer and notes the possibility of contracting breast cancer is as high as one chance in 12 for Australian women;
(b) recognises the fact that breast cancer has the potential to affect every Australian family;
(c) recognises that there are inadequate research funds available to help combat breast cancer.

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners ask that the Senate call on the Government to:

PARA.TAB: (a) increase funding for breast cancer research ten-fold (a minimum of $14 million) in the 1994/95 Budget; and
(b) consider further initiatives through the tax system to encourage donations for breast cancer research.

PETITION.TITLE: Telephone Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the residents of far East Gippsland vigorously support the introduction of cellular telephone services by the installation of a transceiver on Mount Delegate—N.S.W.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government:
Facilitate the placement of cellular telephone transmitters to complete coverage in the electorate of Eden Monaro and areas of far East Gippsland before the end of 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion to vary the order of the Senate relating to the cut-off date for the introduction of bills so that we can deal with the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill 1994. This bill is caught up, as are a number of other bills, in the order of the Senate that was agreed on 29 November relating to the introduction in the Senate of bills after 1 July 1994. The proposal is that that order not apply in the case of the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill 1994.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the order of the Senate of 29 November 1994, relating to the introduction of legislation, not apply to the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill 1994.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 16 November, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill 1994 is to update the Qantas Sale Act 1992 in the light of recent developments. The bill also will amend the Air Navigation Act for reasons I will come to later. Four divisions in the first part of the bill affect the Qantas Sale Act. The second part of the bill deals with the amendments to the Air Navigation Act. The amendments relevant to the Qantas Sale Act include, firstly, those necessary to Qantas being able to participate in the new stock exchange clearing house electronic subregister system, which is known by the acronym CHESS; secondly, technical amendments regarding name changes in certain employee rehabilitation and compensations acts; thirdly, an amendment to clear up an inconsistency with the definition of long service leave to make it consistent with other asset sales; and, fourthly, an extension of the sunset clause provisions of the act regarding the sale from 30 June 1995 to 31 August 1995.

PARA.TAB: The second part of the bill relates to amendments to the Air Navigation Act. These are intended to clarify the Qantas position regarding foreign shareholdings in Australian airlines. The Air Navigation Act 1920 imposes controls over foreign shareholdings in Australian international airlines but, because Qantas is subject to its own controls under the Qantas Sale Act, it was never intended that the Air Navigation Act measures should also apply to Qantas. However, as the wording of the Air Navigation Act is ambiguous it will be amended by this bill to confirm that these measures do not apply to Qantas. The Qantas Sale Act includes specific provisions for Qantas—namely, a limit of 35 per cent on the level of foreign ownership. These amendments ensure that the Air Navigation Act does not apply to Qantas in this regard. According to the government there are no financial implications from this bill, but I will comment on that in more detail a little later.

The very fact that the government has introduced another amendment bill in relation to the Qantas Sale Act indicates just how incompetent the government has been in its handling of its asset sales, in particular its handling of the sale of Qantas. We reasonably expected that the government would no longer control Qantas by the end of this year, yet the government still has a 75 per cent stake. According to the amendments in this bill which extend the sunset provision, the government could still have that 75 per cent interest by July or August of next year. Given the way this whole issue has been bungled to date, who knows that the government will not come back to us between now and August next year with another amendment proposal to blow out the sunset clause still further.

The Labor government first announced the intention to sell part or all of the public ownership in Australia's then two publicly owned airlines, Qantas and Australian Airlines, way back in November 1990—more than four years ago. Responses by potential buyers were sought and lodged by July 1991, after the issuing of an expensive sales brochure and after a great deal of work had been done by the asset sales task force within the Department of Finance.

In the February 1992 so-called One Nation statement, the government announced further changes to its aviation policy, including the proposed trans-Tasman single aviation market reneged on by transport minister Brereton earlier this month, just days before it was scheduled to commence operation. This is another example of sheer blind incompetence on the part of this government and, in particular, the Minister for Transport.

In June 1992 the government announced the sale of Australian Airlines to Qantas and, at the same time, announced its intention to sell the full 100 per cent of the newly emerged Qantas Airlines. At that stage, the government was claiming it would complete the 49 per cent trade sale by the end of 1992 and float off the remaining 51 per cent in the first half of 1993. But, in March 1993, British Airways bought 25 per cent of Qantas for $667 million. In July 1993 the then Minister for Finance announced the postponement of the sale of the remaining 75 per cent until a future date—supposedly, at that stage, within the next 12 months, when the government had hoped to get a better deal on the float and therefore more money into its coffers to help it balance its books, which are, of course, lamentably and dangerously out of balance.

The most recent pronouncements from the current Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) have been for a public float of the remaining 75 per cent by March 1995. But this bill now indicates that even that timing may be too early and it may not be until after the middle of next year, which very significantly means that it is possible it will not be finalised until after the close of the 1994-95 financial year. If Qantas is sold in, say, July of next year, then this process will have taken 4 1/2 years.

The only assets sale that comes close to matching that disgraceful record of incompetence up to date is the sale of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation, which has been going on since the 1989-90 budget—for over five years. Even the debacle of the sale of ANL—the minister has described this as worthless anyway and his comments and actions have greatly damaged the sale value of ANL—which has been a long, ongoing, tortuous affair, still has not, as yet, matched the record of the Qantas sale in terms of time taken.

The impact of the sale of the float of the remaining 75 per cent is potentially very significant. There are some important aspects which the government needs to explain when we are perhaps in committee on the bill or perhaps when the minister is summing up on the second reading, because the figures are very interesting to contemplate.

Already we have seen 25 per cent of the airline sold into foreign ownership—British Airways. That leaves the 75 per cent float still to come. However, under the Qantas Sale Act only 35 per cent of the total shares can be held by foreigners. So that means there is only 10 per cent to go of the remaining float that could be sold to foreign shareholders. A total of 75 per cent is to be sold; therefore, 65 per cent of it—about six-sevenths of what is still to be floated—has to go to Australian shareholders otherwise the foreign ownership provisions in the Qantas Sale Act will be breached.

The float is said to be worth around $2.2 billion, $2.3 billion or perhaps $2.4 billion—nobody really knows. But on the basis of the sale of the first 25 per cent for $667 million, a figure of the order of $2 billion to $2.4 billion or thereabouts probably is in the government's mind. Because of the ownership provisions of that amount only $300 million or thereabouts can go to overseas shareholders. That is, of the float of the remaining 75 per cent almost $2 billion has to go to local ownership. That will impose not insignificant strains on the capital markets here in Australia—the share market, the capital raising market in Australia—in the next year. It will be very interesting indeed to see whether the government can handle it and, more particularly, whether the markets can handle it.

I pass no judgment on that, of course, but I do draw it to the attention of the Senate because it is a point that has not really had much attention up to date. It does raise the question in the 35 per cent foreign ownership of why we are making such a special arrangement in relation to Qantas. Most other sales of assets in Australia to foreigners are subject to the normal policy provisions of the Foreign Investment Review Board. Qantas is being treated separately from that. The government has not really explained why that is the case. Perhaps the government may have some comments on that in its summing up in this debate.

The second point I draw to the attention of the Senate is the impact on the government's 1994-95 budget if the sale is not consummated by the end of June 1995 as seems to be contemplated now by the statements of the Treasurer (Mr Willis) and the Minister for Finance and indeed by the fact that the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill is extending the existing sunset clause out from 30 June 1995 by two months into the 1995-96 financial year through to 31 August 1995.

The government is already in all sorts of trouble with its existing 1994-95 budget. To meet even the huge budget deficit contemplated in this year's budget the government is relying very heavily on proceeds from asset sales and of those the overwhelming sale that it is looking for is the Qantas sale. The government is looking to bring in more than $2 billion to help its revenue situation this financial year.

With this bill the government is sending a none too subtle signal to the markets that that $2 billion plus may not be forthcoming this financial year. The implications of that for the government's already extraordinarily lax fiscal policy are significant indeed. Let me just say in relation to that—and I pick up the notice of motion given this morning by my colleague Senator Watson—that the call by the Governor of the Reserve Bank last night for the government to increase taxes—

TALK.START.PARA: —To find revenue somehow. It does not have to be income tax.

—The government may have to find revenue somehow, but it went to the last election on the fraudulent promise that it was going to cut taxes. Do honourable senators remember the l-a-w law tax cuts? That is what the government went to the last election on. It lied its way into government on a program and a policy of reducing taxation. If the government were to respond to the call by the Governor of the Reserve Bank last night to increase taxes, it would perpetuate the fraud in relation to economic management and the lies of this government in the area of economic policy. Given that Senator Kernot has interjected so vigorously during my speech, I will be interested to hear her comments on the need for tax increases when she makes her contribution to this debate.

PARA.TAB: I get back to the specifics of the bill and the wider considerations of it in relation to micro-economic reform, because the privatisation program is a very important part of micro-economic reform. Over the last 10 years the handling of the micro-economic reform agenda by the Keating and Hawke governments has been an absolute disaster. Privatisation and increased competition in key markets have been ineptly handled or virtually ignored.

The government and its officials in the estimates committee last night were talking about the underpinning of the government's policy being competition policy. What an absolute nonsense that is when we try to match the reality of the government's actions with its rhetoric. The government has gone cold on micro-economic reform in a way that will be very damaging and very dangerous for the economy as we struggle to become an internationally competitive economy. International competitiveness is going to be the thing that will make or break the living standards of this country in the years ahead. The government has gone absolutely cold on most of the changes that are necessary in the structure of our nation and our economy, including in particular privatisation, if we are going to be in a position to capitalise on the enormous opportunities that we have from being in this part of the region, the fastest growing region of the world. The opportunities are there for us if we grab them, but we will not grab them if we do not take the necessary micro-economic reform measures that the government is backing away from at a great rate of knots.

The government should be placing a high priority on reducing its ownership of trading corporations and using the major proceeds from those sales to reduce its bloated public debt. As this government has had asset sales, it has not tried to reduce the public debt—indeed, the public debt has blown out during the period of asset sales. In the last three or four years alone the government's public borrowings have gone from $30 billion of public debt to almost $100 billion this year—the absolute opposite of what is required if we are going to have a responsible approach to economic and, in particular, fiscal policy.

With near record low national savings and a Commonwealth budget deficit still over $10 billion, whilst we are well into the recovery phase, there is no excuse for allowing public debt to continue rising as it is. This is clearly a tired, incompetent government devoid of interest or ideas and, more particularly, devoid of any thought on how we are going to get the basic economic structures of this country, certainly Commonwealth government policies, into place.

This bill would never have been necessary if the government had handled the sale of Qantas with even a modicum of administrative ability. It was not just the way it approached the actual sale, but those who were involved in the sale were frustrated at every stage by continual changes in the government's transport policy, particularly in the area of aviation. It was going to sell Australian, then it was not going to sell Australian. It was going to put Australian with Qantas, then it was not going to put Australian with Qantas. On and on it went, to the great frustration of all those concerned and, in particular, to the great frustration of the process of the sale.

Having said that, the coalition does support the sale of Qantas. We have for over five years and we will therefore be supporting this bill in the hope that it will be the last before Qantas is actually off the government's books. As I have said, given the difficulty that the government could have in finding sufficient local take-up of the float, the government may well have to return to the parliament to seek further change to the Qantas Sale Act in relation to foreign shareholdings. That, however, may not be politically possible for the government until after the next Labor Party national conference due for 1996. By that time, I expect that Labor's attitude to this legislation will be purely academic, because by then the electorate will have thrown this incompetent, tired, arrogant government out on its ear.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Senate this morning is the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill 1994 which will provide the legislative and administrative framework for the sale of the remaining 75 per cent of the Commonwealth's equity in Qantas Airways Ltd. I rise briefly on this occasion to draw to the attention of the people of Australia the complete mismanagement of this whole program of the sale of Qantas Airways.

PARA.TAB: The privatisation of Qantas, I remind the Senate, has been surrounded by bungled attempts by the government on four distinct fronts. Firstly, the initial 25 per cent of the equity sale to British Airways effectively put the control of Qantas into foreign ownership, a situation that gave British Airways a very strategic position in the long term on the great kangaroo route to London on which Qantas built its fame and fortune.

Secondly, the government's mishandling of the third runway has added considerably to the airline's—indeed, to all airlines'—operating costs into New South Wales. These costs fall most heavily on the government's airline, soon to be privatised, Qantas. Thirdly, the proceeds of the first sale were not used to retire debt but to finance new investment projects, an accounting disaster if ever there was one. I therefore use this opportunity to call on the government to use the sale proceeds from the remaining 75 per cent of its equity to retire debt. These proceeds are estimated to be about $2 billion, and that money must be used as part of a deficit reduction strategy and not used to finance current or recurrent expenditure. The government is breaking all the rules of prudent financial management in the handling of its privatisation program, and this Qantas sale is but another sorry saga in that chapter.

The fourth reason for my concern about these bungled attempts by this government at the sale of Qantas is that the parliament currently has before it a further bill which will have a significant impact on employee share ownerships in Australia. This is designed to take share issues by a company to its own employees out of the income tax arena and put them fairly and squarely in the fringe benefits tax collecting mechanism. For most companies of the size of Qantas this will add about $1 million to the costs.

This action will have a very destabilising impact on the sale of Qantas for two reasons. Firstly, it will increase the effective cost to the Commonwealth of the sale of Qantas. Or, looking at it from another perspective, it will certainly impact on the sale price of Qantas if the new employers, as a result of the agreement to sell part of the shares to the employees, have to pay a significantly high cost in terms of fringe benefits.

Secondly, this bungled attempt by the government in relation to the employee share ownership scheme is a human relations disaster. We all know that, as a way of improving productivity, issuing shares in the organisation where an employee works is a very good human relations exercise. It improves morale, it increases productivity and it gives a sense of belonging to something worthwhile.

I put to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that this is a human relations disaster for Qantas. Qantas has a great number of employees—it is one of the largest employers in Australia—and the government's action in relation to the employee share acquisition scheme, which effectively adds in the order of $1 million to its costs, was taken without realising the consequences of it on the effective sale and the proceeds arising from the sale of Qantas.

I take this opportunity to call on the government to do two things: to ensure that it uses the proceeds of the 75 per cent of the equity in Qantas to retire debt rather than to use it for current expenditure; and to amend in a significant way the employee share acquisition scheme so that non-tax avoiding, human relations improving, traditional employee share ownership schemes are not taxed under the fringe benefits tax regime but come firmly within the ambit of the ordinary income taxing provisions.

If the government wishes to separate those schemes that it believes are clones—schemes that are tax deferrals, schemes that are rorts—let it so legislate. But the traditional, the honest, the important things that are improving human relations and giving people a sense of purpose and well being, let them continue. I call upon the government to amendment the employee share ownership scheme to enable a better sale for Qantas to take place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill 1994. I have said on previous occasions that my interest in Qantas is not just as a senator but as a previous employee of Qantas. I want to talk today about the level of ownership.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that there is no way that any government can actually control who buys shares on the Australian stock market. We can impose limits on what is floated on the stock exchange but people can buy shares through agents and, as we know, there are many companies which have been taken over by certain interests, interests that become substantial, and by stealth people can purchase shares on the Australian stock exchange whenever they like. There is no way of knowing from the annual reports of many corporations and companies who owns individual shares and what their nationality is.

It is also nonsense to suggest what seems to be the general feeling that overseas investment will automatically make Qantas more competitive. I think what is certain is that increasing the level of overseas investment in Qantas over time will mean that the interests of Australians in having a national airline will become less and less important to the total run of things.

There are things about an airline that are not entirely market oriented. On the top of the list is safety. There are certain things you do not see when you get on board an airline. While we can see the fittings, how clean the aircraft is, the uniforms of the staff and so on, we cannot see the level of safety. That includes things like crewing time.

Who can forget what happened after Pan Am was bought? The flight crews had their hours increased in order to cut costs and Pan Am started falling out of the air. We, like lemmings, are marching towards privatisation for no real reason except that we are marching towards privatisation. We do not want one of the world's safest airlines, because of the push to increase profits on what used to be our national airline, to decrease its safety margins.

Safety also includes such things as training; not just training of the people who fly the aircraft but other staff and crew—and other training as well. It includes the level and quality of service and maintenance. Those things which are most important about an airline are the things we cannot see. They are the things shareholders do not see. They do not see them in the books as profit; but they are probably the most important things about an airline.

We have heard arguments in this chamber about the Civil Aviation Authority, even from the opposition, that when it is asked to cut costs and maintain safety at the same time, there is going to be a conflict of interest. How can that be any different for Qantas? It will be forced into the same situation if the level of ownership and control is taken away.

It has been recognised that there is also the national interest and national security to consider in relation to an airline. It may be necessary to have people ferried out of a country or from parts of Australia. What guarantees do we have as we go along this path that if we have a huge national disaster we will have the use of this airline to perform those functions?

The worry I have is that recent statements by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) have indicated that we have made certain changes in investment rules with regard to the Uruguay Round of GATT which will be enforced by the World Trade Organisation. There are further steps that will take place with regard to access to investment in Australia and Australian corporations via APEC. That is a few years down the track. What guarantees does the government give us? Because of this process of leaping like lemmings from GATT to APEC, in a few short years we will have absolutely no way of making sure of the level of control or ownership of Qantas that is in Australian hands.

I am issuing these plaintive warnings that we are going down a line that nobody has really checked out. We know there is no real evidence that privatising necessarily creates a better service. I am warning that those things about an airline which are the most important are the ones that do not show up on the balance sheets. I am also asking what it will take before we realise that pushing in this direction for the sake of compensating for a decreasing tax base through government decisions to give to the rich and take from the poor means that in the end that we all may be the losers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Qantas Sale Amendment Bill contains a range of technical amendments. The one we would single out as the most significant is the extension by a further two months to 31 August 1995 for the completion of the Qantas sale. The Australian Democrats are not confident that the sale will even be finished by that date, because the Australian share market is probably getting very close to its limit in terms of big floats—and, certainly, those of the size of the $2 billion Qantas float.

PARA.TAB: We have already had the sale of the Commonwealth Bank, the GIO and Woolworths. There is a lot of competition around at the state and territory level: we have Jeff Kennett in Victoria selling off everything that moves and most things that do not, and John Fahey in New South Wales with his own program. And, of course, our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) intends raising $8 billion in privatisation over the life of this government's deficit reduction strategy.

Senator Margetts has raised concern about an important policy consideration in this debate. The Democrats share this concern and have raised it in the past. What are the strategic implications in an excessive level of foreign ownership of Qantas, if that were to become a reality? The government has announced it will accept up to 35 per cent foreign ownership, with 25 per cent being in any one person's hands. As we already know with the Fairfax takeover, when we look at control—not ownership, but the issue of control—that is more than enough for the company to be effectively foreign controlled. At least in this case—and Senator Short raised the question, but I approve of it—the 35 per cent level is prescribed in legislation. As distinct from media policy, offers to Prime Ministers to provide balanced flights, as distinct from balanced coverage, are not likely to result in the percentages being raised after some private conversation behind closed doors.

When we debated this before, the Democrats moved to reduce the foreign owned percentage to 20 per cent, with a 10 per cent maximum for any one player. Both the Labor and Liberal parties combined to defeat this amendment because, in terms of public policy, they do not really care who owns—but, more importantly, who controls—our former publicly owned assets. I think we should care. We may have lost the privatisation debate—although I think we will be revisiting it—but at least we ought to care about the consequences of privatisation.

I quote from the Sydney Morning Herald of 26 November, where Peter Ellingsen reports from London that `Britain's passion for privatisation has produced no payoff for the public'. I quote two long paragraphs:

On the 10th anniversary of the first privatisation, the public is starting to realise not only that the sell-offs have made millionaires of those who run former state enterprises, but have cost consumers something like $9 billion. Britain's 20 million consumers have seen $200 million of their money handed to the new privateers on a plate. Yet, in a lesson with implications for Australia, these privatised firms have failed to provide promised benefits to the public.

Even the minister responsible for more privatisations than any other, the now retired Lord Parkinson, admits the auction of public businesses has not gone as well as planned. ". . . the net result is that shareholders have done rather better out of it, and customers have done rather less well," he says. In many ways, the push for privatisation has been a false horizon, with the government massively underestimating the value of assets for sale, and the public finding they had to pay the cost of lucrative windfalls for managers and shareholders.

SPEECH.PARA: Shades of that are happening in Australia now. Will we in Australia take another 10 years to learn that lesson? I think it is a legitimate debate to have: whether governments should own airlines and, if they should, to what extent. But the whole issue of privatisation and who ends up paying for it in the long term has not been adequately discussed in this country because the opposition and the government agree on embracing this aspect of economic rationalist theory.

PARA.TAB: The bill today contains the same percentage on foreign ownership as the earlier bill. The other interesting issue raised I think by this bill is the issue of the fate of the employee share plans that Qantas offered. It will be almost impossible for the new owners of Qantas to provide any reasonable level of employee share ownership for their employees, without incurring a massive fringe benefits tax bill under the government's promised taxation of employees' shares. The government has been very quiet on the impact of the budget on employee ownership of Qantas.

The Democrats have been pursuing this issue, as the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) knows. We want to see the employee ownership of Qantas maximised, but under proposed tax laws that could create a massive future tax bill for future owners of Qantas. The point is it will reduce the selling price. So when we are talking about what the public gets out of these sales, we can also raise the question: what will the employees in the long run get out of this sale?

We heard Senator Short raise today's economic hot spot: the comments of the Governor of the Reserve Bank. I heard Mr Costello on AM this morning. I heard the usual opposition mantra: `Cut the deficit, cut services, cut costs. We can do it. The government is being slack.' I just want to point out a couple of things.

First, it is very hard to cut the deficit at the same time as the opposition proposes a sales tax rebate on exports worth $1 billion; doubling overseas aid from 0.34 to 0.7 per cent, worth $1.4 billion; tax deductibility of private health insurance worth $1.4 billion to $2.9 billion; tax breaks on savings worth upwards of $500 million; income splitting or increased home child-care allowances, worth $1.5 billion to $8 billion; regional infrastructure spending of $1 billion to $3 billion; and capital gains tax relief of up to $300 million. The opposition will have to find an awful lot of efficiency saving somewhere to pay for those increases and to bring about its public policy position of cutting the deficit through cutting expenditure.

Second, what I lament more than anything is what the opposition's hypocrisy does to public debate in this country. Every time somebody tries to have a mature discussion about the failure of economic policy in this country or anybody raises the possibility of somehow raising revenue differently, what we see is the opposition popping its little head up again saying, `Ah, the government's going to raise taxes.' There are a couple of fundamental facts of life about this country at the moment after a decade of opposition and government failure to address the way in which we are living beyond our means. Ross Gittins in today's Sydney Morning Herald points this out most eloquently. He says:
Almost everyone—from business economists to radio talk-back hosts to blue-singleted workers in pubs—

SPEECH.PARA: and to this list I would add the opposition—
persists in the belief that spending cuts are a Magic Pudding. The Government can cut and come again merely by eliminating "waste and extravagance" and without harming anyone.

PARA.TAB: This is a mountainous alibi built on a grain of truth. It will always be true that there's inefficiency somewhere in the system which, if only you could get at it, would yield relatively painless savings. But it's equally true that eliminating inefficiency will yield only a fraction of the savings we'd need to put the Federal Budget back onto a self-funding basis.

SPEECH.PARA: To him and to me his conclusion is inescapable that:

. . . until taxpayers are prepared to pay for the benefits and services we expect the Government to provide, we'll go on living beyond our means, racking up public and foreign debt—and leaving the bill for our children.

That is the unpalatable fact of the moment. While ever we have this stupid and counterproductive inability and lack of resolve to discuss what I see is a very serious problem in Australia, then we will continue to neglect our obligation to leave this country in a better state to our children. Back to Qantas, privatisation is one part of the reason that we are living beyond our means. We should revisit the privatisation debate in this country, and it is something that I intend to do.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill 1994. By my count, there have been four speakers in the debate representing the coalition, the Greens and the Democrats. As I understand it, no-one has indicated, although I do not necessarily take this lack of indication as a certainty, direct opposition to this measure.
—We've said we'll support it.

—And the opposition has indicated that it will support the bill. So the bill will be carried. I want to begin by thanking the speakers in this debate for their contributions. I want to deal with a couple of issues that have been raised which I think require some comment from me.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps the first starting point should be the argument that the sale of Qantas should be used to reduce the deficit or to fund some other program of expenditure. I understand that this argument was put earlier in the debate today. We have estimated sale proceeds for the Qantas sale, and those estimates are reflected in the government's budget estimates. Thus they form part of the deficit and debt reduction program. Honourable senators will know that the government has a medium-term deficit reduction program. My point is that, in raising the issue of direct application to the deficit or some other public works idea, the proceeds of this sale when realised will be factored into the budget settings as they stand. Thus they are playing their part in contributing to the deficit and the debt reduction strategy program of the government.

Perhaps the arguments that have been canvassed more recently in this debate are worthy of greater comment. The first concerns the Qantas employee ownership plan, to which a number of senators have referred in their remarks. It is as a principle that the government is attracted to. Employees of enterprises ideally should be offered the opportunity to take a shareholding in those enterprises. In the case of a sale of a significant authority such as Qantas, it is our view that an employee share ownership plan is a desirable feature of that sale. We have said so, and we support the concept. The details of how such a proposal might be applied are not yet settled. They are under consideration and are in a process of development.

A number of views have been put as to what should be the situation, but nothing at this point has been decided other than that the principle has merit and should be applied and that a scheme should be developed to enable employees to take a shareholding in the company for which they work. A number of proposals have been put ranging from, as I understand it, the ACTU on behalf of unions and employees, suggesting 10 per cent of the share offer to a range of other proposals.

The issue put in this debate refers to a debate about tax on employee share ownership schemes as a measure in the last budget. I think I heard Senator Kernot refer a moment ago to the fact that we have debated that in this chamber usually in the format of question time rather than as an extended debate on economic issues. It has been a question and answer repartee-style debate rather than a more developed, considered debate. Nonetheless, it is a debate we have had in this chamber, and one on which I think it is fair to say in all honesty we do not agree.

A number of share ownership schemes operating for employees in Australia are used as tax avoidance devices, as vehicles for tax avoidance. The government's position is that there is a need for regulation in this area to make the schemes genuinely what their titles imply they are—employee share ownership schemes. While that title, as socially acceptable as it is, is used to describe tax avoidance, the tax avoiders escape public scrutiny because they seem to be doing something that is pure and of high or lofty motive. The government's concern is that employee share ownership schemes should not apply just to senior executives in companies. They should be available to all employees in companies; they should be egalitarian schemes in that sense.

Some companies offer employee share ownership schemes not in their company but in other companies as a way of getting around the tax laws. We ought not be seeing this sort of tax rorting. This is an area of tax avoidance that ought to be directly addressed. The government has done that in the budget. Because of some concerns about the way in which the application of those rules might fall, we are further reviewing the application of those rules so that the avoidance issue on tax is overcome. The objective of the government's view is to deal with the avoiders and protect genuine schemes. The Qantas share employee ownership scheme is being worked up in the full knowledge of what the government's view is. It is consistent with the view that it will be a genuine scheme, that it is not a tax avoidance vehicle and that it offers employees the right to hold shares in the authority. As such, my understanding is that it would not attract any level of tax in the way in which honourable senators have suggested it might were it a scheme of the sort that we are seeking to regulate.

A number of honourable senators have made suggestions about extra cost. However, in view of the explanation I have made and particularly in view of the point that the Qantas scheme, when it is developed and unveiled, will be revealed as a genuine scheme which is consistent with the government's objectives, it should not come under the rules that have been applied to deal with fraudulent schemes.

The third area of comment in this debate has focused on the issue of foreign ownership. Qantas is a national asset. It is the flag carrier for Australia. The kangaroo on the red tail of Qantas is a symbol of national pride. One looks at this airline from the point of view of encouraging Australian ownership of it. Some senators have raised this issue in this debate, and some clarification about the government's position is perhaps necessary, given the nature of the debate.

The starting point is to go back to what the original legislation provides. Part 3 of the act enshrines national interest safeguards. It enshrines those safeguards because they are intended to maintain the basic Australian character of Qantas as well as to ensure that Qantas' operating rights under Australia's various bilateral air service agreements and arrangements with other countries are not threatened. Thus, the act requires that Qantas's articles of association must contain provisions which will ensure that: Qantas's main operations base and headquarters remain in Australia; the name of Qantas is preserved for the company's scheduled international passenger services; the company be incorporated in Australia; at least two-thirds of the board of the company of Qantas be Australian citizens; the chairman of the board of Qantas be an Australian citizen; and, while foreign ownership can be accepted, foreign ownership in total should not exceed 35 per cent of total ownership and no single foreign interest can hold more than 25 per cent of that foreign ownership. Qantas's articles are also required to provide directors with wide powers to act, including to deny share registration or to force disposal of shares held by foreigners.

Those provisions are in the act as it stands. They are not subject to this amendment bill. The purposes for them being enshrined in law in Australia now is to address this issue of foreign ownership, the national identity of the airline and the need to maintain a majority Australian ownership of the airline, consistent with the objectives of realising a good market price in the float.

I conclude by again thanking honourable senators for their contribution to this debate. I look forward to the speedy passage of this legislation. The amendments are not insignificant but are along the track we have trodden in the past and are an extension of that track in order to provide the right climate for the people of Australia to realise a best case outcome for the sale of a national asset while maintaining a majority Australian ownership of that asset. I commend the legislation to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the summing-up comments by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) at the second reading stage. Since they were concluding comments, I was precluded from responding on that particular occasion. But he raised a number of interesting and, unfortunately, incorrect statements. I asked the minister how his government intends to exempt future share issues to employees under the employee share ownership scheme which is currently before the parliament from the proposed provisions of the fringe benefits tax regime. The Senate deserves an answer other than a statement that the government has not yet worked it out, because we have a very onerous bill before this parliament which imposes a fringe benefits tax on genuine employee share ownership schemes.

PARA.TAB: The minister says that this is a genuine share ownership scheme but, for some reason, the government intends to exclude the Qantas scheme from the onerous provisions of the fringe benefits tax regime. Does the government, for example, intend to introduce a special bill which will put aside the Qantas employee share ownership scheme from the provisions of the Fringe Benefits Tax Act? Is the minister effectively foreshadowing amendments to the Fringe Benefits Tax Act to exclude the traditional share ownership schemes—schemes that are genuine, schemes that are traditional, schemes that are not new generation clones, schemes that are designed to assist in a good public relations exercise?

I put it to the minister—and he does not seem to have realised this fact—that if we impose a fringe benefits tax regime this will effectively reduce the future sale proceeds of Qantas Airlines, because the new owners will have to pay the fringe benefits tax. I pointed out to the minister—I think he was absent when I made my presentation—that most companies of the size of Qantas will be up for something like $1 million in fringe benefits tax. This is too high a cost for most companies to pay. So, effectively, the company bosses have gone on strike against the actions of this government because of the cost of doing the right thing and issuing shares to their employees in their own company or their parent company. How many share issues have we seen since the minister's announcement of this proposal? Not one significant scheme.

True, in one or two instances particular shares have been given to an exclusive group of directors. However, the government's trade union mates—the very people whom the government has betrayed under this legislation—have been working towards ensuring there is an opportunity for greater employee participation through share ownership. By this very act, under the new employee share ownership scheme, the government is denying them that opportunity. I ask the government to think again.

I am heartened by the minister's comment that they are to be excluded but before we pass this legislation, or certainly before we pass the employee fringe benefits tax legislation which is designed to bring these genuine schemes within this new net, would the minister tell us how the government will exclude the genuine schemes—please, do not just exclude Qantas. A lot of other companies out there—BHP, Coca-Cola Amatil, Lend Lease—have genuine schemes with people wanting to issue shares but precluded from doing so because of the high cost barrier that the government has put in front of them.

We welcome the minister's remarks that the government wants to see 10 per cent. I would certainly like to see more than 10 per cent of the shares go to employees; but it will be well nigh impossible unless they pay a very high cost penalty in the form of a fringe benefits tax. The government is using a sledgehammer to crack a nut. It is causing tremendous pain and grief for all those genuine schemes just because there are one or two out there on the fringe who are not doing the right thing. I say attack them and let the genuine schemes go through.

TALK.START.PARA: —Through this process of privatisation how can the government ensure that corporate profit motives do not become more important than the very important safety issues which, as I mentioned before, are not acknowledged in the profit books of any corporation when safety is such an important issue?

—What does the government propose to do in its budgetary situation for 1994-95 if, as appears likely, the expected proceeds of the sale of Qantas—assuming it does go ahead—are not received before 30 June, which is the reason for the extension of the sunset clause out to 31 August? Am I correct in saying that, so far as the budget situation of 1994-95 is concerned, it immediately creates a hole of something like $2 billion in the government's budget figuring?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —While it is fresh in my mind, let me not say that I cannot confirm or deny the figure that Senator Short has put on it. There are three questions to answer. Firstly, Senator Watson started the questioning process: I am pleased to see Senator Watson in the chamber. I enjoyed his company until about 2 o'clock this morning when we were both working on the economics estimates committee. It is nice to see Senator Watson back so fit and well this morning and in fine fettle. Having complimented Senator Watson, let me deal with his argument, because while I do have some considerable respect and regard for Senator Watson's knowledge in these areas, on this occasion his argument does not hold up, if I may say so with the greatest of respect to him.

PARA.TAB: I have not said in the first instance that 10 per cent of the Qantas sale should be reserved for employee share ownership schemes. It is not the important point, I know. I referred to one body, the ACTU, asking for that to occur. But the amount and the manner in which an employee share ownership scheme will be applied is not resolved at this point. When it is, that is one of those issues that will be addressed. But the burden of Senator Watson's intervention appeared to me to be how this will impact on the price and whether we will be legislating to exempt Qantas from the legislation that is on its way to this chamber on employee share ownership schemes overall. I do not expect it is going to have an impact on the price of Qantas.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's got to!

—What I said in my remarks—this may be the point of misunderstanding—is that it is the intention to make the scheme consistent with the legislation that we are bringing, not at odds with it. If it were at odds with it, fell outside the legislation, was regulated and then required a fringe benefits tax, that would be one thing, but if it fell within the legislation as a proper employee share ownership scheme within the meaning of our intention, it would not attract the fringe benefits tax that Senator Watson referred to and have that depressant effect on the price. This, as I am informed, is the situation.
—It has to be attractive to the employees or they won't take up the shares.

—Indeed, it has to be attractive to the employees. The ability of employees to buy shares is motivated by a series of factors. Certainly one of the attractions is the pride of employees of having a chunk of the company for which they work and the satisfaction of having ownership in part of their employer. Nonetheless, it also has to be attractive from other points of view, too. But this is what the minds of those who are working up the scheme is bent to doing and it would be inappropriate, I think, to have a debate on the legislation on the bill on employee share ownership schemes in the forum of this Qantas bill. Let us have that debate when that bill comes forward, rather than have the debate twice over but on a measure which is not the measure of Senator Watson's concern.

PARA.TAB: I am advised, and I repeat to the Senate, that this scheme is not yet devised. When it is and it is presented, it will be consistent with the objective of the government, fall within the meaning of our intention and not be a means of tax rorting or avoidance but be a genuine scheme. It is my understanding that it will not have the effect that Senator Watson has so colourfully asserted it will.
I think Senator Short's question was about the impact on the 1994-95 budget estimates. He referred to the concept that there would be a hole in the budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —A fact.
—It was an assertion by Senator Short, if I might say. He may regard it as a fact, but I would regard it as an assertion, with the greatest of respect to him.
—It has to be a fact if the proceeds aren't received.

—No. Perhaps if he listens to the explanation I can clarify the point for him. It is the intention of the government to complete the sale within the financial year; in which case, the proceeds would fall within the parameters of the 1994-95 budget forward estimates. The concern Senator Short has about a hole being created would not arise.

—In response to Senator Cook, of course, the hole would not arise if the proceeds were received by 30 June 1995; that is quite obvious. But one of the essential amendments in this bill, indeed, perhaps the most significant amendment provision in the bill, is to extend the sunset clause which now exists from 30 June 1995 to 31 August 1995—in other words, to extend it two years into the next financial year, that is, the 1995-96 financial year.

PARA.TAB: In doing that, there have been statements by senior government economic ministers—I think both the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance—that, given the procedures that are required in terms of progressing the sale, given the size of the float and the capacity for it to be placed in the market and given the timetable associated with the 1995 budget in May, the government believes that there is a real possibility that the proceeds will not be received before 30 June 1995. That is the reason why we have the extension of the sunset clause. If that does happen, there is that hole in the budget. My question to the minister was: in the event of that happening, what provision and plans do the government have to fill that hole?

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe the minister might like to answer the two questions together as he did on the previous occasion. Will the minister not concede that when the employees share ownership was first discussed by the board of Qantas, it was working on the premise of the previous legislation which did not impose a fringe benefits tax on share ownership schemes. Will the minister not concede that in all share ownership schemes the shares are effectively issued at something of a discount? Therefore, under fringe benefits tax legislation currently before the parliament such a discount would attract a fringe benefits tax type liability. Otherwise, there would be no incentive for the employees to take up the quantity of shares that the trade union movement, the board of Qantas, the management of Qantas or even the government would like.

PARA.TAB: There has to be some adjustment in the sale price or else there will be a strike not only by the employers around Australia not to issue new employees share benefit schemes but by the employees themselves in terms of their refusal to take up an entitlement if that discount is not sufficiently attractive. Whichever way the minister looks at it there is a downside to it that I would like him to address.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —With the greatest respect to Senator Short, perhaps I should address Senator Watson first because his comments are freshest in my mind. When one gets into the realm of speculation, the `what if' realm—what if this and what if that—one can paint all sorts of scenarios, and often the mind wanders to bleak ones: what if this; how do you get out of that; and those other problems.

PARA.TAB: The reason why I cannot answer Senator Watson's question in specific terms, and therefore dissipate his concern, is that the proposal itself is not finalised. When it is, then we will see how it satisfies all the conditions I have suggested it is intended to satisfy are met. But the scheme is being developed now with a clear understanding that it should fall within the meaning of the government legislation and not, as I am advised, attract a significant cost.

Let us allow the people who are doing this to do their job and come back with the final proposition and see how they meet it. There are challenges inherent in it but the art of good government is to recognise challenges and to overcome them. To Senator Short, quite a bit can be said about the sunset date. Division 4 of part 1 of the schedule to the amending bill alters the automatic sunset date, to which Senator Short has referred, prescribed by subsection 2(6) of the Qantas Sale Act. This section currently provides that any elements of the sale act which are not commenced by 30 June 1995 are repealed. The amendment bill alters the sunset date to 31 August 1995, as he has said.

The change to the legislative sunset date is to provide administrative flexibility in relation to the public offer of shares in Qantas, scheduled for the period April-May 1995, particularly if the government decides to hold the float following the May 1995 budget. In that event, the public offer could be launched in mid-May 1995 with the objective of completion several days prior to 30 June 1995.

If that occurred, it may not be administratively possible to arrange before 30 June for the proclamation of provisions of the sale act, which are intended to commence following the offer, in which case—and I think this is the point—the float could be completed but the legislative framework for ensuring the transition to a fully publicly owned body would not exist and would need to be re-enacted.

An extension of the two months in the sunset date is proposed in order to cover all eventualities should there be unforeseen developments which affect the timing of the commencement of the float. This raises the possibility that, if there is a delay of a week or two in the float timetable, the sale proceeds may not be received in the year 1994-95, as provided for in the budget estimates. However, it is the government's unequivocal intention that this objective be achieved. Therefore, planning for the float is proceeding on the basis of finalisation before 30 June 1995.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Cook) read a third time.
Motion (by Senator Cook)—by leave—agreed to:
That the order of the Senate of 29 November 1994, relating to the consideration of legislation, not apply to the AeroSpace Technologies of Australia Limited Sale Bill 1994.

DEBATE.TITLE: AEROSPACE TECHNOLOGIES OF AUSTRALIA LIMITED SALE BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 8 November, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The AeroSpace Technologies of Australia Limited Sale Bill 1994 has as its main purpose the establishment of a legislative framework for the sale of the government owned AeroSpace Technologies of Australia, commonly known as ASTA. Another purpose of the bill is to ensure that specified ASTA employees who continue to work for the company after it is sold will retain accrued public employment entitlements and obligations.

PARA.TAB: The bill also provides that, from the date of sale, ASTA is treated as a private sector company and is not subject to Commonwealth legislation which currently applies to ASTA because of its status as a Commonwealth owned entity. Finally, the bill also has as its purpose the recognition and continuation of certain rights and obligations which arose before the sale, particularly in relation to corruption offences.

ASTA is an important organisation. It was formed in 1986 out of the old Government Aircraft Factories and has around 700 staff. It is involved in civil and defence aircraft component design and manufacture. It is also involved in aircraft maintenance and it runs the Avalon airport in Victoria, near Geelong.

The government took a decision in December 1993, I think it was, to sell ASTA. There has been some controversy in recent weeks as to whether the contents of the cabinet minute that reflected the cabinet decision—and the minute has become public in recent weeks—in terms of the assessment of the corporation are in line with the fairly bullish press statement that the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) released after the cabinet had taken its decision. When the Minister for Defence—ASTA falls within the defence portfolio—announced that the corporation was going to be up for sale, he painted a reasonably rosy picture, whereas the cabinet minute had certainly been much more sanguine about the matter and about the prospects for the company. There was some debate on that in the other place and I do not propose to traverse it again.

The fact is that the company is now trading profitably. I do not know what the government has as an estimated value of the company on sale. According to a recent report in the Australian Financial Review, it is expected to be worth around $50 million. Press reports indicate—and I think the minister has tended to support this, but I cannot confirm it—that the government, following calls for expressions of interest in advertisements that appeared a few weeks ago, has two interested buyers in ASTA.

The coalition supports the bill. We have no problems at all with the proposed privatisation of ASTA. Indeed, at the last election it was on our list for privatisation. As the pioneers of promoting privatisation in Australia, we fully endorse moves to sell government commercial trading assets. We see no need for the taxpayer to continue to own such a company. As I said, we will be supporting this bill to facilitate the sale. In doing so, I repeat that it is an important operation. I hope that privatisation and the benefits that can flow from that will lead to benefits for the company and that we will see it go from strength to strength in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —The AeroSpace Technologies of Australia Limited Sale Bill 1994 provides for the sale of AeroSpace Technologies of Australia Limited, which the government has been trying to orchestrate for some time to minimise its losses. That it has not been able to sell ASTA previously in profitable years says more about the current state of defence industries today than it says about ASTA in particular. The last profit and loss statement of ASTA shows a loss of $490,882. This has occurred while the company has been thoroughly propped up by government subsidies.

PARA.TAB: Since its inception the government has made total payments to ASTA in the order of $161.5 million. This is openly admitted in the 1993-94 budget statements. There have also been two loans on top of this: one for $8 million for a short-term working advance, which was repaid; and the other for $3 million under Loan Council borrowing arrangements. I suspect that the clauses at the end of this bill relating to an exemption for the new owners of ASTA from borrowing levies will apply to outstanding loans such as this.

This bill importantly looks after the superannuation and benefits of those 700 workers at ASTA. But what the bill does not explain is why the taxpayer had to prop up this unprofitable organisation for little return. When it comes to the sale of ASTA, what does the government expect to receive? Who has expressed an interest in buying? Are they foreign or domestic buyers? Will the money we receive from the sale cover the $161.5 million injected into ASTA throughout its lifetime?

The government should consider any ultimate losses Australia may receive from selling off ASTA. The government will be tempted to sell ASTA at a low price to get it off the government's hands and stop the steady flow of subsidies into the annual budgets of ASTA. The government will be unsure whether there will be any potential buyers for ASTA with its export dependence and reliance on the contracts of the small and inefficient defence industry of Australia.

The situation that ASTA is faced with is one experienced across the board by defence industry in Australia. This is the post-Cold War reality of the lower global demand for arms exports and equipment. In fact, since 1987, when the value of the world trade in major conventional weapons was at a height of $45 trillion, there has been a decline of about 60 per cent to a world value in 1992 of $18 trillion. The market that has sustained this trend is the Asia-Pacific, which is currently experiencing an arms build-up that every man and his dog are trying to capitalise on, including us.

Since 1987 many multinational defence companies have reconstructed, severely cut back or gone under. In the current scenario, however, these multinationals are concentrating on the Asia-Pacific market, a market not renowned for its human rights, democracy, civil or political rights; we are also concentrating on that market. We combine our arms export push into Asia with the rhetoric of `building regional security'. We cannot, however, compete with global arms companies which have the advantages of economies of scale and global market. This trend is only going to continue.

We must, therefore, re-examine the destabilising effect our arms exports have on the countries around us. I note that, although we do not have a perceived large external threat, we have exported millions of dollars worth of arms to our neighbouring governments with little regard for their use against innocent civilians in internal oppressions.

As leaked in the Australian newspaper on Monday, it seems that one of our major defence white paper initiatives will be to consider a highly expensive military spy satellite to monitor troop, arms and equipment movements in the Asia-Pacific. Are we not existing in a parody which ultimately results in a diversion of billions of dollars away from needy people and worthwhile projects to be spent on defence?

ASTA has in its own way been a success. In its beginnings it started off with a $30 million loss and has worked its way up to a half a million dollar loss in 1992-93. It has minimised its losses only by moving out of defence contracts and into commercial aircraft maintenance. Many companies, like ADI, are in a similar position in having to diversify into commercial areas to stay viable.

I note from the annual reports that both ADI and ASTA have gone into land speculation. ADI wants to develop a 4,000 strong housing development, and ASTA has 4,000 acres at Avalon on which it is hoping to make money. Any sale of ASTA would, I expect, fully value that land and the sale price. It is worrying that ADI is involved in land speculation. One would think the lessons had been learned from the $250 million loss in Western Australia due to WA Inc. Might I remind the Senate that ADI has received $366 million and so far has escaped accountability with that payment.

All in all, I hope that the burden of ASTA on the taxpayer can be resolved in the near future by its sale. I hope, however, that this will entail selling ASTA for a higher price than our total investment through years of subsidies. I hope that it will mean a higher domestic ownership; that we can keep aircraft standards under our wings and the entrepreneurial threat of bogus parts out; and that ASTA will further diversify in order to survive and move away from its unprofitable reliance on defence contracts.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The AeroSpace Technologies of Australia Limited Sale Bill 1994 establishes the regulatory arrangement allowing for the privatisation of the AeroSpace Technologies of Australia group, formerly the Defence Aircraft Factories. While there are no figures in the bill, the ASTA annual report lists the net assets of ASTA as being worth about $220 million. As we have heard already in the debate this morning, the proceeds of this sale will be paid back into consolidated revenue and used to prop up the government's deficit reduction strategy.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats find themselves in a bit of a quandary over this bill. We have always adopted the view that privatisation should be considered on a case by case basis. When it is determined that there is no compelling case why the asset should be retained in public ownership, we are not afraid to recommend privatisation.

But, on our way to that determination, we look at issues like the public interest, the existence of monopoly or community service obligations and whether the taxpayer is, in the long-term, better off holding the asset in revenue than disposing of it. We do not look simply at privatisation as a form of short-term revenue raising, as I think the government and the opposition often do. It is worth noting that, over the life of the deficit reduction program—as I said in my previous speech on the sale of Qantas—the government is planning $8 billion worth of asset sales or about two-thirds of the difference between the deficit at the beginning and that at the end of the program.

ASTA was formed as a commercialised government trading enterprise in 1986 from the old debt-ridden and inefficient Defence Aircraft Factories. Since then, it has developed into a model of a hard-edged GBE, or GTE. Sales revenue has risen from zero to $150 million—83 per cent of that in export sales. Despite the worst downturn in the aerospace industry in recent years, ASTA recorded respectable before-tax figures and abnormal profits of $8.7 million in 1993.

The ASTA components group has received high level accreditation as a supplier to both McDonnell Douglas and Boeing. The aircraft services group has won heavy maintenance and pilot training contracts with ANA at the Avalon facility near Geelong. I think ASTA's management and its 1,600 employees can be pleased with that performance. ASTA owns and operates an airport at Avalon. While the buildings and hangars are nearly fully utilised, we believe that the airport itself is still underutilised. I presume that selling ASTA means selling the airport as well. Perhaps the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) could confirm that for me?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—It does. Is this our first privatised international airport? The aerospace industry also has significant spin-offs for the rest of our economy. Prominent new growth economist Paul Romer points out that the industry leads to significant flow-ons in research and development, and ASTA, with the emphasis on out-sourcing—that is a horrible word—is no exception.

PARA.TAB: There is the dilemma. Here we have a viable, fairly successful government enterprise operating in a cutthroat and very tough global economy. Do we sell? It is also worth pointing out that ASTA is pretty much all we have left to show for what was once Australia's vibrant and dynamic aerospace industry. In our view, the industry was an early casualty of protection levels reduced too quickly with no follow-up industry policy or further development.

If ASTA goes to the wall, basically, we have nothing left. I think this has very serious strategic implications for Australia, if ever we are caught in a war or cut off from major suppliers. ASTA also continues to play an important role in the design, manufacture, repair and support work for defence aerospace systems. We think this work should remain in Australia.

On the one hand, as I said, we have ASTA doing what the opposition says it ought to do—competing in the world market—and we could argue that the government really does not need to be involved in this industry. On the other hand, ASTA has important strategic implications, not just as a major defence supplier but as a vital home industry. I think it is important that Australia retains a viable aerospace manufacturer, but it is not as important that the manufacturer be publicly owned.

If ASTA is sold, as I expect it will be, I think it would be very important for any contract of sale to include some key national interest considerations. The prospective buyer should, first, guarantee that strategically important facilities remain in Australia; second, ensure that as much as possible the research and development work is undertaken in Australia; third, commit ASTA to pursuing an export strategy; fourth, commit itself to further investment and expansion of ASTA; fifth, if the sale includes Avalon airport, the prospective buyer should undertake to develop an access regime which will better utilise the facility and complement regional development strategies in the Geelong area; and, sixth, it should ensure that as much as possible the employment of existing employees is continued.

I note that the parliamentary secretary addressed some of these issues in his second reading speech, but the word in parliament is, try standing between the Department of Finance and a prospective pot of gold as part of an important deficit reduction strategy and see how long parliamentary assurances in second reading speeches stand up. Perhaps the minister could repeat some of these reassurances today.

These conditions make this sale a little different from other sales. In the case of the sale of the Moomba gas pipeline, the Senate originally set conditions on the sale, including the satisfaction of an access regime and proper compensation for the extinguishment of contractual rights which the government had to meet. The Democrats were considering an amendment to test the Senate's resolve to do that again. We thought it was appropriate to set conditions that the sale not be effected until satisfactory assurances were received from any would-be purchaser. I have not done that, but I have certainly placed on the public record our view of the obligations that prospective purchasers should be beholden to in Australia's interests. This is an important asset that is being sold; Australia should get something out of it in the long term.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the AeroSpace Technologies of Australia Ltd Sale Bill 1994. AeroSpace Technologies of Australia, commonly referred to as ASTA, is proposed for sale. As I understand the debate that has been put forward by three senators in this chamber representing the coalition, the Greens and the Democrats, no-one is gainsaying the proposition that ASTA ought to be sold. What we have is a congruence of view that that, in these circumstances, is acceptable. I use the word `acceptable' not to describe the government's view but the chamber's view. However, a concern was articulated by Senator Kernot on behalf of the Australian Democrats about the nature and Australian content of such a sale.

PARA.TAB: The first point is that I agree with the consensus that has come forth about the sale of ASTA. The question raised by Senator Kernot, and I think referred to by other speakers, is an important question. When one looks at ASTA, the first and most obvious consideration is the strategic importance of having on our shores an aviation company able to do the defence work that ASTA can do and able to keep in Australia valuable technology and expertise for the aviation industry. Thomson Radar CSF, the French conglomerate which won the contract for re-equipping Australian airports for radar from the CAA, has decided to locate in Australia a regional headquarters for the whole of the Asia-Pacific area. This is a European company choosing Australia as the base for its radar production for the whole of the Asia-Pacific region, the fastest growing aviation area in the world.

One of the reasons why this major international company chose Australia was the high quality of Australian expertise, technical expertise in particular, in this field. It is important to note that we place a premium on the fact that ASTA embodies, along with a couple of other companies in Australia, expertise in the aviation area, both for defence and civil aviation, that a developed country should want to have—not at any price but on a commercial and viable basis.

Therefore, in terms of the sale of ASTA one of the presiding principles is finding a buyer which can add to the viability of the company, which can bring some new investment to the company, which can generate this company into a more export orientated company and a company able to capture some of the large opportunities in the Asia-Pacific market, and which can add to our base of technological understanding in this field.

The government's preference is for majority Australian ownership of ASTA.
