But, as I have said, the government is seeking a buyer, or perhaps buyers, able to demonstrate a capacity to provide synergistic benefits to ASTA; that is, to support the government's commitment to the ongoing development of a strong export oriented domestic aerospace industry and to maintain employment in that industry. I think that is as far as I can go in answering the questions Senator Kernot has raised.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know you want to do it but will you, can you?

—That is what we are looking for in terms of a buyer. When I said that a cardinal principle or a ruling objective was that purpose, I put that at the top of the list—certainly consistent with the price considerations that might be reached. The strategic considerations of maintaining the entity in this way are of that stature and importance to us. I commend the bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Motion (by Senator Cook)—by leave—agreed to:
That the order of the Senate of 29 November 1994, relating to the consideration of legislation, not apply to the ANL Guarantee Bill 1994.
Debate resumed from 16 November, on motion by Senator Schacht:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ANL Guarantee Bill 1994 gives the Treasurer or his delegated officer on behalf of the Commonwealth government the authority to guarantee payments under loan agreements entered into by ANL Ltd, which was formerly called the Australian National Line. Let me say at the outset that the coalition opposes this bill.

PARA.TAB: The financial impact of this bill appears to be uncertain and open-ended. I will pursue the financial obligations under this bill further in the committee stage. Indeed, I will not say too much during this second reading debate because there are many specific issues I would like to take up and they would be better dealt with in the committee stage.

But I draw the attention of honourable senators to the debate on this bill in the other house and, in particular, to the contributions by my colleagues the shadow minister for transport, Mr Sharp, and the shadow minister for privatisation, Mr Moore, which have outlined in some considerable detail the really very sad and sorry saga of this whole ANL exercise and the duplicitous way in which the government and, in particular, in more recent months, the Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton, have handled this whole issue. The way the government has handled this whole question of ANL is absolutely disgraceful.

The Labor government's stated need for this bill is that it will `help ANL to continue to trade in an orderly fashion, especially during the restructuring process in which the company is currently involved'. That is not a justification for this bill. Rather, it is simply a quite pathetic excuse for the bill. The real reason for this bill is that it provides a taxpayer guarantee to any loans so that the Maritime Union of Australia and its partners—and any partners it can coax together into the ANL deal in terms of shareholding—will be able to take over ANL free of any financial risk. All the risk will be left with the Australian taxpayer. That is what this bill means.

What a deal that is for the unions—a tremendous deal for the unions, which have been absolutely bought off in this whole exercise. What a deal it is for the Australian taxpayer, left with an open-ended commitment of potential financial liability so that the government can do a deal with its mates in the unions, particularly the Maritime Union of Australia.

This is only part of the disastrous underhand deal that the Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton, and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) did to buy off the Maritime Union of Australia. The Maritime Union of Australia held this nation to ransom by shutting down our wharves for a week. In return—and there have been suggestions, which I have not heard refuted, that the strike was contrived and staged in the first place anyway—that union got the biggest reward imaginable from the Labor government. It got this deal that any loans to ANL would be guaranteed when the union tried to buy it. Given the way in which transport minister Brereton has handled this and the public statements he has made, he has absolutely crucified the potential value of this potentially very important asset. He got up and said that the line was not worth anything—that it was worthless. He acted in a way, either consciously or unconsciously, which had the result of greatly undermining the confidence that potential buyers could have in this line and therefore in the value of it.

Then he dealt in the Maritime Union of Australia as an actual part-owner for when the whole thing comes together. So we might finish up with the union getting the line for a song—and bringing in its mates to share in that—because the government has, by its comments, down-valued the real value of the asset; and at the same time we have this bill which guarantees, at taxpayers' expense, the loan liabilities to the company. It is absolutely disgraceful.

Not only that, but the union got an income tax exemption for its international crew members and a stop to real competition in coastal shipping. All this adds up to a federal government—I was going to say, eating out of its hands; but that would be too weak a description. The union has a federal government bowing in absolute subservience, contrary to and against the wishes and interests of the Australian taxpayer.

ANL has been for sale on the market for over three years now. The government has made an absolute mess of its handling of this asset sale, as it has with many other aspects of its assets sale program. Earlier today we went through the Qantas sale debacle that has been going on now for something like four years. ANL, the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation and the airlines have been for sale for years. In the case of Qantas—and there is every sign that it has been happening here, although to a somewhat different degree—the government continually changes the environment in which the particular asset is operating. What the government did there in changing the policy so far as airlines were concerned was legion. We have had continual chops and changes in ANL and others as well. No wonder the asset sales process has been the debacle that it has.

But the ANL sale debacle has severely undermined the operations of the company. It has left a cloud over its future. According to the old board—a board that Minister Brereton summarily dismissed in August in the most outrageous, discourteous way possible—it has cost ANL dearly in business terms. As I said, the government has savaged the value of ANL, and Minister Brereton, in his recent shake-up on this matter, was on the record as saying he `could not give ANL away'. What a statement for a minister to make when his government is about to proceed to try to sell the asset as a going, viable operation. So much for the actions of this minister. He is an absolute disgrace. As a result of that, his mishandling of the ANL sale has cost taxpayers very dearly. If this bill is passed, it will continue to cost taxpayers dearly for potentially well into the future—virtually open-ended.

Sadly, the government has had 11 years—it is getting on for 12 years—of responsibility for transport policy and, during that period, the running of ANL. Surely that is more than enough time to provide the environment and conditions for a company to be profitable and competitive. Instead, by a deliberate process of underfunding the company, refusing to fund the company, refusing to give it the opportunity to be competitive and viable, the government has run it into the sand and left it absolutely stranded.

This bill is not the way to deal with ANL. This is a nightmare of a bill so far as the implications for the Australian taxpayer are concerned.I said at the outset that the coalition will be opposing this bill. We are not opposing the bill because we oppose the sale of ANL. On the contrary, we support the sale of ANL, and we always have. It is the government that is the Johnny-come-lately relative to the coalition in terms of its preparedness to sell ANL.

Let me make it absolutely clear we are not opposing this bill because we are opposed to the privatisation of ANL. We support the privatisation of ANL. We are opposing this bill because it is a completely unnecessary bill. It is a bill that should never have had reason to come into this place. It has come into this place only because the government has allowed itself to be totally manipulated and dominated by the Maritime Union of Australia and other influences—one can only imagine what some of those may be—that have had a detrimental effect on the value of the asset. This bill will just compound the debacle that the government has presided over so far as the whole approach to ANL is concerned.
It is for those reasons that we will be opposing the bill. As I foreshadowed earlier, in the committee stage of the bill I want to put several specific questions about this matter to the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The effect of the ANL Guarantee Bill is to provide a Commonwealth guarantee of the debts of the Australian National Line. The aim is to allow the restructuring of ANL to proceed without raising the prospect of re-financing. This is obviously a measure to avoid frightening the horses—more particularly, it is a measure to avoid frightening the financiers to whom ANL is currently in debt.

PARA.TAB: As everyone should know, the intended endpoint of the restructuring process is that ANL will no longer be in public ownership. The disposal options include a float, a trade sale and a de facto liquidation with a soft landing. A union led buy-out has been put on the agenda following the recent waterfront strike.

It is well known in the chamber that the Australian Democrats challenge the theory of privatisation always. However, it is difficult to argue that the public service provided by ANL, which is hardly essential compared with those provided by such agencies as Telecom and, of course, Australia Post, is worth the drain on taxpayer funds caused by the continuing large losses. The resolution of the waterfront strike has removed any effective constituency for continued public ownership of ANL and the Democrats do not propose to prolong the debate by arguing for it here today.

Indeed, there is room for considerable doubt as to whether ANL is salvageable to any significant degree. The Price Waterhouse/ Salomon Brothers valuation suggested that a managed trade-down—in effect, an informal liquidation backed by a Commonwealth guarantee—was the most likely outcome of the sale process.

The Democrats hope that for the sake of the workers and the viability of the shipping industry ANL can continue as a going concern using Australian crews on Australian award rates. The sceptics will no doubt claim that insisting on Australian conditions increases the risk that ANL will never be viable and, indeed, cabinet last year seemed to have formed that view itself when it decided to scrap that sale requirement. It is up to the new board to set ANL on an even keel without sacrificing that important condition.

As I understand the opposition's position, it does not take issue with the government's view that it should guarantee ANL's debts. If the government did not do so, not only would the restructuring of ANL be hampered but also the credit rating of the Commonwealth would be in some considerable doubt.

Where the opposition departed from the government during debate in the other place was over the need for legislation. As Senator Short has confirmed today, the opposition has persuaded itself that there is no requirement for this bill, while the government begs to differ. The Democrats, for our part, are a little more persuaded by the government's arguments than by those of the coalition. The Audit Act does appear to require legislation before a guarantee can be given, so we will in fact support this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to speak long today on the ANL Guarantee Bill 1994, but I do think it is necessary to put a few comments on the record. As Senator Short has mentioned, a good deal of the problem in relation to ANL has been of the government's own making—in fact the vast majority, in my opinion. He has mentioned the capital starvation that has occurred, and there seems to be quite a lot of evidence of that.

PARA.TAB: There has also been asset stripping—I suppose the kind of thing corporations did in the 1980s—which means that there is an intention to sell eventually and to make money out of what is there in the meantime, but the whole process is thereby made less viable. The context in which all of this has occurred is that of removing any real industry policy from this industry and from many other industries in Australia.

It seems to me that this policy of removing an industry policy or stepping back from industry policy has a lot to do with the egos of those people who have been negotiating for the new trade regime internationally. Australia is wanting to be seen to be leading the way, even though it is foolish and naive to leave our industry stranded in doing so, and not to be looking at the interests of not only the workers in those industries but also of those other industries which depend on a good standard of shipping for Australia.

People have heard me on the record say why we need a decent shipping standard. If we lose our national line and our state lines we know what this might mean. We then have no standard by which to compare other shipping standards. We have already seen a higher percentage of flag of convenience carriers operating here and elsewhere. It is part of the new international deregulated trade regime.

We know how easy it is for carriers to gain a flag of convenience registration. We know what the implications could be if we have a major oil spill, which, I certainly know from what has happened in Western Australia, we have avoided more by good luck than by good management. What will be the economic, environmental and social cost if our lack of industry policy in relation to shipping does result in a major maritime disaster? Who will pay for that? Will it be the government? Will it be the taxpayer? I suspect it will be the community and the environment, because those shipping lines which do not have a strong financial base behind them will be unable to find the money because of the way they are put together. Therefore, we are rushing blind into a situation.

I realise this current situation with regard to the guarantee is as a result of putting ANL between a rock and a hard place. The unions representing the shipping industry are being put into the same place. I believe it is not a satisfactory situation. Our support of this current bill is not because we think it is the best solution. It is the solution that has been worked out by bad policy and it is perhaps the best of a number of evils at this stage.

I do believe it is not too late for the government to seriously look at our interests in relation to shipping; to seriously look at what we are giving away voluntarily under the service provisions of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade; to seriously look at whether or not our negotiators in these international fora are doing the right thing by our industry, our environment and our community; and to seriously look at what the implications could be in relation to APEC of going further in some of these particular provisions.

I think it is time that some of these things were challenged by the community, once they realise that these things are not happening by accident. Industry policy which relates to environment and welfare employment is being changed by decree from on high, and our negotiators in the international fora are trying to lead the way. So the government is very culpable in just about every way we can think of in this regard. It is not good enough. We will support this legislation but feel that the government has a role to play, and ought to be doing so, as far as shipping industry policy in Australia is concerned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the ANL Guarantee Bill 1994. Three speakers in this chamber have contributed to the debate on the second reading. Senator Short, from the coalition, indicated that the coalition—the Liberal Party and the National Party combined—will oppose this measure. Senator Bourne from the Australian Democrats indicated that, with some reservation, the Democrats will support this measure. Senator Margetts, who has just concluded her address to the Senate, indicated that the Greens, if I might editorialise her contribution, will support this measure, although somewhat reluctantly and with considerable reservation, while calling on the government to address other aspects of trade, GATT, APEC, and so on.

PARA.TAB: On that summary of the positions of the parties, and given that the government will support this measure, it is clear that this bill will have a second reading and may indeed pass. Senator Short has indicated that he has a number of questions to raise in the committee stage about the technical operation of the bill and issues relating to the financial guarantees. He also spoke briefly but pungently attacking this legislation.

I will summarise the government's position. It is a matter of observational fact that the ANL over the years has had a rocky history. Because the maritime industry and shipping has been a difficult area, from time to time governments have had to make tough decisions about what should be done to keep the ANL service operating on an even keel. The government has injected large amounts of taxpayers' money into this shipping line in order to do just that—to keep it afloat and operating.

Earlier this year the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) dismissed the board of the ANL and instituted a new board which will report on how the company can be restructured, what the options are for its future, and how it can remain viable. That new board will report at the end of February next year.

This bill arises because there is a need to guarantee the debt of the ANL in order that the board—the new board, which is looking at the restructuring and the ongoing viability of the show and at future options—has time to complete its work, free from anxiety and concern about those who are in debt for the ANL and in order to ensure a proper commercial arrangement for the ANL's creditors. This bill is a holding arrangement so that a properly constituted and capable board can bring down a report about the future of the outfit. If this bill gets knocked off, in effect it would be the vote of the Senate not to extend the opportunity to find a way out of the ANL's problems.

From the indications of support around the chamber, this bill will not be knocked off. But the opposition, which wants to defeat this bill and which aspires to be the alternative government, obviously, as oppositions are wont to do—I make this as an observation rather than an accusation—wants to make life as difficult as possible for the government and put obstacles, confusion and argument in our way at every turn. That is democracy; that is what we expect. We bear it and get on with the job.

But the opposition has a wider responsibility. It has a responsibility not simply to oppose but also to say what it stands for. What would it do if it were in government? How would people judge it if it occupied the government benches and were in charge? One can only draw from its dog in the manger posture, its wanting this bill to be defeated, that it wants to `run the ANL into the sand', to quote Senator Short, by not extending the proper commercial cover for the board, which is now bringing down a report on the ANL's future viability, for it to be able to operate and for proper consideration about the future viability of the shipping company to be made. By wanting to defeat this legislation, it wants to defeat the ANL.

The obligation is on the opposition to say what it would do. It has taken comfort in opposing and, as one would expect, making life uncomfortable for the government. But it is not saying what alternative proposals it has for the shipping line, other than some vague reference to selling it. I do not think that is a responsible position for the opposition to take. As in the past, people will continue to judge it as being incapable of governing, capable only of thinking in negative and defensive terms.

To this stage the debate from the opposition has not extended beyond that point. I wait with interest to see the questions that will be raised by Senator Short. I acknowledge the qualifications and the reservations expressed by the other supporters of this legislation. I recognise the value of the constructive way in which they have been put forward by the other parties. The government has taken note of those. I will certainly refer them to the minister. Obviously, we treat with great seriousness the remarks that have been made. I commend this legislation to the chamber.
Question put:
That this bill be now read a second time
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I foreshadowed in the second reading debate, I have various questions that I wish to put to the minister about the aspects of the bill. Firstly, though, I will respond to the minister's assertion that the opposition's voting against this bill was simply designed to obstruct the proper or desirable processes of the privatisation of ANL. Nothing could be further from the mark, of course.

PARA.TAB: Everything we see before us today in this bill is a living example of how this government cannot properly manage a commercial enterprise. We should not have this bill today. It is simply wrong for the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) to go out and tell the world that, in his view, we could not give away ANL. It is a disgraceful thing for the minister—who is charged with the responsibility of selling an asset at the best price for the Commonwealth and, therefore, the taxpayer—to do.

The fundamental problem with ANL today is a problem that has accumulated for many years under this government. The problem is that this government has deliberately starved ANL of capital over nearly 12 years that the Labor government has been in office. That is why ANL has the problems that it has. It is not because of any incompetence on behalf of the board. One of the problems that the board of ANL faced right through the period of the Labor government was that every time it requested capital injections, necessary capital injections, the government was loath to provide them.

The question that the minister ought to answer, and he put questions to me in the second reading debate, is: what would have been the case if the government had sold ANL some years ago and allowed a private sector operator to own and operate it? What would have been the saleability of ANL if the government had had half an ounce of commercial commonsense and put the necessary capital into ANL to allow it to be competitive and viable? What would have been the case if those things had happened? If they had happened, I would put a few dollars on the fact that ANL would be in a considerably better position and much more secure than it currently is today.

Indeed, I dare say that ANL, which has been traditionally starved by the government of capital over the last 10 or 12 years, would have found itself in a much better financial position for sale some years ago, with its private sector operator taking over a company that was much better placed for the competitive world of today. So the minister should not go on with this cant to me about the coalition being obstructive in terms of the sale of ANL. We have had the sale of ANL on our agenda for years now. We also had the proper financing and funding of ANL on our agenda, had we had the opportunity in government to have done so. I wanted to put that on the record. Many other things are on the record in Hansard in the other chamber on this debate, to which I refer honourable senators because there was a good debate, and very significant contributions were made by both Mr Sharp and Mr Moore.

I ask the minister an initial question. It is a fact that the government owns all the shares in ANL. The government is the owner of ANL. Given that that is the case, I ask the minister: why is this bill necessary at all? Why do we need legislation in order to guarantee the debts of the company when the 100 per cent owner of that company is the Commonwealth?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short has put a question to me, which I will answer. I would like to make one or two remarks about the editorialising in which he engaged before he came to his question. Perhaps the record needs to be straightened up on some of the points that he put. The first point he made—and I took this down—was, `How can the government manage a commercial enterprise?' He asked that with respect to the ANL—that we have somehow bungled managing a commercial enterprise. ANL is not a statutory authority. We are not managing it in that sense.
—I didn't say you were managing it; I said `enable it to be managed commercially'.

—Well, we are the sole shareholder in ANL. ANL is a company incorporated under the Corporations Act, and therefore we have had in place a commercial board. A commercial board has been able to manage the company but with considerable difficulty over a number of years, up until the point at which we felt it necessary, as the shareholder, to dismiss that board and replace it with a tougher, leaner board able to look at long-term prospects for its viability and to restructure the company. That is a responsible exercise of authority by the government. It is not a question of running the show into the ground; it is a question of looking at how the long-term commercial viability of the outfit can be guaranteed.

PARA.TAB: In February we will receive a report on those options from the current board. This bill is about ensuring that the company survives until then and beyond then so that those options can be properly considered and implemented. The main theme of the allegations made by Senator Short by way of interjection and during debate—I took these words down; I hope I am accurately quoting him—is that we have `starved the ANL of capital'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Senator Short acknowledges that; I thank him for doing so. Since 1983 we have provided capital injections to ANL. We came to power in 1983. When a government provides capital injections, it takes taxpayers' money and puts it into a commercial operation. Obviously, the viability of that commercial operation is a major consideration in whether one is wasting taxpayers' money or using it constructively to keep an operation going which will be viable. We have put $160 million of taxpayers' money into ANL since 1983.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short's confirmed assertion is that we have starved ANL of capital. I do not think that $160 million of taxpayers' money is starving an operation of capital. It is in fact supporting it with capital. Since we have to husband the taxpayers' purse with responsibility, we cannot keep doing that. We ought not keep doing that if questions of commercial viability are involved. That is why we have come to the decision that we have to call a halt to that process, look at the alternatives for restructuring the company, and look at the alternatives for its longer-term viability. We need to carry this bill to guarantee that ANL can continue to exist. We need to ensure that the $160 million of taxpayers' money has not been money up against the wall, that it will not have been wasted and that there will be some advantage to the nation.

In five of the past seven years the company has experienced operating losses before interest and before tax. Why would we inject more funds into an outfit which is in that situation without calling a halt to the process? Even if that company now had no debts whatsoever, even if it were debt free, it would still be making a significant loss.

In relation to Senator Short's assertion—he has confirmed this is his assertion—that we have not supported the company and have starved it of capital, $160 million does not sound like starvation to me. But, in any case, there is a responsibility on the government to ensure that it uses its taxpayers' dollars wisely and not as a bottomless pit. The commerciality of a company and its ability to trade successfully are fundamental considerations in what we do with taxpayers' dollars. Let me move, however, to Senator Short's question which related to the present state of the company and whether it is as a result of—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, my question was: given that the government owns the company 100 per cent, why does it need the guarantee provision at all?

—The legislation is necessary—I think this is set out in the second reading speech—because of the specific requirements, as I am advised, in the Audit Act 1901. This bill will guarantee all of the debts. The bill of itself does not guarantee all of the debts. The bill authorises the guarantee of repayments of principal and interest under loan agreements. But, due to the specific restrictions imposed by section 70B of the Audit Act, other debts and liabilities do not need legislation but may be guaranteed by executive action of ministers without the need for specific legislation. According to my notes, the short answer is that, because of the requirements of the Audit Act, we require this bill in this manner. I have confirmed that with the officers.

—I, too, have read the government's second reading speech. I do not think it answers my question. My question is a very simple one. The government owns an asset 100 per cent. The Commonwealth government is normally regarded as being a pretty safe borrower, if you like, because it always guarantees its borrowings and the borrowings of its operations. Why, in those circumstances, do we need a separate bill to guarantee the liabilities of a 100 per cent owned government enterprise?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Now we are clarifying the question.
—That's what I asked the first time—and the second.

—Well all right; Senator Short may have done that, and he has now at least clarified it a third time. The simple answer is that ANL Ltd is exactly what Senator Short has described it as and exactly what I have described it as—it is a company.
—Owned 100 per cent by the government.
—It is a company registered under the corporations law and owned 100 per cent by the Commonwealth—that is to say, the Commonwealth is the sole shareholder.
—That's absolutely right.

—I am pleased we have true communication here. Let me move from that concept to the next concept. The responsibility of a shareholder to a company is the value of the shares—the limit of the shareholding. There is no guarantee beyond the shareholding in the company. That is why a guarantee in this legislation is necessary. A simple reading of the Audit Act shows that the bill is needed in order to guarantee the other debts. It might suit Senator Short or others to argue this point, but that is the advice we as the government have. What are we supposed to do? Are we to ignore the official advice put to us as the government and rely on the amateur interpretation of members of the opposition, or are we to take—
—I think that is hardly fair.

—If opposition senators want to have a go, they should not mind if I have one back. But are we to ignore our advice about the Audit Act or are we not? We have presented this bill because of the advice we have about our obligations under the Audit Act. Opposition senators say, `We have a superior understanding of what the requirements here might be.' It may even be true that they do. Nonetheless, we are bound to observe the advice we have. That is what we are doing and that is the reason for this bill.

—I take it from what the minister has said that, if an asset borrows money, the Commonwealth government—being a 100 per cent shareholder, the only owner of that asset—would walk away from the responsibility of meeting the liability. Is that what the minister is saying? If that is what he is saying—and it seems to be—then he ought to have another think about that because that has enormous implications.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am always delighted when people put words into my mouth. I am not saying that; I am saying what I said. Our advice is that our obligations under the Audit Act require us to carry this legislation.

—I cannot give the minister any more chances to answer, so he will just have to live with his words on the record. Has the Auditor-General reviewed the proposed guarantee? If he has, what comments did he have?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the question is: has the Auditor-General had a look at the guarantee and expressed any views about it? The answer to that question is that there are no guarantees at the present time. This legislation is required in order to clothe the Treasurer with the ability to issue those guarantees. If this bill is passed, we meet the requirements, as we are advised, of the Audit Act. The Treasurer is then in a position to move and issue a guarantee, and that would be what applies in those circumstances. I would need to take advice on whether or not the Auditor-General has a role on that. In answer to the specific question Senator Short has raised, there is no role for the Auditor-General at this point.

—I think I asked: has the Auditor-General reviewed the proposed guarantee—and that is what it is—in the bill enabling the Treasurer to guarantee certain debts of ANL? That is in the explanatory memorandum; that is what the bill is all about. Has the Auditor-General had a look at this? Has he reviewed it? What advice did the government seek from the Auditor-General? What clearance did the government seek from the Auditor-General? What comments did the Auditor-General have?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my turn to make fun of this question, with the greatest respect to Senator Short. The government does not ask the Auditor-General to review its legislation. The Auditor-General has a statutory responsibility to the Crown to conduct proper audits of government departments and authorities. But we do not go to the Auditor-General with our legislation and say, `Please would you run your eyes over this and give us a clearance to enact this legislation?' As I said in my answer to Senator Short's last question, the role of the Auditor-General may arise—and I would need to take advice on whether it does or not—with respect to any guarantee that is offered by the Treasurer should this bill be passed and the Treasurer be clothed with the power to do so.
—But the bill clothes the Treasurer with the power to do so; that's what the bill is all about.

—That is what I am saying. If Senator Short had stopped trying to find holes in the argument and actually listened to the argument, he would have heard me say twice now that the purpose of this legislation is to give the Treasurer that power, consistent with our advice on the need to do so under the Audit Act, and then the Treasurer presumably would move to exercise that power; and at some point there may be a role for the Auditor-General, I do not know. But we have not submitted—and it is not appropriate that we should—this legislation to the Auditor-General for his views about it. We have other ways of forming an opinion about the legality or otherwise of this legislation. Indeed, it may well be not entirely the province of the Auditor-General to express issues on points of law.

PARA.TAB: The other point that I think is worth making in this debate is the question of market confidence, and it is really an issue for the opposition to ponder. There may well be political points made by pursuing the line that the opposition is pursuing; that is a choice for the opposition. We will, of course, deal with that. But for the government too there is a need to maintain and to bolster in a positive way, where we possibly can, the confidence of the market in ANL. If one runs a big scare campaign, a `what if' campaign or a `there are strange things happening here' campaign, which seems to be what the opposition is doing—and the opposition ought to recognise this—that does have the potential to damage the confidence in ANL as a commercial entity in the market in which it is operating and at a time when it is struggling. I guess that is for the opposition to decide; but I think it is appropriate for me to draw it to the opposition's attention and place it on the record because it is a consideration that the government has in these circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just commenting on that latter point—and I do not want to get into a continuing slanging match with the minister—it is absolutely extraordinary for him to say that we have anything to answer for in terms of market confidence in ANL. It was the government's minister responsible for this whole operation, Mr Brereton, who was the person who said, `You couldn't give ANL away'—the most disgraceful statement that one could possibly have right at the start of a sale process. So the minister should not come to me and to the opposition talking about market confidence. The government is the one that has absolutely destroyed the market confidence in ANL and its value.

PARA.TAB: My next question is: did the Department of Finance comment on this guarantee proposal? If so, what comments did the Department of Finance have? Has it supported this proposal?

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two questions, the answers to which are: yes and yes.

—The explanatory memorandum refers to the government's intention to guarantee ANL's existing debt and any further drawdowns on its $100 million promissory note facility. How much is ANL's existing debt?
—I am advised that at the current time ANL's debt in total is $180 million.
—Will all of that debt be covered, potentially, by guarantees if the bill is passed? Will it apply to the whole $180 million of debt?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill will only cover loan agreements. The rest of the debt is covered by the executive powers already vested in the Treasurer.
—Will all the drawdowns from the $100 million facility be covered?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that if the board asks for them the government can consider it, in which case, if it agrees, all the draw-downs can be covered within this bill. But I should point out that I am also advised that at the present time, I guess not surprisingly given the considerations on the mind of the board at the moment, there is no request from the board before us.
—Did I get the minister right? Did he say that `the government would consider it' as distinct from `the Treasurer would consider it'?
—I think Senator Short did, and I am glad he raised the question. I meant to say the Treasurer.
—When might the minister expect the first guarantee to be entered into?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —That assumes the legislation is carried and the Treasurer is in a position to do this. That is a matter for the Treasurer. I understand the Treasurer has, as an interim measure, provided letters of comfort for some of the institutions involved but I also understand that, at the present time, the board has not framed further requests.

PARA.TAB: Just to enlarge on that answer, it is our understanding that the financiers are sufficiently happy with the letters of comfort offered by the Treasurer at this point. But obviously with this bill being carried and the Treasurer's powers being widened as a consequence, it may be—and I put it no higher than that—that further guarantees beyond the level of a letter of comfort may be necessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which financiers is the minister talking about?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of financiers. There are a number of well-known Japanese financiers and some Australian ones. I very shortly expect to be able to tell honourable senators their names. I was just seeking advice as to whether this is a matter for the public record and I am told that it is. The Japanese financiers are, I am advised, Mitsui, Tokai and Nippon. I guess they are all the banks under those headings. From the Australian side, the State Bank of New South Wales, Westpac and, as well, the Bank of Paris are the financiers in this case. I think that covers all of them, or at least the major ones.

—Is the minister in a position to tell the committee what sort of conditions will attach to any guarantee? Are there standard provisions? Is there a sample draft guarantee document available? Will there be time constraints on how long the guarantees run? Is there any information on those things?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —There may be conditions, and I think some thought has been given to how that might be done. But clearly, each case has to be considered separately and in its own particular circumstances. I do not know that there is a general rule here, but there may be conditions applied.
—Is it possible to have a virtually open-ended time limit on any guarantee? Is there anything that precludes that?

—As I said earlier, this is a provision to get us through with this company to the new board's recommendation about future options. For example, if I might hypothesise, if there were an option for sale at some point which was exercised, guarantees would be limited to that option and the restructuring necessary to be carried on. Thus, part of such a process of sale would likely involve the negotiation of those guarantees in the sale process to ensure the future viability of the company.
—Am I correct in my understanding that that does mean that a guarantee could continue for well after the sale by the Commonwealth of ANL is concluded?

—We are in the realm of hypothesising; we are in the realm of `what if this and what if that'. As a consequence, one cannot be prescriptive. Obviously, these things are dealt with in the circumstances of the time. But the guarantees are related to maintaining the future viability of the company and providing a basis for it to operate in some way. If the company were to be sold it might be a consideration that in certain circumstances commensurate with risk factors, and an evaluation of what those risks might be and what is reasonable, such a guarantee could continue. But I underline, put in italics and put quotation marks around it to emphasise the speculative nature of all of this—it might. That is a matter for the circumstances, obviously.

—I take it from what you say that there is nothing in the bill that precludes a guarantee extending potentially, hypothetically, theoretically—whatever we might call it—well beyond the point of time at which the Commonwealth's ownership, involvement and otherwise in ANL is concluded. I understand that that is what you are saying.

—At this time, such a proposition is entirely speculative. That is why I put it in italics, underlined it and put it in quotation marks as well. But the other factor that always has to be borne in mind here is the risk factor and that is, I think, a very powerful factor in these considerations.

—Depending on what sort of answer I get, I think this will be my final question. Is the guarantee intended to apply only to the MUA lead consortium to buy ANL or will it be offered to any and all potential bidders for ANL? If it is exclusively for the MUA, why is that so?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Since this is the last question, I must try to give a clear answer. The guarantee is not aimed at anyone and it is not specifically aimed at the union situation at all. It is for appropriate decision in the circumstances.

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on a matter of public interest. There are few matters of greater public interest in this country than taxes and what is going to happen to them. Bernie Fraser, the Governor of the Reserve Bank, announced this morning that, in his view, taxes must rise. What he is really saying is that the current level of revenue in this country, despite what Mr Keating has said, is simply not sufficient to bring the deficit down. Undoubtedly, the Governor of the Reserve Bank knows, as we know, that Mr Keating is not prepared to cut spending in any way. So his only option is to raise taxes.

PARA.TAB: The second issue I raise is providing fuel to this tax speculation. It was revealed last night before an estimates committee that the government response to the climate change convention and the government options to reduce greenhouse gas emissions are now going before the cabinet. Given that this is a Labor government, senators will not be surprised that, in this cabinet submission, there is a range of options to increase taxes. Whether they are called energy taxes, environmental levies, carbon taxes or fuel excises, they are taxes and they will be coming out of the pockets of ordinary Australians.

I will focus on the matter of taxes and, in particular, the likelihood that this government will raise fuel excise taxes. I will look at the government's record in relation to fuel excise taxes and its performance on road spending. I will conclude by looking briefly at Commonwealth government road funding grants to my own state of Victoria.

This week the Australian Automobile Association released its annual report and I congratulate the association. It drew to our attention, once again, the massive increase in fuel taxes which has occurred under this government in the last two years. Senator Sherry is at the table today. Does he know how much fuel taxes have risen since the Hawke government came into office?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I do.
—Senator Panizza knows. He looks closely at these things and effectively represents his constituents. Senator Sherry, if I said that fuel excise taxes have risen from 7c to—
—You should say it to the chair.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, is Senator Sherry aware that fuel taxes have risen from 7c a litre to 32c a litre under his government. Senator Sherry, am I right or wrong? Of course, Senator Sherry would say that I was absolutely right.
—I am reading figures that go down all the time—like you in the polling.

—I would have thought the taxes that Senator Sherry's constituents pay were of interest to him. Fuel taxes have risen from 7c a litre in 1983 to 32c a litre today. Since the last election there has been the largest single jump in fuel taxes on record, yet this was the election in which Senator Sherry and his colleagues went around Australia with Mr Keating and promised there would be no further tax increases. We all recall that fuel excises were increased in the budget from 26c a litre to 32c a litre for unleaded and to 34c for leaded fuel.

PARA.TAB: So where does all this lead us? It has meant that fuel taxes, which raised close to $1 billion in 1983-84, are raising close to $10 billion today. I wonder if Senator Sherry is aware of the impact on the average car owner since the last election. The average car uses some 2,000 litres of fuel a year. What is the impact on the owner of that car of Mr Keating's 7c a litre rise in fuel taxes? The answer is $140 per year. This is the man who said that there would be no rises in taxes. The problem is that, despite the huge rises in fuel taxes under this government, there is every prospect that motorists—and, of course, all consumers of goods and services, and so all Australians—are going to be socked with another rise in fuel excises. All this is from the man who promised not only that he would not increase taxes but that he would bring down taxes. I put it to you that this government has a major tax problem. It has before the cabinet next week a submission which canvasses various options to raise certain taxes on carbon fuels. I think it is no surprise that fuel taxes are once again in the sights.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard three tables. The first table shows how petrol taxes have risen to record levels under this government; the second table shows how the price of a litre of fuel is divided into taxes, dealer margins, state franchises and oil company revenues;

SPEECH.PARA: and the third table looks at the overall level of petrol excises, road funding, and road funding as a percentage of excise.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The tables read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: [TABLES OMITTED FROM DATABASE - SEE HARD COPY PAGE 3530]

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. It was interesting that in the Senate yesterday Democrat Senator Sid Spindler was concerned about fuel prices being paid by country people. I have said this to the Democrats time and time again, and every time they get up in this chamber and pretend to show some concern about the level of fuel prices I will remind them of it. Not only did they vote enthusiastically to increase fuel prices after the last election, despite the fact that it amounted to a broken promise, but their own policies constantly talk about the need for higher fuel prices. I would point out to Senator Spindler and his colleagues that over 50 per cent of the price of fuel paid by country people and by city people in Australia is taxation collected by Mr Keating at the petrol pump.

PARA.TAB: I draw the attention of the Senate to a second matter, which is that, despite the fact that there has been a massive explosion in fuel taxes under the Keating government, road funding, as a share, has declined. Mr Acting Deputy President, you come from the state of Queensland, where there is a great need for more roads. You will be interested to learn that, with road funding as a percentage of fuel excise in 1982-83, some 62 per cent of the taxes raised from fuel in that year was spent on road funding. After the lean Keating years we come to 1994-95. You will also be interested to learn that the current percentage of fuel excise which is spent on road funding is 8.4 per cent. Not only have fuel taxes gone through the roof, but road funding is being cut and the states, with their narrower revenue base, are being asked to take on more of this burden.

It is worth mentioning that, in my own state of Victoria, Victorians contribute about 27 per cent of Australia's fuel tax revenue and they account for some 35 per cent of Australia's commercial road travel. Despite this, only 16.5 per cent of this year's federal funding will be spent in Victoria. There has been a marked run-down of road transport infrastructure in Australia—I do not think there is any argument about that—and Victoria received only some 62 per cent of the funds necessary for maintenance of the national highway infrastructure in that state. Major road funding is not the only problem; we are also looking at further rises in fuel tax.

I conclude by quoting comments by Mr Tony Love, President of the Australian Automobile Association, in the annual report of the Australian Automobile Association. In the president's report, Mr Love writes about the increases in fuel excise, and he says:

SPEECH.PARA: The impact of these decisions is not confined to motorists, of course. Increasing the level of taxes on road users and reducing the level of expenditure on roads inevitably leads to higher transport costs, higher prices, higher inflation and less competitive exports.
It has been argued that Australia still enjoys lower fuel taxes and prices than most other countries, but that is misleading and largely irrelevant.

Among the countries which have a lower percentage of fuel tax than Australia are the US, Canada, Japan and New Zealand. In regard to actual fuel prices, those which pay more than Australia are invariably much smaller countries.
They do not have to contend with our vast distances and the consequent high cost of transport, which particularly disadvantages Australia's export industries.

The increasing tendency by governments to treat the fuel pump as a convenient and lucrative source of additional income is therefore shortsighted to say the least, although the temptation is understandable.

The latest increases in excise, for example, together with the twice-yearly indexation of excise rates, will help boost the Government's fuel tax revenue by an estimated $1100 million, or more than 13 per cent during 1994-95 alone.

Would that that were the end of the story but no, it is not. I predict that, regrettably, we are going to see higher and higher fuel prices in this country, which will make Australian industry less competitive and which will harm our export potential. There is a recognition, and correct recognition, in the business community and at least in certain sections of the Public Service, that one of the major aims is to cut the input costs to business and to cut taxes on inputs. Fuel excises, of course, increase the cost of inputs to business. Therefore, they make our exports, among other things, less competitive. I conclude by saying that this is going to become a big issue again. Fuel taxes and fuel increases are back on the Keating agenda, and motorists and consumers right around Australia had better brace themselves for further tax rises.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the horrific drought that is gripping eastern Australia at this time, a drought which the federal government seems to have very little interest in.
—Rubbish! What about our package?

—Rubbish, is it? I am glad the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) has raised the subject of the package. Does he mean that inadequate $164 million over four years for drought affected farmers? Does he know what percentage is actually getting this package for drought affected farmers? Does he have any idea that only six per cent are getting the package in this area? Is he aware that in northern New South Wales there is not one farmer getting any of this money? Is he aware that in the Upper Hunter there is not one farmer getting any of this money, and yet he is in environmentally—
—Where would you get more money?

—Where will we will get more money? I think that a government which throws money around like his does, which puts up proposals such as `Let's tear down the Cahill Expressway' and wants to spend money on that sort of nonsense obviously has plenty of money to throw around. The parliamentary secretary has got his priorities wrong, and it is about time he realised what is happening out in New South Wales. Has the parliamentary secretary been out to the drought affected areas?
—Yes, I have.

—How many has he been out to? Is he like the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and been out to maybe two or three in the last four years? The question the parliamentary secretary has got to answer is: why has it taken his government four years to discover there is a drought in this country? Why is it allowing people virtually to be on the point of starvation, virtually on the point of suicide?

PARA.TAB: If this were happening to tens of thousands of people in the centre of Sydney and Melbourne, there would be absolute outrage and his government would do something about it. But because it is in the bush, because it is a drought that creeps up slowly, the government does absolutely nothing. The parliamentary secretary would be well advised to sit over there and keep quiet, because he does not know what he is talking about; he has no solutions to this drought; he is doing absolutely nothing about this drought and really deserves the condemnation of this nation. Wait until we get to the ballot box next time. I can tell him where the marginal seats are in this country. They happen to be out in rural and regional Australia and people in those areas are going to bag the government like hell when it comes to the next election because it has done absolutely nothing.

Drought is affecting eastern Australia. When the government is not aiding in any shape or form 96 per cent of the farmers, and is giving absolutely no attention at all to small businesses in Australia in drought affected country—one-third of whom Telecom Yellow Pages claim are going to collapse in the near future because of lack of aid—then it is on the government's head and the effects are going to come back on it. The history of Australia over the last 15 years shows that this is a temporary boom we are in and that we will be in a downslide in the not too distant future, particularly if the government keeps jacking up interest rates and doing nothing about fiscal policy. If that is the case, then this drought and the effects on rural Australia will come back on the government well and truly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get your priorities right. You got it right all right.

—That is right. I thank Senator Panizza for that interjection. Perhaps the parliamentary secretary should sit down with some of the leaders of the civic communities in rural Australia. I challenge him to go to Moree and listen to the people in the Chamber of Commerce. Is the parliamentary secretary aware that at this cotton harvest time in Moree people are going on holidays because there is nothing to harvest? Normally 300 seasonal workers come into Moree to harvest the crop, but no-one is coming as there is nothing to harvest. This has sucked $5 million out of the rural economy.

PARA.TAB: What effect does that have on small businesses in those areas? I invite the parliamentary secretary to interject again and outline to this parliament what his federal government is doing for the small business sector that is affected by the drought—the one-third that are likely to collapse. What is the parliamentary secretary doing about the infrastructure of the towns of rural and regional Australia that are about to collapse? Because there is no farming income, the small businesses are hit for six and so is the rest of the rural economy. The parliamentary secretary does well to keep quiet, because his government really has no policy to respond to this drought.

Does the parliamentary secretary know what his colleague the member for Page (Mr Harry Woods) said should happen? Harry Woods is sitting on a margin of 100 votes. Harry Woods says that what the farmers should do is rely on the farmhand fund. Is that not terrific? Rely on charity. We have no government policy to help them but they can rely on charity. The farmhand fund is a great thing; it is doing great work but it is patchy in the way it hits rural and regional Australia. The Moree Chamber of Commerce told us that it could find only two people in Moree, which is one of the most drought devastated areas in Australia, who are receiving any money at all from that fund. Two people! I ask the parliamentary secretary: what happens to the rest of Moree? They do not get anything from his government, because basically his government does not care. It does not consider them its constituents so it just leaves them to hang in the middle of this worst drought in 100 years.

In contrast to what the parliamentary secretary has done, we have the excellent record of the Fahey government, which has much more limited resources than those of the parliamentary secretary. In August $22 million went in sensitively directed aid, followed by another $66 million since. It is not just a handout but it is comprehensive in providing rate relief, in getting fodder and water through to these areas; in providing cloud seeding to improve rain, in offering agistment of stock on state government land and in assisting small business through interest rate subsidies.

That is what the state government is doing. The New South Wales coalition government is responding sensitively to this matter. But the parliamentary secretary is not doing anything that is really effective. The only reason he got into it in the first place was the farmhand fund that raised money across Australia. People in urban areas woke up to how desperate things were in the bush. This happened and then the government begrudgingly came out with its mean-spirited package which offered money. With its usual trick, it quoted in one sum the money that will be made available over four years. We have to divide that $164 million by four to get to the annualised figure. Of course, 94 per cent of the drought affected farms will be missed.

Last week, my colleague Senator Troeth, Judi Moylan—our shadow minister for small business—Sandy Macdonald and I appeared at a drought forum in Casino. It is a great pity the parliamentary secretary and Paul Keating were not there. Those 80 farmers and the people associated with the farm industry told us about the problems in regional and rural Australia because of this drought that the government has totally neglected. The parliamentary secretary should have heard what they had to say, not only the farmers but people like Lifeline counsellors. It is a pity the parliamentary secretary is not listening to this, given his earlier outrageous interjections. He obviously does not care, as the rest of the ALP does not care about this particular problem.

What he has got to realise is that his drought package has to be far more sensitive to the actual conditions in this country. It might surprise the parliamentary secretary that a drought in an area like northern New South Wales, which normally has a high rainfall, can be far more devastating over the same number of months than a drought, say, in the western division of New South Wales, which is used to low rainfall. The vegetation and the fauna and the flora and the beasts there have made adjustments to the conditions they live under but that is not so in areas of normally high rainfall. Yet the government has this blanket rule: people must have had drought for 24 out of 36 months. Is that not terrific? The government has just supplied one blanket rule which has no sensitivity to the different ways in which the drought is affecting particular areas like the north coast and the Upper Hunter.

In case the parliamentary secretary is not aware of the pain and suffering and the circumstances that people are going through out there in the bush, let me read him a story that was reported in the Newcastle Morning Herald. This is the story of a Margaret Flannigan who lives on a property 45 minutes west of Scone. It is an area that does not quite make that 24 out of 36 months—it has occasionally had a good month of rain—so it does not count. However, the area is severely drought affected. Let me tell the Senate about Margaret Flannigan's situation. Margaret's husband is away for four months droving cattle in the long paddocks beside the road in order to keep them alive. She is wondering how she is going to cope. She has three children, she is pregnant and she is there managing the property. The creek has dried up and Margaret and the kids spend 17 hours a day dragging cattle and sheep from black soil bogs around depleted dams. They then have to give the sheep and cattle molasses and other feed supplements.

A farmer in Casino showed me his bill for supplementary feed. He spends $22,000 a year on feed that normally comes naturally but which he now has to provide. He is receiving absolutely no income, but has to spend $22,000 just to keep his stock alive. Obviously, the government is doing nothing for him, and nothing for Margaret Flannigan out west of Scone. Even if the government's package did get to her, it would not do very much to solve the problem: it is a matter of too little, too late.

I think the situation in drought affected Australia is best summed up by the president of the New South Wales Farmers Federation, Ted Henderson. Ted has written a poem about the effects of the drought and the government's lack of response to that. The poem is very long, and I propose to read only several verses of it now, but I would seek leave to incorporate the whole poem in Hansard.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Sherry

TALK.START.PARA: —Leave is given, but this is the second occasion that a proposed incorporation has not been shown to us. We should be granted the normal courtesies.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

INTERJECT.PARA: I've served many years at farming
Of sound knowledge I could boast
Worked the Western Plains a little
Spent a lifetime on the coast
Seen the floods back in the fifties
And the droughts afflict the forties
Thrust upon us in a trice
Used by us when there's no rains
Burning up our faith and pasture
Rivers, creeks, are all dried out
Shows us all no good intent.
Of our problems and our grief
That our stock lack feed and water
They have food upon their table
And a pay cheque every week
Why should they give one iota
If our outlook is all bleak.
For a drought is no disaster
'Till at least two years from start
But they never thought to tell us
How we'd manage all that time
Feed our starving stock and families
We look to for some hope
They claim to help us all
"We'd never turn our backs on you"
Are the echoing words of Paul.
But words are cheap and always will be
While pastures fry and cattle die
And even when the rain does fall
Takes months in time to halt decline
Will surely stuff our Country up
Their values and their logic are
This is the clever country though
It's just as well they deemed to tell us
"What a heartless bunch of Labour Feds
Sad at heart and yet content
'Till election of these MP's comes around
And the mark upon our ballot
Will no doubt leave us to say
"Out of office and Good Riddance sir"

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. A section of the poem reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Bob Collins is the Minister
We look to for some hope
But his obvious drought experience
Is clearly far remote
The party that he represents
They claim to help us all
"We'd never turn our backs on you"
Are the echoing words of Paul.
But words are cheap and always will be
It's action sir that counts
While pastures fry and cattle die
The tension surely mounts
And even when the rain does fall
And pastures grow again
Takes months in time to halt decline
And strength to all attain.
The full poem goes into the devastating nature of the drought and the government's lack of action in rural and regional Australia. The government stands condemned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise two very serious matters which occurred yesterday and which raise the gravest concerns about the competence of the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner. These matters raise very serious doubts as to whether the minister is fit to continue in the job. They also raise the further very serious issue of whether the minister has been misleading this Senate for a number of weeks now. The minister has claimed that, in relation to the Oyster Point-Port Hinchinbrook project, he was relying on advice. It is fairly clear from the evidence that the federal minister and the department were aware of the complete proposals for Port Hinchinbrook for some many months.

PARA.TAB: In the documents that Senator Faulkner tabled yesterday, as a result of the Senate's motion that he be required to do so, one of the most interesting documents is a memorandum from the department to the minister dated 22 September 1994. That advice from the department to Senator Faulkner had three major recommendations. The first recommendation or comment was at paragraph 21, which said:

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst maintaining reservations about the overall proposal as expressed at paragraph 16, the portfolio is generally satisfied that Queensland's approach, if fully adhered to, could address the four major areas of concern in relation to World Heritage.

There is advice from the minister's department that the Queensland approach would address any concerns that there might be. There was another recommendation at paragraph 20, where the department advises the minister:
The Deed of Agreement—
which has been referred to in the Senate—
is a comprehensive document and represents an approach not unlike what might have been expected from a full environmental impact assessment (EIA) process.

Whilst I and my staff are still going through it, that seems to fly in the face of what Senator Faulkner and other Labor senators have been saying about the non-existence of an environmental impact assessment and environmental impact report by the Queensland government over this period of time. Yet, in the minister's own departmental advice to him, that question is mentioned and the minister is told that that deed of agreement is of the same effect. Further, in the recommendation from the department to the minister of 22 September 1994 at paragraph 28, the department says:
The recommendation from the portfolio is therefore not to take immediate action under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act.

That was the departmental advice. The document is tabled and the whole letter can be read by the world. On 15 November the minister then had the Governor-General make a proclamation stopping work on the Oyster Point development. We questioned the minister about this and said, `You've known about this for months now. You've known that the mangrove trees along the foreshore were to be destroyed as part of the deed of agreement which your department has had for many months. Why is it now that after so many months you have changed your mind and you've stopped work?' The minister's response was, `I've got recent scientific evidence which requires me to do it and which shows that there will be an impact on the World Heritage values, on the seagrass beds, if those mangroves are destroyed.' That was on 15 November.

PARA.TAB: One of the other interesting documents that Senator Faulkner was forced to table yesterday is a letter dated 14 November—I emphasise that as being the day before Senator Faulkner stopped work on the project. On 14 November the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority wrote to David Kay, the Assistant Secretary of Senator Faulkner's department. All senators would know that the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority is the leading expert on the Great Barrier Reef and northern tropical waters. All senators would also know the very high esteem and regard in which the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority is held. In that letter from the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to Senator Faulkner's department on the day before he stopped work, paragraph 6 says:

SPEECH.PARA: Expert opinion by experienced surveyors is that the seagrasses within the potential arc of influence of the dredging can be protected by appropriate management . . . it is our belief that the effects of dredging will be much greater, in terms of sediment release, than the removal of mangroves, and that removal of regrowth mangroves presents very little threat to the seagrasses beds.

There we have, from this respected authority, the comment that the removal of regrowth mangroves prevents very little threat to seagrass beds. How can Senator Faulkner say that that sort of evidence, which was available to him the day before, caused him to issue that stop-work notice?

PARA.TAB: Further, Senator Faulkner has relied upon a report which he obtained from a Dr Valentine. When he was taking that report around he was saying how well Dr Valentine was regarded in environmental matters, although there were suggestions raised in the Senate that perhaps this was not as appropriate a person to give a report as could have been selected.In a letter dated 14 November, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority says:

SPEECH.PARA: We caution against basing any decisions solely on the opinions of either Dr Valentine or Mr Haigh and recommend seeking the views of seagrass, mangrove and dugong experts.

There is that recommendation, on the day before. I want Senator Faulkner to identify for the Senate and for the people of Australia just what it was—what recent evidence that he had before 15 November—which caused him to issue that stop-work notice. The most recent evidence, the letter from the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, seems to be quite to the contrary.

PARA.TAB: From that point, Senator Faulkner made what I suggest was a very desperate attempt to get himself out of the corner he had painted himself into. He was trying to do something about the exposition that this was, as Mr Goss said, nothing to do with the environment but all about internal Labor Party politics—the Left versus the Right, the payback for the knocking off of the Queensland left-wing member who was the Labor Party president but who was knocked off by Mr Goss and his right-wing faction.
So what did Senator Faulkner do? He set up a workshop of experts, convened:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to develop a consensus about the impacts of the development on the seagrass beds and other World Heritage values and ways to prevent adverse impacts. The focus will be on clearing of mangroves and related foreshore modifications.
What did this workshop of experts that Senator Faulkner set up come out with? This report was released very late last night. At page 4 it says:

Research shows that seagrasses in north-eastern Australia can tolerate and recover from considerable disturbance. Seagrasses can be lost from severe short term events such as storms or through deterioration in water quality . . . However, seagrasses have the capacity to recover.
Further on it says:

Research also indicates that in some tropical and sub-tropical areas, seagrasses have been unaffected by nearby dredging. The Working Group considered that a significant input of sediment adjacent to the development site would give a moderate risk of localised loss of seagrasses but recognised that there would be a high probability of recovery (within about 12 months) . . .

There is the workshop of experts saying what I said yesterday, in this parliament, in a much less scientific and a much more ordinary way. Local people had told me that. They had never been consulted by Senator Faulkner—he was too lacking in intestinal fortitude to go and talk to the locals. Had he done that he might have saved himself enormous embarrassment and what I suggest should be an end to his career as a minister.

PARA.TAB: This report of the workshop of experts goes on to point out that there are approximately 2,400 square kilometres of mangroves in tropical Queensland. In the Hinchinbrook Channel there are 164 square kilometres. There are 38 different species. The effect on fisheries habitat and coastal food chains around Oyster Point of the direct act of the removal of foreshore mangroves would be minimal compared to the total resource in the channel. So there is this report saying that for the small amount removed the effect on the fisheries habitat and coastal food chains in the total resource would be absolutely minimal. The working group's view was that the removal of the four hectares of mangroves could have an impact on the adjacent seagrasses. But the report said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . this gives a moderate risk of localised seagrass loss adjacent to the development. However, there would be high probability of recovery (within about 12 months) . . .
In the short term, the potential for sediment loss on the foreshore due to removal of the 4 ha of mangrove will be minimised if no more root material is removed.

If the trees were entirely removed it could cause some problems, but if the root stocks stay there it is okay. The whole report puts a view absolutely contrary to what Senator Faulkner has been telling this Senate for the past four to five weeks. The report goes on to say:
If management is good, the development may have minimal effects on mangroves and seagrass.
But it does point out:
The current state of the site poses a significant erosion hazard with the imminent onset of the wet season.

Again, I have been warning Senator Faulkner about this. He stopped the development. It is half done. It is in absolutely the worst possible condition. Any local in North Queensland will tell you that if you are disturbing soil you have got to get it fixed up before the wet season comes; otherwise you cause all sorts of erosion problems.

PARA.TAB: Senator Faulkner, the so-called environment minister, has absolutely plagued the environment in that area by stopping work and making sure that it will not start again before the onset of the wet season. We are now in for real environmental problems as a result of Senator Faulkner's incompetence—as a result of him playing politics with this matter rather that worrying about the environment. The report continues, refuting time and time again the things that Senator Faulkner has been telling this parliament over the last four to five weeks. I urge all senators to look at the material that was tabled yesterday and this report of the workshop of experts, because they are very important.

Something needs to be done. I have asked Senator Faulkner to go and talk to the people. He has refused to do that. I want him now to apologise for the 40 jobs which he has cost that local community. I want him to apologise for the costs of $1 million that will be added to that project. More particularly, I want him to apologise for the division that he has caused in the once friendly and happy community of Cardwell. Senator Faulkner has a lot to answer for, and he really must apologise and do something about it now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a brief contribution to the matters of public interest debate this afternoon. As part of the Liberal Party's 50th birthday celebrations around Australia it conducted a national essay competition. In our true federalist style as a party, we also awarded prizes for essays that were of particular value in each state. In Tasmania the winner was Donovan Walker, who is in grade 10 at Parklands High School.
