The essay competition was arranged by former distinguished senator Shirley Walters and Guy Barnett on behalf of the Liberal Party. The three people who judged the competition were Michael Bennett, Professor of History at the University of Tasmania; Keith Mackriell, ABC correspondent and broadcast manager; and Julie Roberts, President of the Tasmanian State Schools Parents and Friends Association.

PARA.TAB: In their letter back to the Liberal Party they indicated some things that should be brought to the attention of the Senate. They all agreed that the quality of the many essays is very high, making their decision about the top three entries particularly difficult. I take this opportunity to congratulate Kate Griffiths of Burnie High School and Kate Willoughby of St Brendon Shaw College on receiving the second and third prizes respectively.

The judges of the competition thought it appropriate that the quality of these essays be given a wide audience and, as a result, the Liberal Party published the essays. They also suggested that every possible effort be made towards providing a larger forum for the essays. I intend to read to the Senate the winning contribution by Donovan Walker, which he entitled `What being an Australian means to me'. Donovan's essay is optimistic, it has a balance of pride in Australia without going overboard and it reflects a lot of values. It gives me confidence in the future generation of young Australians which is growing up in this great country. The essay is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Most people from any area of the world dream of living on an island. I live on the largest island in the world. There is no other place like it and it is this isolation that has made my home an incomparable, unique country. I live in Australia.

For me, being an Australian means optimism and opportunity. We have been called the "lucky country" but we make our own luck by working with positive attitudes and taking on tasks with a special blend of enthusiasm, enterprise and courage.

To be an Australian means to grow up in a society with freedom of choice. This is a luxury that we should never take for granted. I can have the confidence to publicly speak my mind without the concern of being fined or thrown into prison. I can also choose the path that I wish to follow in my career, in my choice of religion, and in the political party that, I think, will give me the best future. I can travel and explore any part of the country I wish, to explore the truth of our culture and heritage. All Australians have these freedoms.

Australians are individuals like no other people in the world. With our `laid back' attitudes, we are sometimes mistaken for being lazy and apathetic. The `She'll be right, mate' cliche seems to fit us very well. Though, admittedly, we are sometimes easy going, we are a thoughtful and optimistic nation. We never feel the need to rush or hurry blindly into things before they are carefully considered. This is a real advantage. We have a relatively stable political system, a friendly rivalry between states and a united but not fanatical, national pride. Many other countries, like America, Europe and Asia have experienced the brutality of civil war where countrymen and neighbours become sworn enemies. Australia has had no real experience of this. However, we are prepared to defend the rights of others and to stand up for what we believe in. We are also tolerant of other cultures and of people with differing backgrounds and welcome their contributions to our developing sense of nationhood.

Australia is not afraid to take its place in the world in a responsible and sensitive way. We have been leaders encouraging world sanctions to protest against the injustice in South Africa when harsh Apartheid laws could no longer be ignored. We have also provided aid to developing countries in both Africa and Asia and have been more than generous in our response to world disasters.

I believe that this is a sensible and responsible attitude from which other countries should learn. It has given us a sense of pride in our country and its people whilst enhancing the tight bond that continues to grow across Australia.

As we grow towards true independence as a Nation there remains a feeling of `mateship' and companionship that is so vital to this land. Australians respect this rare quality, as they do the land and its people. These qualities that have made Australia what it is today are more valuable than anything any other country could offer. So when I am asked, "What does it mean to be an Australian?", I think of our vast coast lines and endless beaches, the magnificent red centre and the fertile coastal plains, the exotic plants and animals, the warm and friendly people with a wide range of attitudes and beliefs and their unique outlook on life and I would not want to be anywhere else.

That was the contribution of Donovan to the national essay competition. Those who have just listened to his contribution would undoubtedly agree that he was a worthy winner of the first prize. His contribution was truly Australia, it was optimistic, it was indicative of the balanced pride he felt in his country and he displayed a good use of language. In short, his contribution was excellent, and I have great pleasure in taking this opportunity to afford my congratulations to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on this occasion because I heard only part of Senator Ian Macdonald's contribution—I did not hear it all. I feel there is a need to clarify a number of issues in relation to the scientists' report on the Port Hinchinbrook development, because I think that senators would agree that, just as few politicians can totally agree on issues, few economists can agree on issues, so scientists can have differing opinions and differing emphases. The conclusions in this report are instructive in pointing to the direction in which the developer at Hinchinbrook and the three levels of government should be working, if the current impasse is to be resolved.

PARA.TAB: While I obviously commend the very strong stand that Senator Faulkner has taken, I think we all agree—Senator Faulkner obviously agrees—that we must resolve this current impasse. It is not going to help for people to continually argue about the fine details of who said what, when and who was more to `blame' than the other. As we have said a number of times in this place, the issues are basically very simple. Sometimes simple issues are more readily confused.

Essentially, this is about a project that got through the Office of Coordinator-General without a full environmental impact assessment, an EIA. That is a process that most people around Australia expect—an environmental, economic and social impact assessment. That assessment was never done. I do not know why it was not done. Maybe the Office of the Coordinator-General is new to these issues and thought that an environmental review would be adequate. Clearly, events illustrate to us that an environmental review has been totally inadequate. That is really where everything went wrong.

Senator Macdonald has been critical of Senator Faulkner's role. I guess, from an opposition perspective, one could argue that that is Senator Macdonald's role. If senators read the Hansard and letters that Senator Faulkner has released, they would find that Senator Faulkner spent many months working through these issues, trying to resolve what he knew was a complex and difficult issue, but trying to resolve it in the best possible way to protect World Heritage values. He did not once say, `No, this development must never go ahead.' He said, `My responsibility is to protect World Heritage values.' He had the Valentine report. He has talked to Minister Robson; he has talked to Premier Goss; he has talked to the developer. He also commissioned the work of the one-day meeting of scientists.

Of course, it depends which sections of the scientists' report that are quoted and which idea is sought to be clarified. I want to put very firmly on the public record, as I believe I have done on other occasions, that this issue is not a win or lose issue. In terms of World Heritage and the Franklin dam debate, someone had to give way. It was hydro-electricity or World Heritage, and World Heritage was seen as the more significant. In the case of the wet tropics, it was the timber industry or World Heritage, and World Heritage was seen as more significant in that instance.

In this instance, the two are quite compatible. There can be a resort; World Heritage values can be protected. There has been a failure at government level, and we can debate why that has happened. We have had a failure at government level to move in adequately at the right time and to set the right standards so that the developer, Mr Williams, would know precisely what he could and could not do and what protections were necessary for this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Queensland government did that.

—Senator Macdonald will not be surprised to hear that I blame the Office of the Coordinator-General because I do not think the World Heritage issue even dawned on it. I think it just thought that this was another fast-track development and away it went. Look what has happened as a result! We might differ on this. That is the background, Mr Acting Deputy President. I know you are very interested in and concerned about the mangroves, so I will talk about that aspect now. I have highlighted what I see as fundamental to this argument. The conclusions say:

SPEECH.PARA: Seagrass beds in the Hinchinbrook Channel are a significant resource and a valuable feature of the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage Area. Scientific evidence indicates that turbidity is a significant factor affecting the growth and the distribution of seagrass communities.

So there is agreement on that point. All the scientists, regardless of their differences on a few other points, agree that the seagrass beds are a significant resource and a valuable feature of the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage area. It is Senator Faulkner's responsibility to protect that World Heritage area.

PARA.TAB: What do the scientists suggest? I must admit that I like people who prepare a report to make some recommendations. That is what I expect in a report. I find it a little frustrating in this report that the authors draw conclusions and do not make recommendations. Nevertheless, these are the conclusions that they have come to. They talk about future short-term actions and they say:

SPEECH.PARA: Future short term actions should therefore be aimed at stabilising the sediments in the foreshore area of Oyster Point:
.the remaining mangrove root stocks should remain in situ; and
.removal of felled mangrove material should be completed in such a way as to minimise disturbance to sediments.

I have tried to be somewhat conciliatory on a number of issues relating to this dispute, but I must admit that I find it rather difficult to be conciliatory towards the developer, Mr Williams, when he said last night on the ABC 7.30 Report that he wanted to get rid of all the mangroves, wherever they are. I do not see how someone who wants the value of an ecotourist development between two World Heritage areas can say that he wants to get rid of the mangroves. It is a contradiction in terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think he really meant it, or do you think he was a bit angry like your Prime Minister is sometimes when he says things he does not mean?

—I would say to Senator Campbell that what people say under pressure is always debatable. I will agree to leave that point there. In the longer term, the scientists say, development of the foreshore requires a foreshore management plan. Frankly, I cannot see how a foreshore management plan includes a beach. If we are going to protect the roots of the mangroves, if we are going to ensure that there is a recognition of the significance of mangroves to seagrass beds as a valuable feature of World Heritage, I see that beach as inconsistent. The boardwalk concept through the mangroves is unique and much more likely to attract tourism than, as I have said before, an artificial beach on a channel—a channel that has crocodiles, not to mention marine stingers at certain times of the year. The report goes on to note that mangroves provide an effective means of stabilising such foreshores and that the two species that presently constitute the narrow fringe readily coppice and can be trimmed.

PARA.TAB: With every respect to my colleagues in Queensland, I believe that no-one can say that there has been high quality site management to date, when we look at what happened in the removal of those mangroves and the subsequent vandalism with chainsaws. No-one can say that that is high quality site management. That is why it is so important that top level discussions between federal, state and local government and the developer are held as soon as practicable. The four respective parties need to sit down and say, `Right. What is possible? What is not possible? What are we going to do to ensure that we can balance the needs of a World Heritage area with the needs of many tourists who will, no doubt, want to utilise the resort facilities that Mr Williams wants to provide?'

In conclusion, I refer to a point that I do not think was mentioned by Senator Macdonald. I apologise in advance if it was. It concerns dugongs and turtles, a much more significant drawcard to Mr Williams's tourist resort than crocodiles and marine stingers. The report states that the adult survivorship of dugongs and turtles must be very high—greater than 90 per cent—for dugong and green turtle populations to be maintained. This is influenced by food availability. The report continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Seagrass is an important source of food for dugongs and green turtles; however, not all seagrasses are of equal importance . . . Should there be a local loss of seagrass in the vicinity of Oyster Point, this would reduce food availability to dugongs and green turtles . . .

Quite clearly, while the scientists have come up with some very important points for consideration, they have not yet absolutely made a recommendation in relation to mangroves, except to say that mangroves are essential for stabilisation and mangroves are critical to the protection of those vital seagrass beds if we are to guarantee the survival of dugong and turtles.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a 30-second comment about the drought in response to Senator Tierney's speech earlier. I want to pick up a couple of matters. Firstly, Senator Tierney mentioned that only two people were receiving support in the Moree area. I find that difficult to believe as Moree is one of our exceptional circumstance areas and people in that area would be eligible for drought relief payment, which can provide a family with around $20,000 per year. Farmers in the Moree area should be approaching the Rural Assistance Authority for an exceptional circumstance certificate in order to receive their fortnightly payments. If there is a particular problem I will be discussing it with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins).

PARA.TAB: Secondly, Senator Tierney referred to the $164 million as being made available over four years. That is not correct. It is being made available over two years. We should not forget that the next cabinet meeting will be considering the second part of a package of assistance to drought areas. The package that has been developed to date—developed by the minister, Senator Collins, and developed by the Prime Minister—and that will be considered by cabinet at its next meeting, we believe, is effective at targeting assistance where it is most needed in an effective way.
I move:
That the sitting of the Senate be suspended until 2.00 p.m.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Last night, the Governor of the Reserve Bank pointed out that Australia's performance relative to APEC nations was poor, that current wage claims are excessive and that the current account deficit will be much higher than the budget forecast. In fact, he said:

QUESTION.PARA: If we want to enter the next century with a greater measure of control over our own destiny as a nation, economically as well as politically, we need to lift our efforts.

Is this not a withering vote of no confidence, which means that the last six years of pain and agony have been utterly wasted? What is the minister's government going to do to address this fundamental economic crisis? Will he or will he not rule out an increase in interest rates before Christmas and an increase in taxes before the next election?

TALK.START.PARA: —To say there is an economic crisis confronting Australia at the moment is so far from the truth as to be absolutely ludicrous. The reality of the matter is that the national accounts figures that have been released today show that this country is unequivocally riding a boom and, moreover, that the circumstances of that boom are such that the growth that we are achieving is sustainable at a very high rate.

PARA.TAB: The boom is something that should not be the subject of the kind of negative carping response we are getting from the opposition. It is terrific news for Australians, in particular those Australians who have been out of work. We have had 13 consecutive quarters of trend growth. We have just recorded growth on year to year to the September quarter of 6.4 per cent, which makes us, right now, at the top of the table so far as the major OECD economies are concerned. That growth has meant that we are well on the way to putting unemployed Australians absolutely back to work, with 403,000 new jobs created since April 1993, the bottom of the trough, with 90,000 of those jobs being for the long-term unemployed, and with extraordinarily good prospects for those who are still out of work because of the sustainability of the present growth environment.

We are not facing a bust because all these circumstances are different from those that we had to confront before. The basic difference is that inflation and inflationary expectations are at historically low levels. We have seen from this morning's figures the basic inflation rate—the GDP non-farm deflator—coming in at just 1.1 per cent for the last 12 months. We are talking of basic rates of inflation of around two per cent now as compared with seven or eight per cent at a similar time in the last recovery, with expectations realised last time of 10 to 11-plus per cent.

We are talking about a current account deficit—yes—which is growing because of the surge of capital imports feeding the investment boom at the moment, but also about a current account deficit running now at 4.1 per cent of GDP as compared with 6.1 per cent at exactly the same stage of the last recovery cycle. We are talking about an environment of fundamental, achieved structural change, which means that we can continue to look forward to major exports in a way that simply was not the case before—a sustainable growth.

We are talking about continuing excess capacity in the Australian economy, which will clearly ease any demands that might otherwise be building up towards inflation. We are talking about a very strong productivity dimension to wage bargaining, which is going to keep that wage pressure under control. We are talking overall about a rolling recovery that is by its very nature much more sustainable than the kind we saw before when every component of demand came together simultaneously to create an acceleration in the environment.

We have a boom on this occasion that began with an increase in consumer demand and dwelling investment, with business investment phasing in, cutting in, at a later stage. We are now seeing a potential falling back in that private consumption, certainly a falling back in dwelling expenditure, but a maintenance at the same time and an expansion of business investment. So we have an environment of sustained recovery and sustainable recovery which is very different.

Of course we are conscious of the need for the Australian economy not to overheat. Of course it is the case that fiscal and monetary policy will both continue to be adjusted accordingly. But let no one misunderstand, and let no one understate, the magnitude of the achievement that has been made with the Australian economy and the figures that stand there on the record to back that achievement up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. So everything in the garden is lovely, is it? Those opposite are the new fairies at the bottom of the garden, presumably. So what is Bernie Fraser on about when he says that the government needs to raise taxes, that the country is going down the Argentinean path and that the government needs to make fundamental changes to economic strategy? Is he just another carping critic to be dismissed or are those in the government just going to hold back and commit the usual electoral fraud—do all these things after the election, if they get the chance? Why will they not face up to economic and political reality? Are they simply wanting to do what Cain did to Victoria, Bannon did to South Australia and Burke did to Western Australia?

—When is the opposition going to tell us what it is on about so far as its program is concerned? Its finance spokesman, Mr Costello, said this morning on ABC radio that the opposition is going to cut outlays by $11.7 billion. That is what Costello says this morning; that the opposition is going to cut the deficit by $11.7 billion. Add that to the increase in outlays of $10 to $12 billion—

—I take a point of order. How can what Mr Costello said have anything on earth to do with Bernie Fraser's resounding vote of no confidence in his own government? Mr President, it is an open and shut case. The question is about Mr Fraser and the government ought to tell us why he is wrong—if he is wrong.
—There is no point of order.
—What Mr Costello said this morning in answer to the question, `What does the opposition think should be the cut in the budget deficit?' was, `Well, it's got to be greater than $11.7 billion.'

—I take a point of order. It is quite clear under the standing orders that this is debating the question. There was a clear, straightforward question to Senator Evans: `Was Bernie Fraser right or was Bernie Fraser wrong?' What Senator Evans is saying has nothing to do with that question. In line with the precedents of all other presidents in this chamber, I ask you, Mr President, to direct Senator Evans to answer the question before him.

—On the point of order Senator Kemp has asked you to rule on, Mr President. The question was, `Was Mr Bernie Fraser right or wrong?' That is an argumentative question. Senator Evans is absolutely within his rights to argue about and debate in this chamber questions put in that way.
—On the point of order; is the Leader of the Government allowed in question time to tell a lie? That is what he has done. Mr Costello this morning said nothing of the sort—and those opposite know it.
—I will ignore that last comment which was not a point of order. It is clear that the answer to the question must canvass the options of economic proposals.

—What Bernie Fraser was saying was that any responsible government has to maintain fiscal and monetary discipline in the kind of economic environment we have at the moment—and we absolutely accept that. What he has also said is that any government has to maintain a sense of reality in the tools that it brings to bear on the fiscal side of the equation. I make the point: where is the sense of reality on the other side of this house when those opposite talk in terms simultaneously of tax benefits of $10 billion or $12 billion and, at the same time, outlays cuts of between $11 billion and $12 billion? It is totally irresponsible.(Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade. I understand that the 31st Australian export awards, sponsored jointly by Austrade and the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, were presented last night. What achievements were acknowledged by these awards? What does this tell us about the capability of Australian industry, particularly in the context of competing in global marketplaces?

—This is another piece of good news. In contrast to the last piece of good news, I thought the opposition would welcome this piece of good news. Several of its number were at the awards last night, and I was very pleased to see them there in what was a bipartisan spirit of support for successful Australian exporters. I was very grateful for that support, and the exporters were grateful for it—and I hope we do not undermine it here today.

PARA.TAB: I did have the honour of attending last night's awards and presenting the Australian Exporter of the Year Award. I was pleased that senators from all parties were there supporting this important event. It was appropriate that they should have been there, and it was an appropriate celebration of the achievement of Australians who are engaged in a very important walk of life for Australia—that is, exports.

All of those who attended last night from the Democrats, the National Party and the Liberals, I think acknowledge that we saw a unanimous expression of view from the judges that the standard of entrants in the export category was the highest seen in the 31 years of the award, and that the finalists from all over Australia represented the new cutting edge of successful export across a range of industry sectors.

The winners were from several states. We had PBR Automotive from Victoria; Hawker de Haviland Australian Aviation College from South Australia; and Argyle Diamonds from Western Australia. From Western Australia we also had Aussie Lobsters—from the point of view of a Minister for Trade who is allergic to seafood, this was not one of the great awards of all time; nevertheless, that company was a very worthy winner—and Intellect Australia.

The winner of the Australian Exporter of the Year Award was Intellect Australia from Western Australia, whose hand-held pin pad has already captured about 70 per cent of the Australian market and a $12 million market overseas for electronic banking products. So it was a very good night for Western Australia. But the winners represented a wide cross-section Australia's export performance in commodities and new areas in manufactures and services, and point to a very encouraging future for Australia's export performance.

A really encouraging feature of last night's event was the clear indication of government—that is, Commonwealth and state government—and industry, public and private, working together on the `team Australia approach' to create a favourable trading environment. Several of the exporters appreciated and commented upon the support they had received from the government in being able to achieve their export successes—including, as I recall, the winner. More and more of them are targeting the new markets and opportunities in the Asia-Pacific. But not only there, of course. Some of them are succeeding in Western Europe, North America, Latin America and other important markets.

Last night's event was a very important exercise in encouraging and recognising the achievements of our exporters. How well our exporters do will be a key determinant of how long we can go on generating the tremendous rate of growth that Senator Gareth Evans just reported to the Senate, and whether we can get the current account deficit down in a way that makes that rate of growth sustainable. Exports are very important for that, and that is why the 6.4 per cent growth that we have reported is good news for everybody, except 36 people in here. Every other Australian will welcome it. It is good news for Australia.

What we did last night was congratulate people who are making a significant contribution to sustaining that. I thank Austrade, the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry and all sponsors of the award for what was an important recognition of an important activity for Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I refer to today's report in the Sydney Morning Herald that, on 28 July, Mr Brereton read a briefing note from his department which said that there would be a four-fold increase in take-offs over the suburbs north of Mascot's Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport when the third runway opened. Why did not the minister take any effective action in response to this briefing note or, at least, have the courage to tell the residents of suburbs such as Petersham, Leichhardt and Sydenham that they would be subject to massively increasing noise levels?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This in fact is a complete furphy which the minister has responded to publicly already. The document referred to by Senator Parer relates to the mayor of Marrickville, who claimed that the minister had withheld information—that is, this document—regarding increases in take-offs to the north once the new runway came into service.

ANSWER.PARA: As the minister has indicated publicly already—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, he hasn't.

—The document was in his possession; it was actually in the newspaper, Senator. It has always been publicly acknowledged that the project would lead to a significant increase in take offs to the north. The EIS—and there was nothing in that note that is not in the EIS—predicted that based on long-term wind patterns there would be a fourfold increase in take offs to the north. That is in the EIS.

PARA.TAB: I might add—and Senator Baume actually put this on the record at 3 o'clock this morning—the EIS also indicated that there would be a net reduction in the number of people seriously affected by noise. That has also occurred. There is about an 80,000-person net reduction in people seriously affected. It is a fact—the people to the east and the west of the runway. In fact, strangely enough, a number of letters have actually arrived from people thanking the authorities for the reduction in noise. They are not exactly protesting about it.

So the fact is—and Minister Brereton has made this clear—that the information contained in that note is contained in the EIS. Since operations began on the new runway, the community has raised concerns—and they were canvassed extensively in Senator Parer's absence in the early hours of this morning—that aircraft are not keeping to designated flight paths and that the airport's noise inquiry unit is inadequate.
The minister has taken effective action to ensure that these issues are being addressed. A system of designated flight corridors—

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on!

—If Senator Parer had been around at 3 o'clock this morning, he would have heard it all explained by the CAA officers. A system of designated flight corridors will be introduced. Operators of aircraft that do not stay within these corridors will be liable for substantial penalties. The staffing of the Noise Inquiry Unit has been increased and so on. Flight paths are being monitored—
—It is not the pilot's fault?

—Who said it was? Flight paths are being monitored continuously. As Mr Brooksbank from the CAA explained last night, in the first few days of the transition to the new runway system there were deviations from the noise management plan. That was corrected very quickly and aircraft were directed by controllers to turn at five miles instead of three miles.

PARA.TAB: The CAA also explained last night that a range of new procedures have been brought into place, which will alleviate the noise that was being experienced at Kurnell, in that aircraft are now flying out of the harbour. The CAA provided the committee with the actual flight path maps that are colour-coded so we can tell the difference between arrivals and departures, as distinct from maps that have been published that do not make that distinction. Perhaps Senator Parer should avail himself of them.

A significant number of measures have been put into place to ameliorate the situation. In relation to these claims that what is happening is at wide variance from the EIS, I point out that this was all predicted in terms of the EIS; that is, that there would be a fourfold increase in the number of aircraft flying on the north-south pattern and a significant reduction in the level of noise being experienced to the east and west of the airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer and I would draw to his attention that the reason I was not at estimates was that I was at the meeting held at Petersham last night, where more than 1,500 people were there to protest about the noise north of Sydney airport. The question I ask the minister is: if the minister has been so effective in taking action—

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. It is impossible for Senator Parer to ask his supplementary question.

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Look, I cannot even take a point of order with the noise from this rabble opposite. All we ask is that he be given a fair opportunity to ask his question.
—I agree fully. It is impossible and I would ask those on my right to be quiet, but it is a question of the pot calling the kettle black.

—The question I was asking is: if the minister's actions have been so effective, why did he not have the guts to turn up at the meeting last night and tell that to the people of those areas that are affected?

—I am fascinated to hear that, bearing in mind the lectures I have heard from those opposite about the priority attached to parliamentary responsibilities of senators when some senators are absent. Instead of attending the Senate estimates, where this was being canvassed in detail and where Senator Parer would have had the opportunity to put any number of questions he liked, he was rabblerousing in Sydney. I would be interested to know if Senator Parer explained to the meeting in Sydney the full-blooded support of the coalition, delivered to me on a weekly basis, for the opening of the second parallel runway at Sydney airport. Those opposite are a pack of mealy-mouthed hypocrites.
—Order! You will withdraw that, Senator Collins.
—I withdraw, Mr President.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. We have seen this week the release by the Australian Bureau of Statistics of trade and capital expenditure data and, most recently this morning, the September quarter national accounts. Can the minister inform the Senate of the details of the data released today and what they tell us about how the economy is travelling?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —One has to restrain oneself and resist using the Roy & HG introduction of `Hello, fellow Asians' because the growth rate of 6.4 per cent puts us in the Asian tiger league. I notice that the Treasurer has said that this rate of growth is too high to be sustained over a protracted period. We expect some moderation in demand. But he has also pointed out significantly that the accounts confirm that the strong growth in the Australian economy is accompanied by a very low level of inflation. The Bureau of Industry Economics summarises the national accounts by pointing to the key points. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: .Growth in GDP (Average) during the September 1994 quarter came in at 1.3 per cent to give an annual rate of economic growth of 6.4 per cent. In trend terms, June quarter growth was measured at 1.2 per cent giving an annual growth rate of 5.8 per cent.
.Private consumption expenditure rose by 2.0 per cent while Government consumption expenditure fell by 2.3 per cent.

.Business investment rose by 3.5 per cent in the September quarter. Plant and equipment spending rose by 7.0 per cent while expenditure on non-dwelling construction fell by 5.7 per cent—mainly due to the sale of a building to the State Electricity Commission of Victoria for $250 million. Private dwelling investment rose 3.4 per cent. Public investment rose 15.6 per cent.
.Changes in stock levels added 0.3 percentage points to GDP growth.
.Net exports deducted 1.8 per cent from GDP growth with exports down by 0.4 per cent and imports 8.5 per cent higher.

.On the income side, Wages, salaries and supplements rose by 1.6 per cent in the September quarter 1994 to be 6.8 per cent higher than a year earlier. The gross operating surplus (profits) of private corporate trading enterprises rose by 7.1 per cent in the September quarter to be 11.3 per cent higher than the same quarter last year.
The commentary on these statistics by the bureau is interesting. It states:
The September quarter GDP result was above market expectations of around 1.1 per cent, and leaves Australia with the highest rate—
I emphasise `the highest rate'—

of economic growth in the OECD. The main features of the September result were strong positive contributions from private consumption and public investment, while a significant increase in imports made a large negative contribution to GDP growth. Importantly, business investment grew for the fourth consecutive quarter, to be 22.2 per cent higher than in the September quarter 1993. Purchases of equipment rose by 7.0 per cent during the quarter, to be a very healthy 30 per cent higher than a year ago. This is in line with the rises seen in imports of capital goods over recent times. Company profits rose by a further 7.1 per cent over the quarter to be 11.3 per cent higher than a year earlier—further encouragement for investment prospects over the next year.
Let me cut to the last line of the analysis of these figures. In bold black type it states:
Importantly, it also suggests capacity constraints are not likely to develop in the near term—production is outstripping demand.
I think that is good news for the objective of keeping inflation low. These are good results. I table the paper from which I have been quoting.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Minister representing the Prime Minister. I remind the minister that, within a few weeks, woodchip licences affecting 764 areas of high conservation and wilderness value forests will be considered and that approving those licences would allow the ravaging and chipping of those high conservation areas. Will the Prime Minister respond to the concerns of at least 45 members of his own backbench caucus by guaranteeing that his government will, firstly, implement the moratorium clause of his own national forest policy statement by protecting from logging areas identified by the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories as having high conservation value and, secondly, not issue any additional licences?

—The government intends fully applying the national forest policy statement on all these matters involving the renewal of woodchip licences and making decisions in accordance with that policy. We have said that on many occasions before, and I say it again now. In regard to the so-called moratorium clause, we have made it clear that we consider it applies so as to require that necessary assessments are completed in areas likely to have high conservation values.

PARA.TAB: So far as the woodchip export licence renewals are concerned, a process has been put in place by the government under which the government strives to balance industry and environment concerns. The government has always sought to ensure that environmental factors are taken into account and that suitable conditions are attached to woodchip export licences to ensure that environmental values are protected, and that will continue to be the case.

As Senator Bell well knows—I do not think any of this is news to him—under the Export Control Act 1992 it is the Minister for Resources who has the responsibility for issuing licences for the export of woodchips. In considering those licences, the minister is obliged to take into account, and does so, advice provided by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, the Australian Heritage Commission and the Australian Nature Conservation Agency. That will continue to be the case.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the minister to the fact that a meeting of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development will take place on 6 December 1994 and, amongst other issues, will vote on funding to complete the Mochovce nuclear power plant in Slovakia despite strong economic and safety arguments against the proposal. I ask: given that Australia has a 1.85 per cent voting share in the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development—also representing Korea, New Zealand and Egypt—has a decision been taken as to the way our representative will vote on the issue of funding the completion of this outmoded nuclear reactor? If so, can the minister indicate to the Senate what that vote will be and what rationale is behind that vote?

—The EBRD has developed several nuclear supply scenarios for a number of countries, including Slovakia, in Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union based on forecasts of low, moderate and high proportions of national energy requirements sourced from nuclear power. If Senator Hill thinks I am not a gun on these matters as a matter of routine, he misunderstands the nature of the briefing process. Under the low nuclear supply scenario, reactors at the Mochovce nuclear power plant in Slovakia are the only partially completed ones in the region recommended by the EBRD for completion. Mochovce consists of four partially completed Soviet designed VVER440/213 reactors with enhanced safety design features, although I understand that only two reactors are being considered for completion. In addition, completion of reactors at the Mochovce nuclear power plant will allow the closure of two VVER reactors currently in operation at another power plant in Slovakia—that is, the Bohunice power plant—and which are considered by the EBRD to present a higher safety risk.

PARA.TAB: Australia has not yet finalised its position on the proposal before the EBRD for funding of completion of the nuclear reactors in Slovakia. The issue needs to be considered further amongst departments in Canberra and with Australia's executive director at the EBRD in London. However, given that detailed EBRD studies have recommended the completion of reactors at the Mochovce power plant regardless of the nuclear supply scenario ultimately adopted for countries of Eastern Europe and the former Soviet Union, and given that its completion would allow, as I just said, the closure of another two high risk reactors in Slovakia, it is unlikely that we would oppose a proposal to fund its completion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for that response, but I would be grateful if the minister could advise when that official decision would be likely to be made. Will the government make public that decision and the reasons behind our agreeing to it, if that is the case?
—I do not believe there is any grounds for confidentiality on this one, but I will need to take that on notice, as I will the question of timing.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Of the evidence the minister tabled yesterday on the Port Hinchinbrook project, which specific documents caused him to stall the development? Did the minister take any notice of the advice given by the respected and acknowledged expert body which manages the Great Barrier Reef and the northern tropical waters, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, just one day before he issued his stop work order and which said that `the removal of mangroves presents very little threat to seagrass beds' and, further, `cautions against basing any decisions solely on the opinions' of the minister's chosen consultant, Dr Valentine? Is not GBRMPA's advice reinforced by the report of the workshop of experts released last night which confirmed what the people of Cardwell have been saying about the absence of any long-term effect on the seagrass by the clearing of mangroves? If the minister had gone up there, they could have told him about that. Will he now apologise to the people of Cardwell for the loss of the 40 jobs?

—It is certainly true that there were differing views between the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and my department about the degree of impact of this development on seagrass beds. The authority's assessment was that the proposed mangrove removal and other works associated with this development did not represent unacceptable threats to the seagrass, provided—and I use its words—reasonable management control is maintained. GBRMPA also recommended seeking the advice and the views of other seagrass, mangrove and dugong experts. The authority staff based their advice on information available to them at the time. Following the preparation of that advice, additional information was received by respected scientists about the removal of mangroves. I will go into that in a moment.

PARA.TAB: The important point is that the recommendations of the submission that was put to me by my department on 14 November were supported by the marine park authority. These recommendations were that I should seek a moratorium on the mangrove clearing, to obtain a scientific consensus on the impacts of the clearing and—if that did not prove possible—to authorise the department to instruct the Attorney-General's Department to prepare the necessary proclamation.

My advice in relation to this matter was informed by considerable scientific evidence. It included, on 24 August 1994, departmental advice from the Valentine report, identifying possible impacts of the proposal on World Heritage values; on 27 October 1994, a fax from Dr Tony Preen, a research fellow at James Cook University; on 2 November 1994, a letter from Peter Hale, the Executive Director of the Centre for Conservation Biology at the University of Queensland; on 2 November 1994, a letter from Dr Len Martin, reader in physiology at the University of Queensland; and on 3 November 1994, a letter from Dr Stuart Bunn, the Deputy Director of the Centre for Catchment and In-stream Research at Griffith University.

There was, on 4 November 1994, a letter from Professor Jamie Kirkpatrick, the head of the Department of Geography and Environmental Studies at the University of Tasmania; on 8 November 1994, a letter from Frank Talbot, Director Emeritus of the US Museum of Natural History, the Smithsonian Institute, past director of the Australian Museum and past professor of Environmental Studies at Macquarie University; and on 9 November 1994, a partial copy of a Queensland Department of Primary Industries report of a seagrass baseline study—the full report was provided on 14 November.

On 15 November 1994, there was a submission from Dr Piers Larcombe and Dr Ridd to the Queensland Office of the Coordinator-General, which was made available to the Commonwealth on 15 November. On the same day, there was a letter from Dr Alan Butler from the Department of Zoology at the University of Adelaide. On the same day, there was a fax from Jane Mellors from the Department of Tropical Environment Studies in Geography at James Cook University. On the same day, there was material from Lem Aragones, a PhD student of the Department of Tropical Environmental Studies in Geography at James Cook University. On 15 November 1994, there was a letter from Eric Wolanski, the Senior Principal Research Scientist of the Australian Institute of Marine Science. Finally, on 15 November, before the proclamation, there was a fax from Professor Helene Marsh. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If all those people said that, why did the minister's workshop of experts not confirm it? The minister can quote every PhD student he wants, but he set up the workshop of experts and none of them agree with it. They said that there was only minimal effect and that any effect would renew after 12 months. So all of that evidence is wrong and the minister has misled the Senate. Why does the minister now not do the honourable thing and apologise to the people of Cardwell for the 40 jobs that have been lost, the $1 million additional costs that have been imposed, and the division that he has caused in that once friendly and happy town of Cardwell? Does this not show that Mr Goss was right when he said that this is more about politics than it is about the environment?

—In fact, the report of the scientific workshop makes clear that, if the developer had continued to clear the mangroves in the way he intended, it could have certainly damaged World Heritage values. The report, in fact, recommended that the remaining mangrove roots should be left in place in order to minimise further disturbance to the sediments, and if the proclamations had not been made those root stocks would have been removed. I say again, as I have said in answer to many questions from Senator Ian Macdonald in this chamber, that I have a responsibility as the environment minister to protect the World Heritage values of the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage area and I intend to meet those responsibilities and obligations.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I ask: has the minister seen reports in today's Age by Mary-Louise O'Callaghan reporting that the leaders of the Bougainville Revolutionary Army have declared an end to their two-month-old cease-fire with the PNG Defence Force? Can the minister provide the Senate with a progress report on the peace process in Bougainville?

—I am aware of media reports that quote Martin Miriori, a BRA supporter resident in Honiara, as having declared an end to the cease-fire which has been in effect on Bougainville for the past two months. I have also noted reports that BRA leaders have threatened to kill Bougainvilleans who have entered into peace negotiations with the PNG government. Needless to say, if true, these are extremely disappointing reports. Those sentiments are profoundly regrettable and totally at odds with the wishes of the great majority of Bougainvilleans who so forcefully demonstrated their desire for peace at the peace conference held in October. I guess, though, in some respects comments of this kind would hardly be surprising, following their decision not to attend the Bougainville peace conference.

PARA.TAB: The BRA leadership has been sidelined as Bougainvilleans have got on with the practical business of discussing administrative and political arrangements for Bougainville with the PNG government. The BRA leadership now appears to have adopted a strategy of seeking to hold the peace process to ransom through the issuing of threats. It does not appear interested in talking either to the PNG government or even to its fellow Bougainvilleans.

Far more promising, however, is the progress toward peace that is being made in discussions between the PNG government and prominent Bougainvilleans, including representatives of the interim authorities, which has led to the signing in Port Moresby just a few days ago on 25 November of the charter of Mirigini for a new Bougainville. The charter commits the parties to step up the pace and momentum of bringing normalcy to services and legal authority to Bougainville. It provides for the establishment of a Bougainville transitional government by March 1995 to replace the former North Solomons provincial government.

The transitional government will have the task of reviewing the province's existing constitution in line with positions to be agreed during further negotiation with the PNG government. Sir Julius Chan, the Prime Minister, has already allocated approximately $1.7 million to facilitate this process.

While of course we do not underestimate the difficulty of bringing about a lasting and sustainable peace on Bougainville, we do warmly welcome—and I want to put this very firmly on the parliamentary record—the signing of this Mirigini charter as evidence that the momentum established by the Bougainville peace conference is in fact being maintained. That could not be the case without the very strong personal commitment being shown by Sir Julius Chan to finding a peaceful political resolution. We commend him for that.

I should say that during this week I have also had some quite encouraging discussions with my newly appointed Solomon Islands counterpart, Danny Philip, the foreign minister, who is visiting Australia. Mr Philip and I agreed that, while Bougainville remained very much a matter for the Papua New Guineans themselves to resolve, both Australia and the Solomon Islands, and particularly, of course, the Solomon Islands as next-door neighbours, are certainly in a position to offer constructive support to that particular process.

Bougainville will, of course, be an important issue at the Australia-Papua New Guinea Ministerial Forum, which starts in Melbourne tomorrow extending over a couple of days and at which I will be leading the Australian delegation. I will certainly be taking that opportunity to express Australia's satisfaction at the overall trend of recent developments, notwithstanding today's news about the cease-fire breaches or commitment to breach—in particular, the signing of the charter—and will certainly be taking the opportunity to encourage the PNG government in its efforts to maintain the momentum toward peace through a peaceful dialogue process.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. On 7 November he said in relation to the closure of the North Perth Migrant Resource Centre that the closure has been `welcomed by communities representing the Vietnamese, the Burmese, the Indians, the Sri Lankans and so on.' Those communities had not expressed that view and, in fact, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard letters from the Burmese, Indian and Sri Lankan communities stating quite the reverse to what the minister claimed. Can the minister please inform the Senate as to why he misled the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have a list which was provided to me by the department of organisations and individuals supporting my decision to establish an MRC in the northern corridor in the outer northern suburbs. They are letters that the department has received from the Maylands Action Society; the Australian Asian Association of WA; Jan Widdess, Victoria Park; the Cambodian Welfare and Cultural Centre of WA; and the city of Wanneroo. Robert Wait in the office in Perth received phone calls from Mr Nguyen Van Phat in the Vietnamese community, the Goa Association, Mr Tim Shaow of the Sri Lankan community and Miss Peggy Byrd, who is very prominent in the Burmese community.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Why did the minister mislead the Senate and say that the communities had expressed their opposition to the closure? He has quoted individuals; he has not quoted the communities. The letters that I am seeking to incorporate, which are on their way over to the minister, are from the communities' representatives. Why did the minister mislead the Senate?
—Obviously, in answer to the first question from Senator Knowles, I did not.
—Can the minister table the letters to which he referred in his answer?
—It is up to the minister. Does the minister want to table those?
—I can table the list.
—No, the letters.
—And I will ask for the letters to be provided by the department.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer the minister to reports by ABARE and sections of his department which have stated consistently that coal-fired power stations are more cost effective than alternative energies. Is the minister aware of recent research from the department of environment which shows that ABARE has consistently underestimated the cost of electricity from burning coal? Does the minister agree that when the cost of transmitting power to remote rural communities and the cost of construction and maintenance of substations and high tension lines are factored in, alternative energy sources such as solar, wind and natural gas fuel cell electricity generation are competitive on a cost per kilowatt hour basis and likely to become more so? What measures is the minister taking to correct the information put out by the bureau and his department? What steps is the minister taking to develop an effective policy response to the issue of greenhouse gas emissions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the first part of Senator Woodley's question, I am certainly aware that ABARE has stated consistently that coal-fired power stations are more cost effective than alternative energy sources. There is a good reason for that—they are. In answer to the second part of the question as to whether I am aware that the department of the environment—

—It depends on what part of the grid you are talking about. Yes, I am aware of those reports. I have not actually read the detail of them but I understand that certainly one of the reasons for that is that those reports factor in—and I see Senator Woodley nodding; I think that is my correct recollection of them—factors broader than, if you like, the conventional factors for determining cost. That is how they get to that.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the third part of the question, as to whether it is cheaper to use alternative sources of energy if we then factor in the generation, transmission and distribution costs, the usual practice across Australia—and I am certainly familiar with it—is that although, when we get our electricity bill, those three components are not actually broken up, the bottom line certainly factors those costs in. I think Pacific Power would confirm that that is the case. The bill at the end of the day incorporates the infrastructure, the generation, the transmission and the distribution costs of the power.

There are many remote communities around Australia—and I am familiar with a number of them—where it is possible that alternative sources could be as cost effective as conventional power, if not cheaper, but despite promising research—and, I might add, a significant investment of my portfolio goes into promoting these sources of energy—they are still a long way in terms of broad scale use from being cost effective. At the moment they are still extremely expensive.

It was only a few months ago that I participated in the opening of a major solar array at a small Aboriginal community just south of Mataranka in the Northern Territory. That major solar array—and, I might add, it is a very expensive solar array—is being used in a hybrid system to supplement diesel power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Coconut oil?

—No, it is a little more realistic than coconut oil. But in terms of that particular set-up, it will be several years at least of major data collection before it is indicated whether the capital costs of the solar cells, which are still very expensive, prove to be cost effective. There are a number of communities that are using alterative sources of power such as solar cells for pumping water and so on that have proved effective, but there is still a long way to go.

PARA.TAB: As to the fourth part of the question, about what measures I am taking to correct the information, I have just indicated that I am not going to because I do not believe there is any need to. In terms of what steps we are taking to develop an effective policy response to the issue, in the time that I have left I cannot do that, but I do have information on the government response on greenhouse, which, with the concurrence of the Senate, I am happy to incorporate in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: The government's response to climate change has been effective in reducing emissions of greenhouse gases well below levels that otherwise would have been reached.
Current actions by Australia will achieve a 7 per cent reduction in total emissions against the projected `business as usual' (ie without any measures) level.

This is a good performance and compares favourably with countries such as the USA and the UK. It is harder, however, for Australia to meet the implied target in the climate change convention, because, in percentage terms, our projected `business as usual' emissions are higher than most other OECD countries.

In keeping with the dynamic, phased approach of the 1992 national greenhouse response strategy, the government is developing further greenhouse options, including innovative approaches involving the active participation of industry.
We look forward to the continuing co-operation of the states and territories in the development and implementation of the national greenhouse response strategy.

Current measures adopted by the government to meet Australia's international commitments cover a wide range of areas encompassing energy and agriculture. Moreover, they constitute a responsible and balanced approach that reflects the need to protect our vital economic and trade interests.

Australia's contribution to global efforts on greenhouse are in keeping not only with our commitments, but also with Australia's circumstances in which so much of our economic welfare and trade competitiveness are linked to our efficient production of energy, based largely on fossil fuels.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee has heard much evidence this morning about the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill. In particular, the Acting Solicitor-General conceded that the bill would provide an arguable defence for an incestuous relationship between adults where the woman could not bear children. An eminent QC also conceded that the bill would give an arguable defence for the use of pornography if necessary or desirable for sexual conduct. How will the Prime Minister convince Australia's churches that they will have nothing to worry about with this bill?
—I will refer that question to the Minister representing the Attorney-General, who knows more about what happened this morning than I do.

—To the extent that anyone knows about what happened this morning, it could be fairly said that Senator Cooney chaired a round table discussion amongst a number of leading QCs and representatives of different groups. That process is still part of the process before the Senate and I do not think I should go to the substantive issues of the bill, as they are before the Senate committee.

PARA.TAB: I can say, however, that the advice given to the government, the advice that has been passed on to churches, is that the sorts of concerns that the bishops are concerned about are concerns that are not concerns in law. That is why the Attorney-General has in fact written back to church leaders to explain to them why those concerns that Senator Boswell has are concerns that will not be substantiated if and when legislation like this is tested in the courts.

We believe that we are acting on the best legal advice, and the advice of our eminent counsel is that when the bill, together with the explanatory memorandum and accompanying documentation, is read fully and understood, we have nothing to fear, and nor does Senator Boswell, in terms of the concerns that he has been raising here, at the committee this morning and also in the estimates committee process about a week or so ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister has raised the fact that the explanatory notes have been modified and that that will placate the Australian bishops. In fact, the Australian bishops have not been placated by the offer of the Attorney-General. In the case of the minister and Mr Tang, the minister's second reading speech was ruled not to have any substantial weight in the deciding of the case. Therefore I ask: why would changing the explanatory notes make any difference, and why would he not change the legislation?

—Firstly, this goes to legal advice; secondly, it goes to issues on the Notice Paper; thirdly, it goes to an issue which is before the committee process; and, fourthly, and probably most importantly, it raises an issue which will cause more division among the opposition. I do not know what Senator Boswell's motive is but he is going to make Alexander Downer's life very difficult by going down this particular route. If I were Senator Boswell, I would leave it to the committee process and, in the meantime, give his leader a little bit of breathing time—he needs it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The government has announced new marketing support arrangements for the Australian dairy industry. Will the minister outline how these new arrangements will help the industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Cabinet this week, along with endorsing a new package of support measures for the citrus industry about which I have already advised the Senate, has also endorsed new support arrangements for the Australian dairy industry. The level of support under the new arrangements will be unchanged from the existing dairy plan, which has served the industry well by providing a secure framework for adjustment. The stability of the producing sector, consistent growth in production and investment, rapid expansion in exports, and the rationalisation of the processing sector, are all proof of the benefits flowing from the industry arrangements put in place since 1986. Indeed, it is generally held that the Australian dairy industry is in better shape at the moment than it has ever been.

PARA.TAB: The new arrangements stem from Australia's commitments under the Uruguay Round. The current arrangements are classed as an export subsidy under the round, which has led to the need for a new support mechanism. Australia is committed to reducing its export subsidies in both the volume receiving subsidy and the amount in dollar terms. Unfortunately, the present scheme could not be sustained as it is not geared to handle volume reductions.

Legislation to implement the new arrangements will be introduced as early as possible in the 1995 autumn sittings of this parliament. The new arrangements will continue to provide a sound framework for industry as it adjusts to the phasing out of support by the year 2000. The dairy industry can then expect to be treated within the Australian economy in the same manner as other rural industries.

The new arrangements will be introduced on 1 July 1995, or after the World Trade Organisation agreement comes into force for Australia. They are necessary to demonstrate that Australia can meet its Uruguay Round commitments before joining the World Trade Organisation, which it is scheduled to do on 1 January next year. Having joined, Australia will obtain improved access for its exports and a reduction in export subsidisation over the longer term. ABARE has estimated that Australia can expect to receive a boost of more than $200 million in dairy exports as a result of the GATT round.

In conclusion, I would like to acknowledge that this has been a difficult exercise that has required intense consultation over most of this year with the dairy industry. I would like to pay tribute to the very constructive work of the Australian Dairy Industry Council in assisting the government with its deliberation on these matters. Given the very technical nature of the new arrangements and the time constraints here—I do not want to tie up question time unnecessarily—I seek leave of the Senate to incorporate a written summary of the actual support mechanisms.
Leave granted.
The summary read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: SUMMARY OF DAIRY MARKET SUPPORT ARRANGEMENTS

ANSWER.PARA: The new market support arrangements provided by the Government represent a further progression of the framework for adjustment in the Australian dairy industry following the 1986 and 1992 Dairy Plans.

Under the Uruguay Round, the export support payment under the present market support scheme is classed as an export subsidy. Australia is committed to reducing its export subsidies in both the volume receiving a subsidy and the amount in dollar terms. Unfortunately, the present scheme could not be sustained as it is not geared to handle volume reductions. This makes necessary a replacement support mechanism.

Legislation to terminate the present market support scheme from 1 July 1995 or the next 1 July after the World Trade Organisation Agreement comes into force for Australia is before Parliament. This is necessary to demonstrate that Australia can meet its Uruguay Round commitments before joining the World Trade Organisation, a move scheduled for 1 January 1995. Having joined, Australia will obtain improved access for its exports and a reduction in export subsidisation over the longer term.

The Government gave an assurance to industry on 1 July 1994 that a replacement mechanism would be provided from 1 July 1995 and that it would provide a level of support as near as possible to that agreed under the 1992 Plan.

Given that the scheme had to be changed, the Government has opted for a transparent and clearly identifiable domestic market support scheme, which is consistent with GATT and meets Australia's commitments under the Uruguay Round .

The mechanism selected is an input levy on milk used in the manufacture of dairy products. The levy will be paid by manufacturers into Consolidated Revenue and then appropriated to the Australian Dairy Corporation, which will administer the scheme.

The Corporation will rebate exports to manufacturers on presentation of documentary evidence and pay the balance of the levy, less administrative costs, as support to manufacturing milk producers. Manufacturers will therefore be able to either recoup the levy paid through the export rebate or pass it on to consumers. There should be no increase in the price of dairy products as the consumer transfer will be no greater than that generated under the current scheme.

The levy will be adjusted annually to generate receipts equal to the consumer transfer, which would have been provided under the 1992 Plan, subject to the maximum levels specified in the present legislation, which are reducing annually.

As requested by industry, the all milk levy on market milk will be continued at the current rate, generating a transfer within the industry of about $35 million from market milk to manufacturing milk producers. The total support flowing to the manufacturing milk sector is estimated at about $135 million in 1995-96.
The Government is concerned to ensure that there is a smooth transition to the new scheme, preserving normal cash flows as much as possible.

Due to the practice by manufacturers of pre-paying the expected export support payment and consumer transfer under the current scheme to the producer in the price paid for milk received, stocks on hand at 30 June 1995 will contain a notional levy of about two cents per litre milk equivalent. These stocks will not be eligible for export rebate under the new scheme as they were not subject to statutory levy.

The Government is keen to ensure that manufacturers are not disadvantaged in the changeover, or the new scheme put at risk. Accordingly, the Government has decided to allow the Australian Dairy Corporation to make special arrangements using industry funded borrowings to smooth the transition.

Imports of dairy products will be unaffected but will be closely monitored by industry and Government to ensure that Australian manufacturers and the producers that supply them are not disadvantaged in their own domestic market. An import offset arrangement along the lines of that currently in force will be continued with respect to export rebates.

The new market support arrangements will continue to provide a sound framework for industry as it adjusts to the phasing out of support in 2000. The Government's position is that there will be no legislated support beyond 30 June 2000.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer the minister to Wool International, the marketing arm of the new Australian Wool Corporation, and the proposal for its privatisation in 1997. What income tax implications will there be for wool growers' funds turned into capital in Wool International in 1997 under the present taxation laws?

—It is absolutely impossible to answer that question at this time. I have to say that there is an enormous amount of work to be done yet before that privatisation is announced. All the issues that Senator Panizza has referred to are just part of what will be a very complicated exercise. I must say that, if it is completed with the same success that the government's new measures introduced by Minister Crean have had to this point in improving conditions for the wool industry, it will be successful indeed. There is a lot of discussion to be had on these issues yet, as Senator Panizza would well know, before any definitive position can be taken.

PARA.TAB: One thing I would like to say—and Senator Panizza is well aware of this—is that Wool International, I am pleased to say, has been a very successful policy initiative of this government. It has worked extremely well. The organisations it needs to work with are working cooperatively with it. I indicated to this chamber not so long ago that the government would not be deviating from the scheduled and legislated-for selling of wool—which I think Senator Panizza would have endorsed. That is still the case. That has been supported by what has been a welcome, very significant and continually firming price for Australian wool. All those issues will be debated fully with industry well and truly prior to 1997.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. As the minister said, there is a lot further to go. There is a lot of confusion out there on that angle. Will the minister issue a statement to wool growers in the near future so that they may be in a better informed position and in a better position to pay the tax in 1997 that, I know, will accrue?
—As I have just indicated, the government will continue to consult as closely with industry on all these issues as we have done successfully to this point.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. The minister would be aware of the widespread concern within the Australian athletics community regarding testing for performance enhancing drugs in their sport internationally. Is that concern well founded? Is the minister aware of particular concerns regarding drug use by athletes in the USA?

—In the sport of athletics there were 10,400 tests conducted by IOC accredited laboratories in 1991; 11,300 in 1992; and 14,400 in 1993. The percentage of out-of-competition tests has increased each year. In Australia last year the Australian Sports Drug Agency conducted 369 tests on athletics participants, including 226 out-of-competition tests. The International Amateur Athletics Federation implements drug testing both in and out of competition. In 1993, 476 tests were conducted on athletes from 25 countries. In 1994, 800 tests were conducted. The IAAF announced the day before yesterday that it intends increasing the 1995 out-of-competition testing program to 1,200 tests.

PARA.TAB: Despite this plan, the program is still not fully effective, as it is difficult to test many athletes at short notice. Only 10 out of the 204 member countries have national agencies such as ASDA. The mobility of international athletes also creates a problem with keeping up to date contact information on international athletes. It will only be with the cooperation of the IAAF, its member countries and the national agencies that testing programs will become more effective.

I am aware that our athletes and Athletics Australia are concerned about the lack of effective testing, in particular of athletes from the USA. In an annual survey conducted this year by ASDA, 25 per cent of Australian athletes who responded believed that the USA was a country where drug use in sport was a problem; in comparison, 17 per cent thought China had a drug use problem. The Australian government, as you know, Mr President, is working hard to address those concerns. Steve Haines, the Chief Executive of ASDA, will meet with Dr Arne Ljungqvist, Chairman of the IAAF Medical Commission, next month to discuss the drugs in sport issue.

ASDA has recently signed an agreement with the IAAF to conduct an out of competition testing on its behalf in Australia and the Oceania region. I am looking at ways of working with my colleagues in the multilateral anti-doping agreement from Canada, Norway, the UK, France and New Zealand to pressure the IAAF to further advance its testing programs. The IAAF also announced yesterday that it intends to suspend an athlete after the first sample has tested positive rather than wait until the result of the B sample test. This is to speed up the entire doping control procedure as well as cut down on rumours. The IAAF states that the new rule will have no effect on an athlete's rights. Athletes will still have the right of the B test, the right of appeal and the right of a hearing. I will be considering this decision in light of the ASDA legislative review that is currently under way.

With specific regard to the USA, ASDA is currently working with the Australian Olympic Committee to establish a testing agreement with the United States Olympic Committee. The USOC is responsible for implementing the testing program for Olympic sports in the US. Unfortunately, the USOC does not have responsibility for the US athletics testing program. The US athletics organisation conducts its own testing without the use of an independent body. Because of this closed shop, it has been difficult to get testing statistics from the US.

I am aware that our athletes are concerned about the situation. I can assure the Senate that I will be continuing to work actively in the international forums to ensure that our athletes are playing on a level drug-free playing field.
