TALK.START.PARA: —Under the 30-day rule, contained in procedural order No. 15, I ask the Minister representing the Attorney-General, Senator Bolkus, for an explanation of why I have not received an answer to questions Nos 1739, 1740, 1741, 1742 and 1743, which I put on notice on 5 October 1994, concerning various aspects of the corporations law.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be very easy for me to say that I will take that on notice as well. I will get in touch with the office of the Attorney-General this afternoon, see where the hold up is and come back to Senator Vanstone some time tomorrow with either answers or an explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I can take that to be some sort of an explanation, I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: On 5 October 1994, I placed questions on notice for answer by the Attorney-General. To date, I have not received answers to those questions. The questions related to proposed changes to the corporations law to change the definitions of a `security' and a `futures contract' in order to allow the Australian Stock Exchange to trade a new product it has developed—a share ratio. The Attorney-General's handling of this issue has been unsatisfactory, to say the least; bungling and verging on the incompetent, to be somewhat more realistic. The failure to provide answers to the questions that I placed on notice confirms serious doubts about the ability of the Attorney's department to handle what is a difficult and complex area of regulatory policy.

PARA.TAB: The saga began earlier this year when the government introduced a draft omnibus Corporations Law Amendment Bill. When the final bill was introduced into parliament, slipped in was a provision that effectively allowed the government, by regulation, to completely alter the division between futures and securities regulation under the Corporations Law. The amendments were introduced to enable the Stock Exchange to trade an unnamed product.

The changes were drafted in such a way that they had serious implications for the wholesale regulation of futures, securities and derivative markets. The changes were subject to institutional and opposition pressure, and the provisions were withdrawn by the Attorney-General. Following the withdrawal, the Stock Exchange announced the product that it wished to trade—a share ratio. The Attorney-General's Department put out an exposure package, which provided a draft bill and more details of the underpinning regulatory framework.

All along, the Sydney Futures Exchange has expressed its concern at the changes. It said that a share ratio was essentially a futures contract and should, therefore, be traded on a futures exchange. That concern was obviously directed at protecting its own turf. It has made no secret of that. The Sydney Futures Exchange said that, if a share ratio which exhibited the characteristics of a futures contract was to be traded on a stock exchange, it was necessary to create a level playing field between the two selling bodies. That is not an unreasonable suggestion to make.

It was on that basis that in October I asked the Attorney-General a series of detailed questions relating to licensing, clearing arrangements, investor knowledge and protection. To date, I have not received a response to those questions. In fact, it was clear from a very early stage that the Attorney-General and his department were either unwilling or unable to answer the questions themselves. It may surprise even you, Mr President, to learn how I know this.

The Attorney-General's Department sent my questions off to the Stock Exchange, asking it if it would like to complete the answers. The fact that the answers would be coming from the Stock Exchange has been confirmed to honourable senators on this side of the chamber by at least two senior officers of the Stock Exchange. In other words, some questions in relation to a detailed policy area were put on notice in the Attorney-General's portfolio. His department simply could not hack answering them, so it sent them off to one of the parties which had a vested interest in the change so it they could provide the answers. I find that absolutely unbelievable.

It is the government which has the responsibility to ensure that an appropriate regulatory framework exists for securities and futures markets. Ultimately, it must be the government that makes decisions on its own and brings those decisions to the parliament for approval.

While the Stock Exchange performs a very important independent regulatory function, it is still, in a sense, a commercial enterprise. Questions of broad shifts in existing regulatory frameworks need to be determined by the government and the parliament, not by one of the bodies that has a direct interest in the outcome.

I do not criticise the Stock Exchange for its part. Of course, it is going to present the argument in favour of its cause; it would be negligent if it did not. I am, however, scathingly critical of the government, which does not seem to have the ability to determine its own regulatory agenda: so much so, it goes to one of the parties—in this case, the Stock Exchange—seeking answers to questions that have been put on notice.

We do not, as yet, have the answers to these questions, but we do have another bill which was introduced a couple of weeks ago. No doubt, some senators opposite are aware of the fact that there has been a further blunder. As I understand it—and the government has not denied it yet—the wrong bill was introduced. The Attorney-General walked in and introduced the wrong bill. We will soon see the proof of this, because there will be amendments to that bill. They will come under the generalised heading of `technical amendments' and will be designed to turn the bill the Attorney-General introduced into the one that he should have introduced.

It was intended to introduce a bill that allayed many of the concerns about a level playing field between the Sydney futures exchange and the Stock Exchange. Unbelievably, however, an earlier draft somehow was introduced by mistake. We all make mistakes. I do not know anybody who does not. But with 3,500 staff and with six months to think about it, I would have thought the Attorney-General could get at least that aspect right. This type of bungling hardly instils confidence in the Attorney-General or in his department as a federal watchdog of securities and futures regulations. The regulation of derivatives is a complex and challenging area and appears to be simply too big a task for the Attorney-General and his department.

In conclusion, I ask honourable senators who may at some stage have insomnia and read Hansard or who may be listening now to ask themselves, if they make a mistake in their tax or if a stockbroker or someone selling futures makes a mistake and the wrong bit of paper goes forward and there is a loss incurred and a drama, whether they think they could go before the Taxation Commissioner and try on the line, `It was just a mistake.' See whether they would be believed if they had 3,500 staff and six months to get the paperwork right. See whether they could get away with what the Attorney-General is trying to get away with. The answer is that they could not, because there is one rule for him and another for every other law abiding citizen.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Parer this day, relating to the east-west runway at Mascot airport.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collins's response was another Richo response to Senator Parer's question: it was simply false. He said that the fourfold rise in traffic levels was shown in the environmental impact study and that the public knew all about it. That is false because, while the EIS did say that there would be a fourfold increase, it would not be until the year 2010. That is 15 years away. In fact, the fourfold increase has happened immediately because of this government's incompetence and deliberate policy decision to shut down the east-west runway before the dual runway was in full operation. That was a deliberate government policy.

PARA.TAB: On top of that, there was a difference between the published flight plan that prevented turning after take-off for a distance of five miles, and an internal plan which was totally different, which was not revealed to the public and which showed that turns could be allowed after three miles. This meant sending aircraft over areas not publicly revealed as being subject to noise during the interim period before next March when the dual runway becomes properly operational on completion of the new control tower. The fact is that the government made a deliberate decision to cut off the east-west runway for normal operations even before the new runway was fully available for operational purposes.

The government or the CAA, or both, lied to local residents despite knowing the facts, particularly with knowledge of the concern expressed about this by the Federal Airports Corporation in a letter to the CAA printed in the Telegraph Mirror last week. A section of that letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe the proposed interim operating procedures for the parallel runway have the potential to attract severe, and undeserved, criticism in the early months of operation which may be hard to overcome when the interim arrangements have passed.
The article further states:
The effect of the adoption of the interim arrangements—
that is, arrangements deliberately determined by this government to suit the electorates of Barton and Kingsford-Smith, occupied by the minister, on the one hand, and Mr Punch, on the other—

TALK.START.PARA: —An absolute conflict of interest.
—It is an absolute conflict of interest, as Senator Parer says. To continue:

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of the adoption of the interim arrangements would be that for approximately six months of those runway operations the affected suburbs would be subjected to the full numbers of aircraft operations described in the EIS rather than a gradual increase over the next 15 years.

So the minister—this minister for Richos—has misled us again. It is just incredible that he can come into this place and get away with this kind of nonsense. The minister is certainly aware that the dual north-south runway at Kingsford-Smith Airport will not be fully operational until next March when the new control tower is completed, yet a decision to close the east-west runway for normal traffic immediately the partially usable and much lower capacity dual runway was opened on an interim basis only by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to a great roll of drums on 8 November.

PARA.TAB: Who made this decision to close the east-west runway, in light of the fact that the 1989 governmental promise to do so related to the dual runway becoming fully operational—not partially so on an interim basis? What we want to know is: did the right wing Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton, whose electorate, along with that of his right wing colleague Mr Punch, has benefited from this decision to the severe disadvantage of electorates represented by left wing ministers Mr Baldwin and Mrs McHugh, approve this premature change? Was he made aware of the disastrous consequences of this decision for suburbs north of the airport before it was implemented?

Why did the Acting Chief Executive Officer of the CAA refuse to answer these questions at last night's Senate estimates hearing? What has the government got to hide? Why did Minister Brereton say on Lateline on 23 November that part of the problem of the noise at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport was due to pilots getting used to the new operational requirements, that there is now a far greater compliance and that he intended to restrict the flying operations so that pilots stick to the centreline? Why did he say that the government intends to enforce that by legislation and quite draconian penalties to ensure that pilots do not deviate? The fact is that the CAA could provide no evidence whatsoever of pilots deviating. There has been no pilot deviation. This was a red herring dragged forward by the minister in another attempt to mislead the Senate. I am glad to see the chief misleader has now returned to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the same matter. I think it is worth clarifying a myth that is being spread about by this government, particularly by Senator Collins. Senator Collins knows full well that we have never walked away from the fact that we have always supported the parallel runway. However, what we have never supported is the closure of the east-west runway. What we have seen over the last decade is a whole lot of ineptitude and incompetence by this government, which opposed the parallel runway and said that it would build Badgerys Creek—I think Senator Gareth Evans made the announcement in 1988 that the government would build Badgerys Creek and that it would take 10 to 15 years—notwithstanding the fact that Sydney Airport was in such a state of congestion that it was described by the chairman of the Australian Tourism Industry Association as being like a clapped out cattle yard. It was only when that became obvious to the government—four, five, six or seven years too late—that the decision was made to go ahead and build the second parallel runway. Senator Collins also was critical of me for attending a meeting at Petersham.
—Instead of attending to your parliamentary duties as shadow minister.

—Instead of attending to my parliamentary duties. Have honourable senators ever heard of such hypocrisy in their lives? Here I was, attending a meeting which no federal member of the Labor Party, no-one from the Senate or the House of Representatives, had the courage or the guts to attend.

PARA.TAB: Senator Collins said that the minister had taken effective action. If he had taken effective action to fix up the noise problem, why did he not come and explain to those 1,000 or 1,500 very irate and very emotional people what a good job he had done? About every seven or eight minutes during the meeting speakers could not be heard because of the noise of aircraft—aircraft which did not fly over that location previously.

This government does not understand that we were doing something. It is so arrogant and out of touch that it has no idea what this matter is about. We were listening to the concerns of people who were genuinely worried about what has happened to them. The government has lost sight of that. My parliamentary duties were ably handled by my colleague Senator Michael Baume by prearrangement. Undoubtedly, Senator Collins would know that but it sounds like good copy to get up and say what he did.

The real concern is this: people who deliberately purchase a home under a flight path do so knowingly and they buy those homes at discounted prices. At last night's meeting it was estimated that some 300,000 or 400,000 people purchased homes not expecting, in their wildest dreams, that they would be under the flight path of planes which passed overhead every three or four minutes. They are understandably very angry people.

The purpose of attending that meeting was to listen. If honourable senators have ever wanted to see rats running for cover, they should have heard the Labor mayors and the state Labor members who got up one after another and bucketed the minister, Mr Brereton. It supports the view given by Senator Robert Ray some years ago, which I thought was a ripper description of the Labor Party, that his faith in human nature was restored when self-interest won the day. If ever there was an example of rat runners and self-interest winning the day, it was the Deputy Leader of the Labor Party in New South Wales, Dr Refshauge, getting up and criticising Mr Brereton. He was demanding that the east-west runway be re-opened.

The east-west runway has been shut simply for a political reason, as Senator Collins knows. It is not a safety measure. The CAA, the FAC and all those people know that it is not a safety measure. If it is a safety measure today, why was it not a safety measure six weeks ago when we had the main runway and the cross runway operating at the same time and when the throughput of aeroplanes was substantially higher? This thing has been brought on before the new control tower is in place. It has been brought on for political reasons. Everyone at that meeting knew that there had been a shift of noise from Laurie Brereton's electorate to the electorates north of Kingsford Smith airport.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Michael Baume, in his normal fashion—and, I might add, he has a great reputation for it—has grossly misrepresented the evidence that was given this morning in the Senate estimates committee, as the Hansard record will indicate. I am delighted to hear that Senator Parer is a great supporter of the parallel runway at Sydney airport but not of the closure of the east-west runway. Even a kindergarten student would know that right from day one—and it is contained explicitly in the EIS—it was always the intention to phase out the use of the east-west runway.

PARA.TAB: It is utter rot. Senator Parer might like to have a look at some of the incidents that have occurred over the last three years before he rabbits on about it having nothing to do with safety. One of the great advantages of parallel runways—and this was a central issue in the construction of the parallel runway from day one—is that it avoids the use of simultaneous operations. Simultaneous operations—and this was explained last night—

TALK.START.PARA: —They are run around the world.
—Yes, we can in fact do it.
—There you go.

—Of course we can run sim-ops, but it is safer not to. That is a matter of fact. Let me say something about potential conflicts. I regret to say that they have occurred at Sydney airport, including one major one that was reported on the front pages of the Sydney Morning Herald. A major disaster was averted by 3 1/2 seconds by the action of an Ansett pilot. Two big aircraft almost collided on the intersection and impact with a third aircraft that was on the intersection. It is safer to operate without simultaneous operations, and Senator Parer knows it.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume's assertion that these questions were not answered last night is false; the Hansard record will indicate that. The CAA officer concerned fully answered the question, but not to the satisfaction of Senator Baume because it was not the answer he and Senator Parer were looking for. The fundamental case that they are resting this on is that the decision to take the east-west runway out of service—and, again, Senator Parer has reiterated it—was entirely political—

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course it was.

—`Of course it was', he says—was directed by the minister and had nothing to do with safety. Even a kindergarten student would know perfectly well that the situation with intersecting runways and simultaneous operations where two aircraft are approaching each other is exacerbated when there are two runways that intersect, not one. It is safer—and Senator Parer knows it—to operate the two parallel runways without simultaneous operations. I will tell Senator Parer that, as a frequent user of Sydney Airport, I am very pleased indeed that simultaneous operations are not being run along with the running of two new parallel runways. It is a nonsense.

PARA.TAB: Last night in Senate estimates, Mr Buck Brooksbank, who is in charge of air traffic control in the CAA, and has been for many years, confirmed that it was his advice, as the officer in charge of air traffic control, that determined that the east-west runway would not be used on operational and safety grounds—not Mr Brereton. That was explicitly laid out. In fact, the CAA issued a press statement today confirming the advice that it gave last night. The press statement says this:

SPEECH.PARA: The Civil Aviation Authority today reaffirmed—
it puts the lie to what Senator Baume and Senator Parer have just said; it destroys the political case they are trying to make—

its position that on safety grounds it strongly advises against the use of the east west runway in intersecting operations with the parallel north south runway system. The position is based on the following considerations: it has been accepted internationally that parallel runway operations are an improvement in safety over intersecting operations. More complex three runway configuration operations would increase work load and complexity for both air traffic controllers and pilots with conflicting traffic patterns both on the ground and in the air.
That is a fact. The statement continues:

A large number of aircraft would need to cross the active east west runway to position for take-off on the parallel runways or taxi into the terminals after landing. It is estimated that aircraft would be expected to cross the east west runway every 45 seconds or less. With the use of any intersecting east west runway the required safety corridors to accommodate aircraft carrying out missed approaches could not be readily provided.

That is confirmation, again on the public record, of what was delivered, which gives the absolute lie to the case being made by Senator Parer. The decision not to continue to use the east-west runway, which has been intended from day one, was an operational decision of the air traffic control chief at the CAA, not Mr Brereton.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Alston this day, relating to the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: My question related to remarks made last night by Bernie Fraser, the Governor of the Reserve Bank. This is a matter of great significance because we all know the circumstances in which Mr Fraser was appointed to that job. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) thought he had him in his pocket; in other words, that the Reserve Bank would do the government's bidding, and by and large it has. Indeed, I have no doubt at all that Mr Fraser would not be immune from the same telephonic blowtorch that the Prime Minister brings to bear on anyone who might even think of stepping out of line. That is why it is highly significant that what we got last night was a devastating indictment of government economic policy in recent years.

PARA.TAB: One only just has to look at some of the things that Mr Fraser said to realise the extent to which he has totally lost confidence in this government's ability to govern: Australia's performance relative to APEC nations is poor, both in terms of productivity and in terms of growth; current wage demands are excessive; the current account deficit is excessive; and the ABS figures show that Australia's current account deficit was the largest ever recorded in a September quarter.

Mr Fraser is not a fool; he knows very well what this government is about. It has been given all the right advice. It has been told that it ought to cut government expenditure. Indeed, Mr Fraser prefers to put it in terms of raising taxation revenue. But the end result is the same because he is saying it is simply not sustainable to have the level of current account deficit that we have at the present time.

Mr Fraser pointed out that the Australian economy is currently growing at an annual rate of five to six per cent, which cannot be sustained without generating higher inflation and imports. That is why he said interest rates have already risen by 1.75 percentage points in recent times. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: On-going current account deficits of 5 or 6 per cent of GDP would not be conducive to improving our external debt position. In fact, they would worsen it, increasing our vulnerability to the vagaries of sentiment in international financial markets—something which many people already find unsettling when it starts to go against Australia.

That is the message we were getting from Mr Keating back in 1986 when he said that if we continued to run a current account deficit of $12 billion a year we would turn into a banana republic. That was seven years ago. Now we have a situation that is much worse.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, I think Mr Fraser's remarks demonstrate beyond doubt that the Prime Minister is not only the greatest economic failure that this country has ever had but also the greatest policy fraud. Time and again he is prepared to make grand statements which he has no intention of delivering—for example, the l-a-w tax cuts which are currently postponed will clearly never see the light of day. Indeed, if this government ever got another chance to bring down a budget and it were to act responsibly, we would see taxes going in the opposite direction.

What Mr Fraser was saying in blunt terms was that this country has run out of credits, that what the Prime Minister said seven years ago about Australia becoming a banana republic is even more true today. That is why I want to mention in passing the disgraceful attempt on the part of the government to distract attention from Mr Fraser's blowtorch and somehow suggest that Peter Costello, the shadow Treasurer, had indicated the need to, and, indeed, was pledging that the coalition would, cut government expenditure by $14.5 billion.

What Mr Costello did instead say was that Australia needed to cut back on its levels of expenditure, and he went out of his way to demonstrate that this was an urgent necessity and to make it clear that he was not proposing to cut the budget by 14, 41 or any other figure. Once again that was simply a desperate attempt on the part of the government to distract attention from its own policy bankruptcy.

What I think it all means is this: after seven years and one of the most painful recessions in Australia's history with more than 800,000 people out of work, with youth unemployment still around 27 per cent, the Labor government, under the stewardship of Mr Keating, has fundamentally failed to achieve the necessary restructuring to allow us to grow at a sustainable rate. We are simply back on the treadmill. We are looking at a boom-bust outcome. We have achieved nothing for all that agony and all that suffering that many hundreds of thousands of Australians are going through all because the vanity of the Prime Minister will not allow him to take the necessary tough decisions. This bloke is a wimp. He is not interested in tough decisions. He is interested in posturing to the media, but he is certainly not interested in the national welfare. The sooner the public of Australia wake up to him, the better.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also want to take note of Senator Evans's answer. Australia, under the economic stewardship of the Keating Labor government, is now in an historically dangerous fiscal position. It is dangerous because it affects not only the lives of those who live in Australia now but also, particularly, the future of young Australians who will have to inherit the economic disasters of this Keating government.

PARA.TAB: I have in the past couple of years read the disastrous outcomes of some of the Reaganomics years, particularly as told by David Stockman, the budget office director in the Reagan administration. When I heard what Mr Fraser reported late last night and then heard the government's defence here in the Senate today it reminded me of some of the warnings that David Stockman made to the Republican Party and to the Reagan presidency during those years of that presidency and the lunatic tax cutting without spending cutting that created some of the horrendous deficits that the Reagan era produced.

We see in Australia Bernie Fraser advising Mr Keating, the Prime Minister, advising the Keating Cabinet that what they are doing is going down a lunatic economic path which, in the end, will destroy the lives of hundreds of thousands of Australians. We have already seen in the past two months interest rate increases which are already stopping young Australians getting jobs. Small business is the big job creator in this economy, to take it right back to where it counts.

There are hundreds of thousands of young Australians who have never had a job and many more who have been unemployed for extremely long periods. Many of those do not have roofs over their heads. Many of those live and sleep on the streets. I met some of them in a park in Fremantle on Sunday afternoon—young kids coming up and begging; no jobs, no hope. Many of the friends of those young people are turning to suicide as the solution.

It all comes back to the economic management of Mr Keating, who is ignoring all of the warnings that have gone on in developed economies in the free world for generation after generation. What he and Senator Gareth Evans are pretending is happening is what David Stockman called the magic astrix—the sort of future spending cuts that no-one could ever say where they would be made. Former Senator Peter Walsh has used the term `magic astrix' as well to talk about the deficit reduction plan that this government says it has put in place.

Clearly, what Mr Keating and Senator Evans by agreeing with him are saying is that they believe in magic astrixes. They blame the Greens for believing in magic puddings but these guys, by ignoring Mr Fraser's very sensible warnings about the horrendous shape of the Australian economy and the effects that it will have on future generations, are saying that they believe in the magic astrix. The magic astrix is a lot more dangerous than the magic pudding, because the magic pudding will never be government policy; the magic astrix is.

The other thing that Mr Keating believes in is a lady called Rosie Scenario, who David Stockman described in his book The Triumph of Politics. What Rosie Scenario said, translated into Australian, is that the budget will whirr back into surplus. `Whirr back into surplus,' I think were Mr Keating's words a few years ago. The book stated:

SPEECH.PARA: But Rosie Scenario, the old 1970s tax and spending policy, would have projected out over five years to produce an unprecedented surplus.
It is the same concept.
How could this be?
The answer was this:
Rosie Scenario, why she was an economic heart throb. Touch her hand to the deficit ridden federal budget and the surpluses never stop.

That is what Mr Keating believes the federal budget will do without any action on spending and without any action on tax. That is what he asked the people of Australia to believe. We know that it is unbelievable; Mr Fraser knows that it is unbelievable. But the saddest thing about this is that the people who will be affected by this deception are young people, probably in school at the moment, who will not have jobs when they get out of school. Small businesses will not be able to employ them, nor will big businesses, because this country is moving down what the prime minister himself called `the road to the banana republic,' only a few years ago. He is now trying to turn this nation into a republic but he has also taken us down that road to economic ruin. We are having warnings every day from Mr Fraser and they are being ignored. It is a dangerous state of ignorance.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Environment Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner), to a question without notice asked by Senator Ian Macdonald this day, relating to development at Hinchinbrook Island.

SPEECH.PARA: I have spoken a couple of times already today on the very important matter of the Port Hinchinbrook-Oyster Point development. I did ask Senator Faulkner some very serious questions in question time. Unfortunately, he avoided answering most of them. I would like to give him this opportunity to respond now. Rather than telling the parliament what this is all about, I think he has gone outside to have a discussion with the media—calling a media conference to talk about these things—which is the wont of this government. It prefers to do that instead of making statements explaining to the parliament the ineptitude of its management of the country.

PARA.TAB: I invite Senator Faulkner to answer this question: why will he not apologise to the people of Cardwell for the 40 jobs that he has cost that community, for the $1 million additional cost that the development will now incur, and also for the fact that he has caused division in what was once the very happy, peaceful and pleasant seaside town of Cardwell? I also want to ask Senator Faulkner, who is supposedly the environment minister, what he will do with the huge environmental problem he has created.

If ever there were a cause for the Green movement—the conservation movement, the environment movement—to get up and demonstrate about, it is Senator Faulkner's action in this instance. Senator Faulkner has single-handedly caused the greatest environmental problem that there could be in the Hinchinbrook Channel area. By stopping the development, stopping the developer in midstream, the soil is in a very loose state, the developer is not able to finish the work and when the heavy monsoonal rains come to North Queensland, then as any North Queenslander knows—Senator Faulkner would not, because he has not had the intestinal fortitude to go up and talk to the locals—the rains will wash that loose soil into the channel and cause real environmental damage.

I want to know what Senator Faulkner will do with the problem he has created in the next couple of weeks before the rains come. It is a major problem—a major environmental problem—and he has caused it. The developer and the Queensland government have walked away from it. It is now left in Senator Faulkner's hands and I await his advice to the Senate on what he will do to overcome that huge environmental problem.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The world has changed dramatically since the Australian government published its last defence white paper in 1987. We knew then that we were living in a dynamic era, but the nature and the pace of the changes which have since taken place were quite unforeseeable.

PARA.TAB: Of all the changes, the most significant has been the collapse of the Soviet Union. This was a massively important event, which fundamentally changed the global security environment. Almost overnight, the east-west stand-off, which dominated international strategic affairs for 50 years, was no more. No part of the globe was unaffected by this radical change—certainly not Asia and the Pacific.

This historic geo-strategic change has been accompanied in the Asia-Pacific region by continued and rapid economic growth. Potentially, this too has enormous long-term consequences for strategic relationships and security in the region. The government's 1994 defence white paper—Defending Australia—addresses the long-term consequences of these major changes for our defence policy.

Defending Australia looks ahead 15 years to provide broad guidance for defence policy making and for the force structure and capability decisions we will have to make. It provides the framework for developing our defence policy through the next decade. Defending Australia is a substantial and complex document. Today I will simply highlight some of the underlying thinking and key themes.

Our starting point is the conviction that Australia must maintain the capability to defend itself against armed attack. Despite all the hopes and aspirations we share for reducing the chances of conflict since the end of the Cold War, military force is still an important element in international affairs, and will remain so. That is a fact of life—regrettably—but a fact nevertheless. It is also a fact that, while we will do all we can to avoid the use of force ourselves, ultimately, armed force can only be resisted by armed force.

We must therefore continue to be sure that we can defeat an armed attack on our territory. We have a continent of our own to defend, and a unique set of national interests. We must be self-reliant, with the capabilities to provide for our defence without relying on the combat forces of other countries.

The key judgment in this white paper is that fundamental changes in strategic affairs, both globally and within our region, will make Australia's strategic environment more demanding over the next 15 years. The threat of global war has all but disappeared, but so has the predictable shape which the Cold War imposed on strategic affairs throughout Asia and the Pacific. In its place, a new, more fluid and more complex strategic pattern will emerge.

Security in the region will be shaped by continued high levels of economic growth. The sustained expansion in the economies of most countries is bringing enormous social and economic benefits. It is also increasing the capacity of many countries to modernise and develop their armed forces, and to become more confident and self-reliant in their security.

The military capabilities of our regional neighbours are improving, especially through the introduction of higher technology systems. We will also see a growing capacity to sustain and operate these systems. Australia looks to the future of this region with confidence, and with a strong awareness of the opportunities which Asia offers for our own future. In looking to our long-term security, we will take a positive approach to the region, and to the international defence policies and relationships which support our defence interests. Nevertheless, prudence requires that we maintain the capabilities to ensure our defence self-reliance.

Australia's defence policy, as spelt out in this white paper, recognises our responsibility to help shape our security environment. This requires that we engage closely with our region on strategic issues; that we maintain our alliances with the United States and New Zealand; and that we contribute effectively to multinational security efforts. Just as Australia's prosperity is strengthened by our economic integration with Asia, so our security will be enhanced by closer strategic engagement.

Australia has an active role to play in the evolution of a secure regional environment which reflects our needs and interests, and makes armed attack on this country less likely. The way we seek to influence this environment will need to evolve as strategic circumstances change. The task will become more challenging as our security environment becomes more complex and more demanding.

We will strengthen our bilateral defence relationships, and actively pursue multilateral approaches to security in the region. In particular, we will foster an accurate understanding of Australia's strategic interests and security concerns. In turn, we will ensure that we understand the perceptions, concerns and capabilities of our neighbours. At the same time, our alliance with the United States will continue to be a key element of our defence policy. We will work with the United States to ensure that the alliance continues to meet the needs of both parties—both in a strategic sense, and in the practical benefits it delivers.

We will continue to give strong support to United Nations and other multinational endeavours which promote global security. An effective United Nations can help to make war less likely throughout the world by mobilising international action against aggression. Our support for the United Nations therefore makes a direct contribution to our security. It is also through the United Nations machinery that the government is able to respond effectively to humanitarian crises, such as those in Rwanda and Somalia.

Important as these commitments are, we do not structure the Australian Defence Force for them. The ADF has clearly demonstrated that its force structure and readiness levels are sufficient to undertake United Nations tasks—provided the defence budget is supplemented for major contributions. We will continue to examine each multinational operation on its merits, and evaluate each contribution in terms of our national objectives. Effective arms control measures also contribute directly to Australia's security. Therefore, defence will continue to support the government's policy objectives in relation to global regimes for arms control.

We are also strongly committed to transparency in defence planning in order to build trust and reduce suspicion—especially within our own region. The publication of this white paper is, itself, an important trust-building measure. While the government will continue its active pursuit of Australia's international defence interests in these ways, the key message of Defending Australia is that our highest defence priority will continue to be to build, maintain and support forces which ensure we can defeat any armed attack against Australia.

We do not believe that any country has an intention to use force against Australia. We have no disputes with other countries which might be expected to give rise to the use of force, and there is also no reason to expect one to develop. However, disputes can arise, and intentions can change relatively quickly. Because military capabilities take many years to develop, it follows that we plan on the basis of capabilities, not threats. Let me repeat: we plan on the basis of capabilities, not threats.

No country has the capability to seize and hold major territory on our continent. Significantly, we believe that no country plans to develop such forces. To do so would require a very large effort, and we would expect to have substantial warning of any such development. However, the capabilities available to mount lesser levels of attack on Australia will grow over the next 15 years. Such attacks could be very damaging to Australia, and could arise with relatively little warning.

The key challenge for defence capability planning will be to adapt to the greater demands posed by increasing military capabilities in such short-warning conflict. We will continue to use the most cost-effective means to ensure our security. Our planning will exploit Australia's geographic advantages, technological capabilities, and our wider national resources to ensure we can defend this country. This means giving clear priority to the naval and air capabilities needed to deny our approaches to an adversary.

We must recognise, however, that the development of military technology poses new challenges. Over the longer term we will need to be more selective about those military capabilities in which we must maintain our technological advantage. We will also use our defence capabilities more efficiently. All elements of the Australian Defence Force will work closely together as an integrated force, and make the best possible use of their equipment and facilities.

Our ability to draw on wider national resources will grow in importance. We will seek to integrate a range of civil assets and expertise into our defence effort in order to sustain our capabilities more efficiently. This will provide a wider base for developing and supporting high-technology systems. The effective use of our geographical and technological advantages, backed by the diverse strengths of our national support base, will give Australia a defence posture of greater depth and resilience.

From this key objective flows the main defence priorities set out in Defending Australia. I want to highlight three today. Firstly, high priority will be given to the skilled people we need in the ADF. The Australian Defence Force's tradition of excellence is based on the professionalism of its people. Our deployments to the Gulf War, Namibia, Cambodia, Somalia, Rwanda and elsewhere have demonstrated this beyond question. We should also acknowledge the great body of unsung work which our forces do every day to ensure they retain the necessary levels of proficiency and preparedness.

The ADF will remain fundamentally dependent on the quality of its people. It is easy to overlook some of the special demands military life places on our people and their families. We must therefore ensure that they receive adequate recognition. While personnel numbers will not increase over the next 15 years, the demands placed on our people by new technology will.

Recruiting and retaining high-calibre people in the defence force presents long-term challenges. Over time, we will increase community understanding of defence, and encourage greater recognition of the career opportunities that military service provides. In addition, a wide-ranging defence review of the principles which underpin ADF personnel policies and procedures has begun, and will be completed next year.

Reserves, too, have a long and proud tradition of service in peace and war. The white paper makes clear that reserves now have specific roles in our operational elements. They form a fundamental part of our total force and provide important links between the defence force and the wider community. Changes in reserve training are being implemented, and a detailed structural review of the army reserve will be carried out next year. This will ensure that our reserves are better equipped and that their training standards are more closely aligned to those of regular members.

Secondly, the government will emphasise investment in high-technology capabilities which increase our security. We are moving ahead with plans to procure airborne early warning and control aircraft, and we will replace the Macchi lead-in fighters and our ageing transport aircraft. We will also proceed with new command, control, communications and intelligence networks, new helicopters for our ANZAC frigates, new minehunters, and new vehicles for the land force. Our six new Collins class submarines, due to come on line in the next few years, will be the most capable conventional boats in the world. They are sufficient to meet our forecast needs.

We will, however, review the need for additional submarines in the context of the first five-year defence budget in 1996-97. Our existing Leopard tank fleet will meet our needs until at least 2010. Therefore, we will not take up the recent offer to purchase newer Leopard tanks because this would not be cost effective.

Defence capability development is not just based on acquiring new equipment. In a number of cases, we have the opportunity to enhance our capabilities by upgrading existing equipment and systems. For instance, we will ensure that our FA18 Hornet fighter aircraft remain highly effective well into the next century by upgrading their sensors, electronic countermeasures and weapons. We will also undertake major upgrades of Australia's FFG frigates, M113 tracked armoured vehicles, and P3C maritime patrol aircraft. In our land force, the scope of efficiencies programmed by army will free up the personnel and resources necessary to raise a fifth infantry battalion. This battalion will be formed over the next three to four years.

Thirdly, the government will continue to pursue a more effective partnership between defence and Australian industry. This is essential to strengthen defence self-reliance over the long term. We look to internationally competitive industries in Australia and New Zealand to supply, maintain and adapt our high-technology defence equipment. We also look to industry to design and manufacture equipment suited to our unique needs. To encourage and assist our industries to develop the capabilities defence needs, we have identified a number of changes to the way defence works with industry.

Defence will rely more on the strengths of the commercial sector. We will identify further opportunities for the commercial support program and help industry to acquire more defence-related intellectual property. In addition, we will encourage greater local industrial research and development and, within carefully enforced guidelines, encourage increased international material cooperation and defence exports. Our emphasis on a strong partnership with industry will be complemented by the efficient use of Australian defence science and technology to help develop and support our most important defence capabilities.

More broadly, successful national defence requires the closest possible links between defence and the wider Australian community. This partnership ensures that vital support is available for our defence in peace and in conflict. It also provides major benefits to the Australian community through the ADF's activities in such areas as disaster relief, bushfire fighting, search and rescue, and counter-terrorist support.

Finally, I address the issue of resources. National defence can never be done `on the cheap'. More complex and demanding strategic circumstances will place even greater pressure on our defence budget. We cannot escape that. It is often assumed that, by reducing uniformed personnel numbers, we reduce our defence capabilities. This is not the case. Defence has recently achieved major reforms which have reduced personnel numbers and costs significantly, without reducing capabilities. Personnel costs have dropped from 60 per cent of the defence budget 20 years ago to under 40 per cent today. The government will continue to seek defence reforms and efficiencies.

Nonetheless, we recognise that these savings cannot accommodate all the additional pressures on the defence budget over coming years. Those pressures will arise from the need to meet higher labour costs as ADF skill requirements rise and to sustain the operations needed to keep our capabilities highly effective. At the same time, we must invest in major new equipment and facilities because continual development is essential to maintain our relative level of capability.

The government is determined to sustain defence funding. A long-term commitment is fundamental when capabilities take decades to develop and introduce. We will provide the stability and predictability which is so important to the development and management of long-term projects and activities. For the next few years defence expenditure at current programmed levels will enable the plans and projects outlined in Defending Australia to proceed. Beyond that, modest real increases will be needed to meet the demands of an increasingly complex defence environment. The government has considered these issues carefully and responsibly, and is committed to sustaining defence spending at approximately two per cent of GDP.

The government has also decided that, from 1996-97, it will provide defence with a five-year budget commitment. This is a historic commitment. It is a decision which will provide an assured basis for long-term planning. This will allow more efficient development of defence capabilities, more effective procurement from industry, and better personnel planning and management.

Many areas in Australia contribute to our defence objectives. Defence, in turn, contributes to other national objectives. This includes Australia's international security interests, which require very close integration of government policies and approaches. The relationship between the departments of Defence, Prime Minister and Cabinet and Foreign Affairs in these areas is especially strong, and contrasts markedly with the approach of some 10 years ago. Our commitment to this integrated approach was reflected in the close consultation which occurred during preparation of this white paper.

The decisions we make on crucial resource and other issues over the next few years will shape Australia's defences well into the next century. The government is determined that, in the coming decades, our adaptable, versatile and self-reliant defence effort will effectively safeguard our country. I move:
The the Senate take note of the documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding on behalf of the coalition to the defence white paper of 1994, it is probably fair to say that the paper is intended to give us more of the warm fuzzy glow that we have had served up to us in earlier Labor defence policy statements. But Australians should not be deceived. The government tells us that defence cannot be done on the cheap—and the minister is quite right: it certainly cannot be done on the smell of an oily rag—and the government continues to argue that it is committed to defence self-reliance.

PARA.TAB: I am disappointed that in this document the government fails to credibly address the central issue of how it will fund the defence of Australia. Instead of a real commitment to self-reliance, the white paper is full of promises to examine future ADF capabilities. Perhaps the government is colour-blind—I thought maybe this was a green paper, not a white paper. Australians should understand that many of the announcements are not new; and of the rest, they are merely promises to investigate.

In the short time available to me just before this debate, I made a quick collection of some of the matters which are `under consideration': military satellites, to be examined; unmanned aerial vehicles, to be examined; fixed seabed acoustic arrays, to be examined; AWACS, closer but still to be examined; Land Force, to be examined; the ready reserves, to be examined; the call out protection, to be examined; and the two Collins class submarines, while off the agenda for the moment, are to be re-examined in 1996-97. It is for that reason I say—and I think with some force—that this is a white paper that should have been a green paper. These were matters to be examined; these were matters for consideration. The only clear unequivocal commitments—and we hope that they are unequivocal—are those that have already been announced over the last few years.

My following observations regarding today's white paper are made, sadly, in the light of the government's track record with its last defence white paper in 1987 and the strategic review in 1993. Because we are so used to rhetoric and promises that do not come true, it is inevitable that we are sceptical about anything that is written in this white paper. It is perhaps unkind to the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), but it is a fact of life: we will believe him when we see it.

We have had a mere two hours to assess this paper, and I thank the minister for the courtesy of that much. But it has taken the government seven years to write it, and that is a long time and I would have expected more from it. It is long overdue. I will have more to say about this in the next few days, and my initial responses are inevitably pretty brief. I would like to have been able to go into it in more depth for this debate.

Let me talk, first of all, about defence policy. While the white paper continues to argue for defence self-reliance, trying to engender a sort of visionary sentiment and warm fuzzy glow, we do not know how the government will really fund it because the current trend is towards zero or negative real growth in defence budgets—and I will talk about the budget issues later.

However, does Mr Keating's call for self-reliance, which he made in a recent speech, mean that he does not intend to draw upon US military resources to fill the shortfall in our defence capabilities? Is that alliance really off, in practical terms? In one paragraph in the white paper it is mentioned that we still value it—but that is buried fairly deeply and does not go into any detail or emphasis. So I am just wondering whether Mr Keating is thinking he can go it alone.

Let me remind the government of the comments about bludging which were made back in August by the head of the New Zealand defence force. He was talking there about New Zealand, but the same holds good for Australia in trying to be self-reliant. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . any move to abandon the defence relationship with Australia would have repercussions far beyond defence. The Australians would rightly see us as pushing the cost of our security onto them, to be bludging on their defence taxes. Retaliation in the areas of trade, investment, immigration and travel would almost inevitably follow.

So it is an argument for us to try to achieve self-reliance, but it is not an argument for us to mislead our people and suggest that we truly can be totally self-reliant. There is a tiny little bit in what the minister says about self-reliance in terms of combat forces, but that is a very little bit, as he knows, and it is not true anyway on today's personnel and force structure. We badly need an increase in our combat forces, but I do not see us moving very far in that direction.

PARA.TAB: If people argue for self-reliance, they have to pay for it. It comes at a cost. In previous wars we have relied on our great and powerful friends for our logistic support. We now have to provide that for ourselves if we are really going to talk about being self-reliant, and that means more people, skills and equipment. So the government should at least be honest.

In Defence of Australia 1987, the government argued for defence in depth—the coordinated application of the full range of defence capabilities and that that would be Australia's defence strategy. In Strategic Review 1993 the government went further, and it started to talk about taking control of the air-sea gap.

Control is a very specific military term. Therefore, in quite a few ways, SR 1993 was a change in direction. Control requires a far greater level of military capability than denial. I wonder whether the government has given much thought to what our neighbours think about the strategy of control of the air-sea gap. I would not think they would be too happy. They have exclusive economic zones which come into our air-sea gap, and I would have thought that they would have had an interest in what we were trying to do in that area. No doubt the government's investigation of the possibility of fixed seabed acoustic arrays will also impress our neighbours, just at the time when we are trying to seek greater regional trust.

In DOA 1987, Labor argued for a defence strategy to meet credible levels of threat in Australia's area of direct military interest. Strategic Review 1993 also argued for strategic engagement with the region. That is all very interesting because we are now being told how very quickly threats can build up in our region. The white paper states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . hostile motives and intentions can develop much more quickly than military capabilities can be built up.
It goes on to say, at this stage:
. . . no country is currently acquiring the range and scale of forces necessary for an operation of this magnitude.
The white paper goes on to talk about uncertainties after the end of the Cold War—and it took a long time to notice that it had happened. It states:

. . . we acknowledge the possibility that our security environment could deteriorate, perhaps quite seriously in the future. We recognise that at some time in the future armed force could be used against us and that we need to be prepared to meet it.
It is fantastic to see that at last there is a bit of honesty. That is a major statement which people should at least address their attention to. It goes on to make the necessary conclusion that:

PARA.TAB: If we are to do that, Australia must develop and maintain adequate forces today. A military force that has been neglected in peace cannot be revived quickly when a threat emerges. The military capabilities required to defend Australia must be sustained continuously if they are to be available and effective when they are needed because the necessary technologies and skills

SPEECH.PARA: —and I emphasise `skills' because they are people things—
take a long time to develop.

People may sometimes think that some government documents are written by two different arms of government, because the piece that I just quoted tells us what it really is all about. But when we come to the budgetary considerations, it looks as if that comes from somebody who lives in cloud-cuckoo-land. It is certainly not part of the group that wrote that.

PARA.TAB: As part of the strategic engagement with our region that we are talking about, the government has recommended sharing training with our neighbours. Of course, the coalition supports this. The coalition was there long before the government. I draw the attention of honourable senators to A Strong Australia, which was our very detailed policy document brought out in 1992. We spelt out very clearly our support for cooperative regional defence arrangements, but strategic engagement means an increase in training and training costs.

How is that extra and costly training obligation going to be met under this white paper when even now, under the current situation without the extra engagement with our regional neighbours that the government is talking about, the Royal Australian Navy cannot achieve the planned days at sea, which it has been given as a task to meet? It achieved less than 90 per cent of the planned days at sea in 1993-94. That means that one day in every 10 planned days of training at sea was slashed. So much for being able to expand and be in strategic engagement with our neighbours. Those training exercises will be even more costly.

The other two services have also not met their targeted training levels, according to the 1993-94 defence report. We do not hear any mention of that from the minister. There is no reference to that in the white paper. The CDF, the Chief of the Defence Force, has a readiness directive for each unit in the Australian Defence Force. The readiness of each of our units is secret, but by careful reading of the defence annual report we can see that at the very least training levels have not been met. From that we must deduce that readiness targets were not met as well, and we should all be extremely concerned because we get a piece in the white paper that says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . existing infantry readiness levels are now considered broadly sufficient for the defence of Australia—
mind you they make a proviso—

in our present circumstances. The exception to this could be in the period of any conflict prior to call-out and preparation of the Reserve, when considerable demands would be placed on our four Regular battalions to protect important assets . . . The availability of a fifth infantry battalion would greatly enhance our capacity . . .

So it would, but I will have more to say about that later because that battalion, while it is now something under consideration I am glad to see, is going to be raised over the next three to four years only as the resources become available. It is one more thing on the never-never.

PARA.TAB: I will just briefly mention the peacekeeping role because the minister made a claim in his statement, which I do not think accords terribly well with what we actually have in the white paper. The briefing that we in the opposition have had about peacekeeping is that it is critically important that our force structure should not be distorted by the demands of peacekeeping, that we should so fashion our force that it is for the defence of Australia and Australia's interests, and peacekeeping in a sense is an incidental activity. It comes down the list and it should not distort our force structure. The minister said as much in his statement this afternoon in the Senate, but I see here in black and white in the white paper that we are meant to believe the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: If situations arose where the Force lacked the specific characteristics to provide adequate options, we would consider some marginal variations to force structure.
There is the foot in the door. The white paper says:
The justification for this would be examined on a case-by-case basis.

When the government wants to do this down the track, it will point to this in the white paper and say, `See, we flagged it with you.' Well, let succeeding generations note that the minister said otherwise at the same time he was tabling the statement. I am not too impressed with that double speak.

PARA.TAB: I turn now to the question of the defence budget. The assumption is that growth in the economy will be sufficient to fund a real increase in defence outlays. There we face two problems, because continuous economic growth is unlikely. The normal functioning of the business cycle will ensure a downturn in two to three years at the most, if not before. Certainly, if the government's fiscal policy proves ill-judged, as we believe it will, it may well be sooner and more severe.

The government's fiscal strategies do not mirror the path of economic growth, anyway. In general, to sustain economic growth, government expenditures should be reduced before growth peaks. Where government countercyclical expenditure is required—that is, where increased expenditure is needed to kickstart the economy—its focus is usually on short-term expenditures and not on defence. For those reasons, it is unlikely that national economic growth will provide the level of increase in defence outlay required to permit funding of the equipment bulge that we all know is coming—it is acknowledged—in about 2010. The defence budget will probably be in serious trouble before then.

The financial policy aspects of the 1994 white paper of diverting real growth to equipment at about 20 per cent of expenditure and restraining expenditure on personnel to around 40 per cent of the expenditure, as we heard the minister say earlier, are much the same as those for the 1976 white paper; and that planned 23 per cent expenditure on equipment and 44.5 per cent expenditure on personnel by the year 1980-81. But the 1976 white paper objectives were not reached because of economic problems. The government should at least learn from that experience. The big economic problem that that government faced was wage inflation. We all know only too well the threats that are on our economic horizon right now with the increased wage demands.

The 1976 white paper failed because of economic problems, particularly wage inflation. Let this government be warned: it cannot predicate extra expenditure for defence at all based on economic growth. Any wage inflation pressures which are under way at the moment, generated by the government's current wages policy, could have a significant bearing on the success of this 1994 white paper. It is also wise, therefore, for the white paper to assume that most efficiency savings, if any, will be absorbed in increased remuneration for Defence Force personnel and civilians.

I would like to briefly mention defence industry. I wonder whether the government believes that Australia can, through substantial defence exports, be a defence industry support base for the South-East Asian region, as it claimed in the strategic review 1993. The interesting thing, which the government does not seem to want to talk about, is that defence exports are only about $16 million per annum. I draw the Senate's attention to how that figure is calculated. Australia's total annual exports of controlled defence products is some $90 million. Of that, less than 10 per cent goes to South-East Asia. Of what we are actually selling, about one-third of our defence exports are comprised of sporting firearms and ammunition, having little to do with defence industry, another $28 million resulted from offsets activities, and $15 million from the defence cooperation program. That left something like $17 million of real exports. That information came from the chairman's address to the defence export outlook conference in 1993. Yet, once again, we hear the rhetoric about defence exports.

The problem was that in 1986 Mr Cooksey estimated that Australia could have defence exports of $500 million by the early 1990s. The defence export policy has to be described as yet another government failure, but the Labor Party persists with the hope of making Australia a defence industry support base, despite the current climate in our region and elsewhere of an arms bazaar and the difficulties that Australia has with its costs of getting a toehold.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are accusing us of not having enough, and I presume Senator Margetts will accuse us of having too much. We can't win.

—You will have to choose which is the best advice. I am sure Senator Schacht will be interested in the fact that the Australian National Audit Office is planning to do an audit into defence exports, and I cannot imagine that his government will be too happy about that. I believe it will blow the lid on the ineffectiveness of Labor's defence exports program, and that is strongly interrelated with a home-grown defence industry. I acknowledge the value of developing skills and technology and retaining intellectual property in Australia, but it is achieved at a price—and that price should be very visible so that this country can make a knowledgeable decision on when it is prepared to pay the price and when it is not.
—Hear, hear!
—I must have said something wrong for Senator Margetts to agree with me!
—No, I agree that their defence export policy has been a failure.

—That makes two of us. That price also makes it very difficult for us to compete effectively with other defence exporters. Yet the government would have us believe that Australian defence industry is now so much more competitive than it was a few years ago. We have not seen the proof of that. I remind the Senate of the lack of industrial relations reform coming from this government and the lack of reform to infrastructure, both of which go to the basic costs of Australian industry—whether general industry or defence industry.

PARA.TAB: I now turn to defence personnel. I cannot help wondering where the government now stands on the force structure review. We have had 3 1/2 years of reduced manning levels throughout the services. I cannot believe that it can continue with the levels that are causing real worries over training and safety in the Australian Defence Force. For example, army troops have not been receiving adequate training in the use of the Steyr rifles. The report in the army's own newspaper in July last year said:

"Everyone was happy with the training. However, the instructors trained by the SARP team were often not given sufficient time in their units to conduct a complete conversion course," Captain Grant said.
"The unit training, in a lot of cases, was deficient. The instructors had one day, two days or a couple of half days over a month period and no time for continuation training."

SPEECH.PARA: That goes also to the problem that some units have had with shortage of ammunition. Last week's decision to dramatically increase the recruiting numbers in the Defence Force was an admission that the personnel ceiling management had failed. The government should have foreseen that a combination of the force structure review policies and the economic upturn would strip the ADF personnel numbers to minimum levels. Perhaps the government thought that the `recession we had to have' would never end. Many of us think it has not.

PARA.TAB: The force structure review has caused serious problems for the defence forces. The personnel numbers in the combat units are inadequate. The logistics numbers also need maintaining if we are aiming for self-reliance. As I said earlier, our great and powerful friends supplied our logistics in the main to us in the past. It takes people to maintain troops in the field.

We also have the CSP program. That is still being supported in its current form, despite the fact that large numbers of service people are getting out because their career advancements are being reduced. We have these hearts and strings paragraphs in the white paper about how important defence families are and how personnel are the lifeblood of the defence of Australia. That is true. The Chief of the Defence Force, Admiral Beaumont, is reported as having talked about morale being:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . `patchy', although generally good at operational bases, while the attitude in support bases (those people being subjected to the greatest change under programs such as commercial support—CSP) was `less good' . . . many people were put out of their "comfort" zones . . . many were feeling `less secure'.

We should all be concerned about that. If the Senate does not believe the CDF about the lack of morale, I suggest it cops this. I refer to an item from the North-West News, a newspaper circulated in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Brisbane.
—Brisbane, is it? It is interesting that the community billboard in that paper has an article entitled `Army thrift shop'. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: DONATIONS of clothing and kitchenware are needed for the Army Thrift Shop at Enoggera.

PARA.TAB: Donations may be left in the shed at 14 Taurama St, Enoggera, or by phoning 359 7409 or 354 2037 for pick-up.

SPEECH.PARA: And here is the clincher:

PARA.TAB: All money raised will help under-privileged army families.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a disgrace. Our fighting men and women now have to rely on charity. Many of their families are eligible for welfare, to their great and understandable disgust. The government's policies have also cut seriously into the preparedness and expertise base of the ADF. Is the government planning to continue its decade-plus tradition of high equipment funding at the expense of personnel numbers and their training? It seems so from this white paper.

PARA.TAB: Given the current size of the defence budget pie and the need to improve service conditions to attract new personnel, an inevitable blow-out in training costs to deal with the influx of recruits is coming. How will the government meet its personnel obligations? Will we have more of those 1930s style battalions that went into history as Dad's Army? Do honourable senators think we will have enough money left to afford the broomsticks so they can train?

We are setting up a fifth battalion, which is badly needed. I understand that will be achieved by splitting two battalions which are already grossly undermanned. I have here figures showing that the battalion in Townsville, which is meant to have 703 people, has 675 people. The 2nd/4th Battalion, which is the one believed to be splitting, is nominally 689 people. It is now down to 526. The 3rd Battalion at Holsworthy is meant to be 623. It is down to 557. The 5th/7th Battalion is nominally operational at 740 and is nominally 639, yet it has 480. That is the reality of Australia's defence and how self-reliant we can be, yet we are splitting a battalion that is already grossly undermanned to make two new ones, which will be even more grossly undermanned. So what will we end up with? Four grossly undermanned battalions in lieu of the three grossly undermanned ones we have now. Even then, it is not planned that that will start for several years.

The minister says the first defence priority highlighted is the increased need for skilled people. But the white paper comes at a time when, with a recession coming to an end, there are worrying signs of a wastage crisis like the one we had in the 1980s as separation rates, especially amongst skilled personnel, begin to creep up. How does the minister plan to, first of all, retain existing skilled personnel against outside competition, because that will be costly, and, secondly, recruit new skilled personnel without significant financial inducements, as page 12 of the minister's statement says that for the next few years defence expenditure will continue at the current programmed levels?

I do not have much time today to go into the other issues that I would like to except to mention that the ready reserve continues to have real problems. What is the government going to do about that? It is going to have a review. It is having a review, just like it is having a review of everything else in this paper. It was the government's idea. It proved, as we told the government at the time, to be a lot more costly than it said, and it is still not going to improve our readiness levels and our capability. Problems still surround the government's commitment to people in the ready reserve, just as they still surround its commitment to the reserves. I notice that, once again, the general reserves are to be reviewed. I say to the general reserves: `Look out. Here comes the government with another knife.'

It is inevitable that, with 20 per cent wastage in the general reserves, the reasons for people—reserves or regulars—leaving the defence forces will have to be looked at. But that review, I believe, will be looking at more than just reasons for wastage. I think it is positive that the government has recognised the need for better conditions of service for the general reserve. But, in conclusion, I have to say that I am disappointed with this white paper. The government promised to protect Australians from the threat or use of armed force, but despite its rhetoric about commitment, in practice it has shown no sign of being prepared to pay the cost of such protection.

TALK.START.PARA: —The white paper Defending Australia is a great disappointment, if not a huge disappointment. Hardly anything in it is new and nothing in it has not been foretold to anyone who has been following the defence debate in Australia. It is disappointing because, in essence, it prescribes a further run-down in Australia's meagre defence capabilities. Admittedly, the paper is attractively presented. It has a good layout and good chapter headings and is full of motherhood statements and purple prose. But it is utterly without any substance with respect to the defence of this country.

PARA.TAB: It maintains the general approach of this government because it reaches back philosophically to the Dibb 1986 paper. It re-runs all the old discredited dogma of the sea-air gap and low-level contingencies and relates it to the eternal geographic fact that Australia is an island and therefore that is the basic determinant of Australia's defence. We are back to the old business of no threat for 15 years, which first surfaced during the Whitlam years, the old dogma of the adequate warning time—the time we have to prepare if we have an emergency—and all those other things.

The whole basis of this government's approach is to write strategic reviews which show there is no threat and the strategic reviews and the white paper then justify inadequate expenditure on defence. Yet this government admits that things have changed dramatically since the last white paper in 1987. That is certainly true—there has been the ending of the Cold War and the great changes in the Asian economies which have produced very significant changes in our environment which have a great relevance to Australia's defence. But nothing flows from that in this paper, even in the name of the paper. Defence of Australia was the previous white paper in 1987. This one is known as Defending Australia. There is such a lack of positiveness in that.
