The change between the titles of Defence of Australia to Defending Australia reflects the lack of commitment of this government to what we have before us today.

The previous paper in 1987, Defence of Australia, gave us an unbalanced defence force. It gave us a totally inadequate land force with four understrength infantry battalions structured for the mythical low-level contingencies. It gave us a huge investment in naval hardware, and it neglected the army and the air force. So, in effect, it gave us this unbalanced force structure. What Australia needs is a balanced, flexible, modern force. But, to the government, flexibility means that we can take an army unit and send it on peacekeeping ventures. That is not the purpose of flexibility at all.

The report has a few proposals of merit in it. The most important of those is the provision of an AWACS capability. I will believe that when we see it, because parliaments in this country have been talking about acquiring an AWACS capability ever since I came into parliament 16 years ago. Nothing can overemphasise the importance of an AWACS capability, given our present inadequacies. It is important to all three services, particularly the navy. But all we have had from this government is endless evasion. It has never signed up and got its feet on the ladder to provide anything. We have always been told that new developments are around the corner and that, if we wait a little while, something better will come along. That is certainly true of all technical advances, but the fact of the matter is that AWACS has been around since 1943, which is over 50 years ago, and we still do not have one.

The proposal that we look at satellite communications for military purposes is very important. The proposal that we resurrect another infantry battalion is important, but it will go less than halfway towards solving the problems of the army. There are a number of misleading statements in the document. The implication on page 46 that Rapier will become obsolescent by the year 2000 implies that the Rapier defence system is adequate at the present time. Nothing could be further from the truth. It is woefully out of date. It is the mark I version that has never been modified.

The reference to the F111 and F18 strike capability in all weather is not true; it is only true if they are operating against undefended targets. The intention to retain adequate self-protection capabilities is mentioned in paragraph 5.66 of the report. The fact of the matter is that the RAAF does not have an adequate capability in electronic warfare. It cannot operate into modern, defended environments. It lacks the ability to suppress electronically enemy air defences and it lacks the ability to look after itself.

One of the most misleading elements is in relation to preparedness. Preparedness in a defence force relates to both the readiness of the personnel involved to go about their tasks and the ability to sustain them. It is no secret that the sustainability of the Australian Defence Force today does not exist. We have no stock holdings of missiles and ammunition to enable us to use the defence forces in a wartime setting. The readiness of some units is adequate but, without the ability to fight, it is all in vain. There is nothing in this report which gives any concrete proposals as to how the sustainability question is going to be addressed by increased stock holdings, because increased stock holdings require money.

In relation to the army, there is quite a bit in the white paper about the reserves. What we have in the land force at the present time is totally inadequate. We have four under-strength infantry battalions. In three to five years time this will be raised to five under-strength infantry battalions. Because the army is a manpower-intensive organisation, the heart of the army is in the reserve infantry battalions, of which there are 14. They are all inadequately manned, inadequately trained and inadequately equipped. All that we get from the government is a vague proposal to look at their needs. There is no commitment to spend the hundreds of millions of dollars that are needed in equipment and training to bring them up to speed.

There are also potential difficulties for the reserve in the reference to centralised training. I would argue that the quality of training for reservists is just as important as it is for regulars, and the quality of training that the regular force can provide is at a higher level. But the point is that a large part of the general reserve is involved in the training groups in the various states which have a pure training function. That absorbs a lot of officers and senior NCOs. If we eliminate those by transferring that function to the regulars, we do a great disservice to the reservists because we cut out the employment of officers and senior NCOs who are important for an expansion function.

I want to move to the most important failing of this report, and that relates to the funding. It is highly significant that the minister never once referred in this statement to the fact that he was gutting the Australian defence budget. The last Defence of Australia document, in 1987, called for between 2.6 per cent and 2.8 per cent of gross domestic product to be spent on defence and it set forth a series of objectives. The Australian Defence Force failed to reach all those objectives because it did not have enough money.

The government introduced the Sanderson report, the Force Structure Review, which was a very flawed document intellectually. It cut 16 per cent out of the manpower in the uniform section of the Australian Defence Force. But even then it fell far short of what it set out to achieve in DOA 1987. This time it is promising even more in Defending Australia 1994 than what it did in DOA 1987, yet it is proposing that there be less money for it. It is suggesting that approximately two per cent of the Australian GDP will be spent on defence for the next five or 10 years. Knowing this government, if it used the word `approximately' advisedly we are probably looking at 1.7 per cent to 1.8 per cent of the GDP going to defence, which is totally inadequate.

There is no such thing as defence on the cheap. This country is worth defending and it is worth having a defence force to protect it. The defence force spends money in this country and it spends it productively. It creates national pride and awareness. Above all, it gives us a sense of security and the freedom to pursue our own destiny.

Even this paper states, `A military force that has been neglected in peace cannot be revived quickly when a threat emerges.' That is very true; yet there is no observation and application of that statement in the crucial area of funding, which the paper is all about. We live in a time when warning times are very short. We are saying that the Australian Defence Force has to be self-reliant, and that means a very high degree of readiness.

We are aiming for a deterrent function in the defence force. We do not ever want the Australian Defence Force to fight; we want it to deter people who may feel that they have an interest in taking Australia on in a military sense. But if we are going to operate effectively in a deterrent role, then the reality of it has to be there, not the potential.

We cannot fund a defence force in the good years and not fund it in the bad, because we must maintain professional experience and professional expertise. The complexity of weapon systems we have today take 10 or more years to develop. Look at something like the F111 fleet that we have. We are still developing the capabilities of that, although it has been in service for nearly 20 years. At the end of the day, we never know when we are going to need a defence force. All the experts have always been proved wrong historically when they have tried to predict threats and the timing of them.

This government has not taken the honourable path of providing for the national security. It has chosen to pay for the security of Australia with the lives of young Australians, because we are going to be caught unprepared when the unforeseen happens. That is the great tragedy of this paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is very much a steady as she goes defence white paper. It has many similarities with the one published by Minister Beazley in 1987, at the height of the Cold War. When we contrast it with the huge changes in global affairs, it seems that the more things change, the more they stay the same. There are no major force structure changes planned and funding is expected to remain roughly constant. Operational priorities will not change substantially, although there will be an increased emphasis on regional cooperation, which is already under way.

PARA.TAB: The primary mission of the ADF will continue to be continental defence using a mixture of mostly defence strategies and a dash of offensive tactics. The stated focus continues to be low-level assault rather than concerted military attack. Defeating aggression in the air-sea gap is still the preferred approach. New acquisitions will include early warning aircraft, helicopters for the Anzac frigates and minehunters. The need for more Collins class submarines will be reviewed in two years time and a number of equipment upgrades are planned. Significantly, defence funding is to be planned over five-year time frames, starting in 1996, to provide greater certainty than the present annual allocations provide.

This is the first defence white paper to be issued since the Cold War ended and the first since multilateral regional security consultations began. No previous white paper has been released in the context of a regional free trade agreement with major implications for our relations with our neighbours. These changes are all acknowledged in the document, but their importance is downplayed on the basis of a key argument that also underpinned the 1987 white paper. As the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) was at pains to emphasise, our force structure is planned on the basis of capabilities, not threats. Relations between countries can turn sour very quickly—so the argument goes—and it is too late to then build up our armed forces to counter the threat which has suddenly materialised.

This paper goes on to state that the post-Cold War regional environment is more fluid and unpredictable than before, which means, in essence, that we have to be prepared for things to go wrong. Indeed, the bold statement is made on page 11 that `our strategic environment will become more demanding over the period covered by this white paper'.

It is the time-honoured role of military planners to be pessimists who plan for the worst case scenario. But that statement, in the view of the Democrats, is taking pessimism too far because it ignores the fact that the culture of international relations is changing. It seems unarguable that the barriers to regional interdependence are lower now than they have ever been, and are set to drop much further. This means that the threshold of possible military action between Asia-Pacific states has been raised significantly in recent years, and is virtually certain to rise much further.

This is not to deny that, as the minister says, military force is still an important element in international affairs. But the constraints on the hostile use of military force are greater now than ever before. Sure, there are parts of the world which are embroiled in intense and horrific armed conflict. But the trend is unmistakable.

The Democrats believe that our strategic environment is likely to become more manageable, not more demanding, in the period covered by this white paper. In saying that, I do not want to create the impression that we have a utopian view of the regional security environment. Military capabilities, particularly naval capabilities, are expected to grow as the decade wears on. The potential of a growing Chinese economy to support naval expansion is worrying. There are unresolved disputes which could spill over into intense but localised military conflict—for example, competing claims over the Spratly Islands.

But, for all that, we are witnessing the growth of an international interdependence through trade, tourism, communications, and cooperation in many fields which is making the use of military force in international affairs increasingly impermissible and ineffective. The Democrats would not argue, however, that likely improvements in the regional security environment mean we should immediately make huge defence spending cuts and cancel major equipment programs.

The fact is that the improvement in our military security stands in direct contrast to the trend in our environmental security outlook. We have less cause to worry about military attack than we did 10 years ago, but much more reason to be concerned about the greenhouse effect, land degradation, and population growth. The social foundations of national security, such as low unemployment and an equitable distribution of wealth, are also under much greater challenge now than in previous decades. Global health care is faced with new challenges caused by the growth of international travel. In the Democrats' view, some inescapable conclusions arise from these realities.

The most obvious is that we need to re-examine our security priorities. Security is becoming more multi-dimensional, and it is bad policy to continue to look at defence in isolation. It is time for a thorough review of the challenges we face and the best way to balance and integrate our responses. That is the basis of the bill I recently introduced to establish a parliamentary commission of inquiry into Australia's security priorities.

This white paper represents the exact opposite of the scheme outlined in my bill. Instead of looking at security in the broad, it looks at military defence in narrow isolation. And instead of engaging with the community by providing for public input, it has been developed in almost total secrecy. This white paper speaks of the importance of engaging the community but it has failed to involve the Australian public in the most fundamental way—by encouraging public debate about our security priorities and how they might be met.

I believe that it would be foolish for the defence establishment to assume that the community will always be content to leave security and defence to the experts. There are plenty of signs of a difference in view. A recent EPAC paper found that the average Australian believes that defence spending should be 20 per cent less than it is so that more can be spent on, for example, environmental protection. To engage the community requires more than token forms of interaction. It requires real dialogue.

In our opinion, a rational assessment of our security priorities would lead to a number of conclusions which are at odds with the conclusions of the white paper. Firstly, more effort should be put into developing a proper coastal protection system which could play a support role to our front-line forces in the event of attack. For all the rhetoric about the need to meet low-level incursions, it is still possible for a boat-load of Vietnamese refugees to sail undetected into Darwin harbour.

Secondly, there should be more emphasis on getting value from the ADF in peace-time, by purchasing appropriate dual-use equipment. As an example, the Democrats have long argued that Canadair amphibious aircraft have great potential for water bombing in the bushfire season as well as for coastal surveillance and interception. Thirdly, we should begin a regional arms control debate through the ASEAN regional forum. Instead of spending taxpayers' funds on two more submarines, as this white paper suggests we might, why not abandon that plan now and propose instead to add naval arms control to the regional security agenda?

Fourthly, we would limit regional military cooperation to areas which have clear security benefits and do not implicate Australia in human rights abuses. In our view and, I might add, in the view of many people in every party in this parliament, the training of Indonesian special forces does not fall into that category and should be discontinued. Training for peacekeeping, and joint maritime zone patrols, are a different matter. The Democrats strongly believe that regional engagement should not be allowed to override our fundamental values.

Fifthly, we would put more emphasis on peacekeeping than the case by case approach outlined in the white paper. As flawed as the United Nations is, it must be reformed and built up so that it can play a pivotal role on the world security stage. Our security future lies more with the United Nations and emerging regional institutions than with the United States, and our defence policy should better reflect that reality. For example, the US-Australian bases at Pine Gap and Nurrungar should increasingly be tasked to serve the legitimate security functions of the United Nations if they are to have any future role here.

Sixthly, we should make the size of the defence budget, and the way in which it is spent, much more accountable. There should be more debate over our security priorities, as I have already mentioned, and there should be greater security to ensure that taxpayers' funds are being spent effectively and efficiently.

There is nothing either new or too alarming in this document. But it has failed to accommodate changes in our regional environment and in community opinion. It is a source of frustration to the Democrats that we have not been presented with a bolder, more forward-looking blueprint. The longer we wait to grasp the nettle, the more opportunities and resources will be wasted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all I have to say that as a policy review this statement is pathetic. During the estimates process it was mentioned that the policy review program in the Department of Defence costs the taxpayers $14 million. During that process I asked the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) several questions in relation to how policy is reviewed, how it is costed and how various options are worked out as to whether or not they are economically efficient or actually meet the needs of security, and the minister refused to answer these questions. He did say, however, that there would be a policy review in this white paper. I looked and looked and none of those questions were addressed, strangely enough.

PARA.TAB: I have picked out some of my favourite pieces in the minister's speech. One of them is on page 6 and reads:

SPEECH.PARA: We will continue to use the most cost-effective means to ensure our security.

Considering, as the minister mentioned in the estimates process, the department does not do any cost analysis of different policies—or, if it did, he did not mention them—I am wondering how it works out what the most cost effective means is.

PARA.TAB: The disappointment is that, because the opposition has a policy on increasing defence spending, whenever the spending is in defence areas it is also loath to look those costings in the mouth, even if there is great waste. Unfortunately, it is left to the Greens (WA) and the Australian Democrats to question that cost effectiveness, and sometimes there is huge waste within the defence budget. Because of this philosophical idea that defence spending must be quarantined and increased, this accountability stops short.

As has been mentioned, this defence white paper is simply more of the same. It contains some new politically correct definitions that we are now planning for the `capability' of our neighbours' weaponry, troops, training and equipment instead of their imminent threat and it hangs on tightly to the rhetoric of self-reliance. Drawing from this fundamental premise, the paper advocates a number of continuing large capital acquisitions, such as more Collins class submarines, the possibility of spy satellites, helicopters for the Anzac frigates, new patrol boats, an upgrade of the P3C Orion aircraft and two new heavy landing ships to replace training ship HMAS Jervis Bay and heavy landing ship HMAS Tobruk.

These acquisitions continue the line of forward defence or offensive defence that the government upholds. No major changes are foreshadowed with our aircraft force of long range F111s and FA18s. The government may have learnt the lessons of a dependence on American defence goods in the past. This lesson came after we acquired additional F111 aircraft and, shortly afterwards, the United States threatened to scrap its whole fleet, which would have left Australia high and dry and without United States expertise and spares to continue operating our force.

Our Collins class submarines are ridiculously expensive, so much so that we could not sell them for the amount they cost us to build. It is even more ludicrous that we want more Collins class submarines as it is impossible to pay a reasonable price for them. The six we are locked in to building now have cost us $820 million each at current prices, up from initial figures of $400 million. Likewise, the six Anzac frigates have not been without their problems and have cost us $540 million each, although the original figure was half that at $240 million each. These projects have doubled in cost at a time when we are pushing arms exports and handing over intellectual property to try to make our defence self-reliance activities back home profitable.

I would like to mention how pitiful it is that DSTO receives half of CSIRO's budget, yet the DSTO is solely for defence related activities and defence research benefits from CSIRO's contribution to Department of Defence research. That defence research is taking such a precedence when CSIRO is suffering cuts which benefit all Australians is extraordinary and harmful to the direction we are taking.

In the white paper defence activities will continue to be commercialised, with the rule of thumb being that industries limit their defence activities to 25 per cent in order for them to stay in business. It is a statement in itself about the hopelessness of self-reliance. Industries are continuing to be highly subsidised in long range high technology projects that we do not necessarily need or want, but they are perpetuated by the notion of self-reliance and that we need to learn how to make these items ourselves. This is an extremely problematic concept because, due to this new high technology direction, we are more heavily reliant on technology transfer from the United States. So how can this be deemed as promoting self-reliance?

Again and again in the white paper the government articulates that its rationale for being self-reliant in the first place is that we cannot expect the United States to help us in our region. The Department of Defence has found itself in a state of non-preparedness in the past, but there is no indication in this paper that these problems will be addressed. I refer to the results of the Department of Defence inquiry into Australia's military preparedness, which found that we have depleted war stocks and stockholdings of munitions and other equipment which would need to be supplied by the United States in order for us to defend ourselves. This is not self-reliance; it is critical dependence on foreign sources and is a reality for Australia.

Despite all this heavy spending, high technology solutions and large capital acquisitions, we have overlooked our basic reliance on troops and munitions in favour of the unreliable high technology approach. I notice this is a point which Senator Newman made as well. We are shooting ourselves in the foot with arms exports. The paper states that we have a modest defence export record in 1993-94 through exporting only $70 million worth of arms control defence related equipment. It is true that it is even more modest than that because the majority of that figure would be made up of sporting firearms, ammunition, offset activities and the defence cooperation program. Although I must add that `sporting firearms' means guns and we are exporting guns to Singapore where individuals cannot own a gun licence. So we are talking about a lethal weapon which is hardly sporting.

I agree also with Senator Newman, and I mentioned this at the time, that the defence export policy is a failure. As a policy for making arms cheaper, it is a failure. As a policy for increasing income for Australia, it is a failure. We have spent hundreds of millions of dollars in subsidies and the official export figure is $17 million. So the reality is that if we are talking about employment it is a very expensive way to get it. It is certainly not helping us in any other way that I can see. It has certainly downgraded any particular emphasis on human rights and the impact of real regional security.

However, when we have small figures like this it does not mean that we should not bear the true responsibility of the impact of those defence arms exports we have made—the impact on regional security and on the local populations of our neighbours, who we can develop close relations with. In fact, the tighter the buyers' market the more likely we are to make stupid decisions which will embarrass Australia on the world stage and have an impact on human rights in the area. For instance, when we export to Cambodia, Thailand, Vietnam, Korea, Indonesia and Papua New Guinea we are aiding the repression of the local people. They could be persecuted for a number of reasons—political and civil expression, ethnic fighting, separatism or for standing up for environmental degradation or social and economic exploitation.
On page 8 of the white paper the government admits that these tensions are a source of regional instability and a low level threat for Australia. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Ethnic and national tensions, economic rivalry, disappointed aspirations for prosperity, religious or racial conflict, or other problems could produce an unstable and potentially dangerous strategic situation in Asia and the Pacific over the next 15 years.

However, we are happy to be gung-ho and keep supplying these nations with defence exports to help them control their internal problems or their local people and, by doing that, we actually inflame them. We are fuelling more problems by not dealing with the roots of conflict. This creates further instability and we become more on our guard to maintain our high technology solutions or, in Defence's terminology, to meet our neighbours' capabilities. Defence is foolish if it does not realise that capabilities are easily transferable into threats.

PARA.TAB: I also want to mention the continued lack of accountability in defence activities. I have mentioned it briefly before. I note that the future of the Australian bases may be in doubt after the year 2000, which I welcome. However, I am extremely concerned about the lack of information and public accountability and the secrecy that surrounds defence procedures. In this chamber people have heard in very recent times my degree of annoyance that Australian Defence Industries, a wholly government owned enterprise, and other related corporations did not have their documents ready in time for the first estimates committee hearings this year.

The lack of policy accountability process would not pass a public company accountability test. The reality is that we do expect more, and the fact is that the more money we spend on defence the more accountable it should be, not less. While nominal defence spending has declined, actual expenditures are increasingly hidden. The corporatisation of Defence reduces accountability and makes it appear that there is less money in Defence than is the case. An example is the Australian Submarine Corporation, which is 49 per cent federal government owned, but through the Australian Industries Development Corporation not through Defence.

Defence Industries were previously directed under the control of the Department of Defence and funded from its budget. Bit by bit we have noticed that other peacekeeping related activities will now be farmed off to the particular departments involved, so that other departments' budgets will be involved in Defence activities, which in reality means increased Defence expenditure.

A major problem in relation to both peacetime domestic security and peacetime operations is also the problem of skilled and less skilled personnel. In peacetime operations personnel with specific training are often required. The majority of Australia's capacity in a few skill areas may be involved in peacekeeping operations, even if the total troop commitment is small.

In Cambodia most of the communications personnel from all units were involved. In Africa it was the engineers. This leaves the ADF domestically without key components, personnel who are not easily replaced. This comes down to what we put our emphasis on, whether we provide decent conditions for our personnel or whether we siphon that money into war toys.

The Greens oppose an open cheque for peacekeeping. This should be identifiable. If we are planning to go into more peacekeeping in the future—and that is a debatable point—if we are planning to be more involved in a regional army kind of set up, a standard force of some sort which the Minister for Foreign Affairs has mooted, then the public needs to know what is involved. They need to have this debate, because we need to set out what this is likely to cost. If it does, it may well be held in a separate account, perhaps under Prime Minister and Cabinet. However, it should not come from somewhere else, general revenue or other programs. Therefore, if we are going to do this we need to know what it costs, what we are planning for and we need to make sure we are not pulling out from other social budgets in order to fund a virtual open cheque for peacekeeping in the future.

One solution that has been mentioned is to provide extensive specialist training within the peacetime military to look at some of those peacekeeping requirements. This allows us to meet specialist needs in peacekeeping without compromising security. This would also be consistent with the core force concept of a disproportionate number of specialists and members capable of leadership, allowing a rapid up-take of basic soldiers in the event of actual threat to Australia.

Ready reserves have not proved effective. Intake is low and troops are far more expensive than initially estimated, costing some 80 per cent of regular troops. I would like to also refer to some of my other favourite purple patches from the minister's speech, which state:

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, the government will continue to pursue a more effective partnership between Defence and Australian industry.

Defence has a very strong policy of supporting industry development. It gives millions to industry. It has a subprogram, industry involvement and contracting, that is funded at about $90 million a year by the Department of Defence essentially as an industry lobby group to Defence and government. Virtually all its acquisition and policy programs include specific support for industry, often well funded. It spends billions building equipment from scratch that could be bought or built in existing facilities.My other purple patch relating to this is:
The government will emphasise investment in high-technology capabilities which increase our security.

I would like to know how. It promotes private defence industry, builds and sells production works such as the Australian Submarine Corporation with Swedish company Kockums or the Anzac frigate venture with Transfield. It sees a role in establishing these even though it proves expensive with about $200 million added to the cost of each Collins class sub or Anzac frigate because of its policies. In the newest project, the mine hunters, the hull is a basic design that could have been built in a number of existing shipyards, shipyards craving business. Government is again funding a whole new shipyard to build six ships. The electronics, the most expensive part of the ships, are imported in either case.

PARA.TAB: In order to try to keep these industries afloat—excuse the pun—and reduce its cost, government supports exports. This export promotion, and the need for exports costs taxpayers money and results in conflicts of interest in an arms exports regulatory regime already dominated by Defence. We could refer back to my speech on that with the defence exports inquiry for the problems involved with that conflict of interest. The consequence is stupidities like selling small arms to Indonesia or Thailand and a government-backed push for export of major weapons platforms to our neighbours and technology transfers which means that by that stage we have no control over what happens to that technology.

As it states in 11.4, our defence exports are modest. This is because they are expensive. There is an abundance of surplus equipment available to buyers. The small amount of exports only makes Australian defence industries more economically untenable and increases pressure to export at any cost.

I refer also to Senator Ray's comments that we respond to capabilities not threats. If we think about it, this is a vicious cycle. If we are supplying or helping to supply the high technology war toys to other countries in our region, then of course we are going to respond to that. If we are supplying high technology equipment, others will get it from us and other places if we are seen to be leading the way. Then what we are doing is leading the establishment in our other regional arms race, and it has been well acknowledged that one of the few regions which is still spending on defence is our own region.

It has been mentioned by Senator Woodley that an EPAC study in the Australian indicated that the Australian public actually believe that they would prefer a 20 per cent cut in Australia's defence spending. This is what the public is saying about where they want public money to go to. The very least that is necessary is for the government to increase its accountability of what it is spending at the moment. There are plenty of ideas about how we over time could concentrate more on security and less on offensive defence.

Increases are seen as important in surveillance and in troop presence in the north. Yet these are exactly the areas where we are most fervidly trying to sell arms. Finally, with all the expectations a 15-year plan for our nation's defence brings, there is nothing new or inspiring in this document. As usual, there is little information on procurement, costings, training or strategic planning which is usual for defence. What we see, however, is a possible ratcheting of defence spending in 1996-97. So we are seeing plans put into concrete, a five-year budget commitment and long-term—not just short term—unaccountability. On page 5 of the minister's statement he said:

SPEECH.PARA: We are also strongly committed to transparency in defence planning in order to build trust and reduce suspicion.

It is, but industry gets a great many more documents which are more easily obtained than we in the parliament get—a lot of assistance and a lot of information. It does not come to us and it is not debated at any length in this particular parliament. So the government is not accountable to the parliament and the transparency is not here.

PARA.TAB: On page 12 there is an indication in relation to these longer-term targets which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Beyond that modest real increases will be needed to meet the demands of an increasingly complex defence environment.

I also want to articulate my deep concern that when Senator Ray called for submissions this year for the white paper he said that the public would not be invited to make submissions because they were not capable of commenting on the highly complex issues relating to defence. Instead, he chose to focus on the opinions of the Defence industry, the Australian Defence Force and defence academics.

PARA.TAB: Most of these people would have a fairly narrow definition of `defence' and many would indeed have a vested interest in an ever-decreasing defence budget and larger outlays on big capital projects. I also refer to the PR statement on bush fires in this report. It seems that the people in New South Wales might disagree that this has been a good PR exercise for the military considering they went in there without any proper equipment or training. It seems that as a PR exercise, as an excuse for what is currently being done in this Defence white paper, it might not carry much water with the people of New South Wales.

It is the Australian public that wants a different notion of security and different priorities for defence spending. Many community groups and individuals are calling for a less high tech and expensive approach to defence, making it more people-based. They want to be consulted and they want more confidence-building measures to enhance regional security and our relationships with neighbours. They want to re-direct spending on arms exports to helping the people in the nations to which we are exporting these weapons that kill and maim. They also want to see inefficient defence industries converted to civilian operations, as is happening in Western Europe.

The cost to date of the blown-out Collins class submarine project and the Anzac frigates projects is close to $10 billion. Yet, at the end of the day, our large coastline is not any closer to being defended, we have large hospital queues, our farming sector and rural communities are in disarray, and our schools and universities are suffering cutbacks. Taxpayers' money could be far better spent on directly helping the people of Australia through social justice initiatives, repairing the environment and improving health, housing, education and community services. I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the notice of intention I gave earlier today, I now withdraw business of the Senate notice of motion No. 2 standing in my name for today, for disallowance of the telecommunications code dated 30 June 1994. I seek leave to make some brief remarks on the matter.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter has a fairly long history but, in essence, it arises out of the concerns expressed on all sides of the chamber in relation to the proliferation of mobile telephone towers, particularly digital towers, to the proximity of those towers to schools and homes, and to what quite often seems to be the cavalier approach taken by the carriers to the process of negotiation and consultation with local residents. Indeed, I have received a number of complaints that when the going got rough the result was that, overnight, a tower appeared and the carriers effectively dared the local community to do something about it. I do not think that was ever a viable option for the carriers or for anybody else. Over time, sanity has prevailed and we have achieved a modus vivendi.

PARA.TAB: I think it is very important to recognise that the provisions of the final code, as it is called, still did not require a sufficient degree of advice to residents of the local communities. Indeed, it left the matter in the hands of local councils. Going on past history, one could not always assume that they would adequately bring the matter to the attention of the ratepayers. It certainly seemed to us that one way of achieving that was effectively to require those councils to advertise and give residents the opportunity to express their views on a proposal—not open-endedly, because I do not think anyone wants to see inordinate or indefinite delays in the rollout of the digital network, but we certainly wanted to see a process that would give people sufficient opportunity to complain and to work through some of the concerns.

As a result of those representations, on 13 October I gave notice of intention to disallow the code. Since that time, I think it is fair to say, Senator Bourne and I, in our different ways, have been negotiating with the carriers to achieve a satisfactory outcome. I think we have reached that stage today—coincidentally, the last day before the code would be automatically disallowed if there had not been a debate on the motion. Therefore, I think we can regard the matter as having reached a successful outcome, with the result that it is not necessary to proceed with the motion to disallow.

Rather, I seek leave to table correspondence, consisting of replies from the CEOs of each of the three mobile carriers and a letter from the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) to Senator Bourne. I believe that she will seek leave at the end of her contribution to table the letter that she wrote to the minister in the first instance, leading to his reply.

I also seek leave to table a draft guideline and a list of the type of facilities involved. The draft guideline relates to a set of guidelines currently being developed between the carriers and the Municipal Association of Victoria, which I assume will form the basis for a national set of guidelines. The end result of that should be that all ratepayers and citizens will have the opportunity to comment on proposals to erect towers so that no arbitrary decisions will be made, irrespective of the interests of the local communities. That is, they will not have the ability simply to say, `No, not in my backyard', but they will have the ability to point out preferable options and explore the various proposals on which they might obtain advice.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been a very satisfactory outcome, from our point of view. We welcome the pressure that the Democrats have brought to bear on the government. Whilst the minister, to some degree at least, has been dragged screaming to the table, the end result is one that will be in the interests of all residents as well as users of mobile phones. I thank the Senate for the opportunity to speak.

—by leave—I think we all agree that the draft telecommunications national code, which was replaced by the full code on 30 June, was inadequate. We have all heard horror stories of mobile phone towers being put up with no community notification or consultation. The present code is an improvement in that disputes over proposed towers can be quickly referred to the Commonwealth Environment Protection Agency. However, as Senator Alston said, it is still up to local government authorities and to the carriers as to whether they tell local residents that a tower might be built near their backyards and to give them a chance to respond.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats take the view that mandatory notification and consultation with communities should be provided for in the case of environmentally significant activities, such as the installation of mobile phone towers. As a minimum, this should involve prompt notification of local residents through letterbox drops and ads in the local press, as well as an avenue for providing written and verbal comments. In the event that there is significant community concern, public hearings should also be held.

We are aware that, under the auspices of the Australian Local Government Association, the Municipal Association of Victoria is negotiating with the carriers on guidelines for community notification and consultation in the case of high impact activities, such as tower construction. The Democrats welcome this development but we are not satisfied that it is enough. There is a real possibility that the negotiations could be unnecessarily protracted. Also, there is an overarching requirement for community notification and consultation which should be given the force of law by being included in this code.

However, we came to the view that disallowance was a last resort because it would create a legal vacuum. That is why we approached the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) and have obtained three undertakings from him and the carriers. The first is that the carriers will abide by the spirit of the draft guidelines from tomorrow. The second is that the MAV guidelines will be extended nationally by the end of February, resources permitting. The third is that the code will be subjected to a full review by AUSTEL from 1 July 1995. The basis of that review will be a new draft code which, we have been assured by the minister's office, will contain new requirements for community notification and consultation.

I thank the minister for agreeing to this approach, and I thank Senator Alston for agreeing to withdraw his disallowance motion in the spirit of obtaining a workable outcome. This is an example of a cooperative approach achieving significant improvements.

I also have pieces of correspondence which I seek leave to table. The first is the letter from the minister to the three carriers, to which they responded with the letters that Senator Alston has just tabled. I think it is important that the minister's letter be put on the table as well because it sets out the matters to which he asks the carriers to respond. It is very interesting to look at the responses in the same context. The second item that I seek leave to table is my letter to the minister, requesting him to do certain things. It will make clear his response to me, which has also already been tabled by Senator Alston.
Leave granted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The telecommunications national code determined by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) on 30 June 1994 is a document that aims to carefully balance the network roll out of the licensed telecommunications carriers with the need to respect our environment and cultural heritage. It is clear that the Australian public will benefit from the provision of efficient, modern and cost-effective telecommunications services. The public are also clear winners from the new competitive environment that this government has created.

PARA.TAB: I would like to mention some figures relating to the impact of competition in Australia on the growth of the mobile communications market. In June 1993 there were approximately 650,000 mobile phone customers. This had risen to one million customers by March of this yer. By September 1994, the latest month for which there are figures, there were 1,400,000 customers. In other words, customer numbers have grown by more that 100 per cent over the last 15 months or so. I am informed that numbers are currently growing at about 1,500 new customers each day.

I think the Senate will agree that these figures clearly indicate that mobile communications are demanded by the Australian public. In fact, the government regularly receives approaches from Australians in those areas not currently able to receive mobile services, seeking support for the services to be expeditiously extended to their localities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good idea!

—These requests have come from most states on the mainland, from Tasmania , and in particularly from Australians in rural towns and localities. I add that for Senator Panizza. It is against this background of public demand for mobile services that carriers are aiming to expand and deepen their network coverage in order that the public demand can be met.

PARA.TAB: In these circumstances, it is also incumbent on the government to ensure that uniform national procedures are in place to facilitate network development. But environmental considerations are not overlooked. In the past, Telecom enjoyed very broad powers and immunities. With the advent of competition, these powers and immunities were wound back via the combination of regulations passed by this parliament under the Telecommunications Act 1991 and the draft telecommunications national code formulated in December 1991.

Further obligations have now been imposed on carriers in the code determined by the minister on 30 June. Circumstances are clearly spelled out where carriers will automatically be required to notify the secretary to the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories of their planned activities and the carriers are not able to go ahead with those activities until the secretary advises them that they can proceed. I think those provisions effectively provide the secretary with the veto power.

The new code also specifically provides a role for local councils to receive full details of the carriers' proposed activities to enable affected communities to be consulted. In addition, where there is still disagreement between a carrier and a local government authority about the environmental significance of a proposed mobile facility site, that proposal must be referred to the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories if the council so requests. Again, the carrier cannot proceed until any objections by the department are resolved. Carriers are also now required to collocate cellular mobile towers wherever it is technically feasible and compatible with network configuration. This will minimise any adverse effects on the environment.

The code also provides a measure of flexibility about the notification process. I am informed that the carriers have taken the responsible step and, with the Municipal Association of Victoria, are discussing an arrangement that will take advantage of the code's flexibility. The discussions are leading to a guideline that will relate to the level of notification and consultation required of the carriers on the impact of their activities.

Senator Alston's approach of disallowing the code would have meant a much less stringent regulatory environment governing the carriers' activities. Neither the minister nor the Australian Democrats wanted this. I do not believe the community did either. I am pleased that Senator Alston has decided to take the more sensible approach and withdraw his notice of motion.

I would like to point out to the Senate that, following discussions with Democrat Senator Vicky Bourne, the Minister for Communications and the Arts proposes to hold a formal review of the operation of the code, beginning on 1 July 1995. The review will be conducted by Austel. By that time, there will be 12 months experience by which to judge the new code and the review will enable the community to comment on its operations. It is in the carriers' interests to ensure that their track record by that time is positive.

I would also like to inform the Senate that the Minister for Communications and the Arts has received written assurances from all three carriers that they will work to bring the current negotiations on the guideline to an early successful conclusion. While the negotiations are proceeding, it is the government's expectation that the carriers will abide by the spirit of the guideline, particularly with respect to those activities that will have a high impact on local communities, and will endeavour to apply the guidelines nationwide. The carriers have assured the minister that they will do so. For the information of senators I seek leave to table the responses from the carriers. I suspect that that will be duplicating what Senator Alston has already tabled; but I cannot be sure that the letters I seek to table are the same.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should add that the government is encouraged by what we know of the operation of the new rules. The evidence available indicates that the new arrangements are working as intended. In particular, the process of negotiation and compromise between carriers and councils appears to be working well. We are confident that further experience will only reinforce these initial positive impressions.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 10 of 1994-95—Efficiency Audit—Cash Management in Commonwealth Government Departments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation to Federal Parliament for 1991-94 entitled Walking Together: the First Steps.
—I present the 18th report 1994 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I also lay on the table the Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 18 1994, dated 30 November 1994.

The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —When we adjourned this debate at lunchtime, I was in the process of putting what I hoped was nearly my final question to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook). I do not think he tackled it so I want to come back to it briefly. Are the guarantee provisions contained in the bill intended to apply only to the MUA league consortium to buy ANL or would the guarantee provisions be offered to any and all potential bidders for ANL?

PARA.TAB: In the minister's reply, as I recall it—and I jotted down a couple of his responses—he said that it could apply beyond the MUA lead consortium, but that it depended on whether it was appropriate in the circumstances, or words to that effect. I did not really understand what that meant, and I wonder whether the minister could clarify that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Short. I think he has correctly described the situation we were in just before lunch. He has, as I understand it, re-asked the same question and given me a chance to be clear about the answer to it.

PARA.TAB: This bill is not about any party who might be interested in purchasing ANL at some time; this bill is about guaranteeing ANL's debt and the arrangements that are needed to take care of ANL financially through the period which the newly ensconced board has in order to prepare options for the government to consider in February.

The question, as I interpret it, relates to who might be part of a consortium bidding at some future time, if ANL were on the market, to purchase ANL and whether this relates to them. It does not relate to any of that side of the arrangements at all. It strictly focuses on the need to provide a guarantee for the debts of the organisation and the other arrangements necessary to carry it through. I hope that the situation is clearer than it was before lunch.

I would quote from a news release, put out by the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton), of 22 August 1994, referring to the arrangements he had made to institute the new board for the purposes of defining options for the ANL. In the concluding paragraph of that press release, he says:

SPEECH.PARA: To ensure that ANL is able to continue to trade in an orderly fashion the Government intends to guarantee all existing debts of the company and any further draw-downs required on its promissory note facility.
That, I think, is the neatest answer to the question that is being put. This is about that sort of thing, not about possible purchasing or what the unions might or might not do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for that answer. If I have it right, the minister is saying that, regardless of who buys ANL or, indeed, almost regardless of whether anyone buys ANL, this bill will apply only to the existing debts and also to the further draw-downs, if any, on the $100 million promissory note. Is that the understanding?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is my understanding, but I think Senator Short asked me what is the case with this guarantee if, coming up to the point, there is an option for sale and that option is embraced by the government and it is in a negotiating position over a sale. In an earlier answer to a slightly different question before lunch I gave a highly qualified answer, balancing the risks that might be involved in a new entity having the guarantee extended for it. Bearing in mind that answer, the answer to Senator Short's present question is yes, he has adequately defined the situation.

—I thank the minister. If, by any chance, ANL was not sold and instead of being sold was liquidated, where would this bill and the guarantee provisions resulting from it leave the Commonwealth in the line of ANL credi tors?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short has put a scenario forward which is not the scenario intended by the government. It is not the intention of the government to liquidate ANL.
—I know.

—The intention of the government is to restructure it, to find a basis for its continued operation. However, in that hypothetical case—and, again, I now venture into the realms of speculation, which it is not a wise thing to do at any time on such a matter as this, but I do so in order to answer Senator Short's question as fully as I can—I am not quite sure where the government would stand in relation to its rights in the creditors' list, and neither am I sure I can be advised on that.

PARA.TAB: Bearing in mind that the idea of liquidation is not an option that the government is considering and it is not an intention of the government, the advice I have is that, in a liquidation situation, with the qualifications that I have just given, the debt would be paid out in a liquidation scenario. But that is not, as I have said, the government's stated position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that mean that, if this bill were not enacted and if ANL were regrettably liquidated, the amount of taxpayers' money would be less at risk than it would be if this bill were to go through because there would be a greater liability provision in the case of the bill going through? Am I correct on that?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are in the realms of being hypothetical here, and this is a very hypothetical question. Any answer that is given has to be seen in that very hypothetical context.

PARA.TAB: The government wants the legislation to go through for the reason I stated earlier: we need this legislation to meet the requirements of the Audit Act and to engender in the marketplace a greater degree of confidence than might otherwise be the case. If the bill were not to go through, that scrambles all of those settings and we would just have to have a look at the situation in those circumstances, but it would be a tragedy for market confidence in ANL and in our ability to properly discharge our obligations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I just get a yes or no answer to this fairly simple question: will the government have more taxpayers' money potentially at risk in the event of the liquidation of ANL if the bill is enacted than it would if the bill were not enacted?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to that question is that the amount of exposure is limited to what the level of risk was at 22 August when this was undertaken, plus the draw-down since then and through to the time at which we make a decision. As I said, we are getting into a very hypothetical field.

—With respect, it is hypothetical only in the sense that we are hypothesising that ANL might be liquidated. We all hope that it will not be, but we know market realities and so on, and it must always, therefore, remain a possibility. When any responsible government is looking at legislation such as this, presumably, that must be in its mind.

PARA.TAB: I think a simple yes or no answer is required. Will the government have more taxpayers' money potentially at risk in the event of a liquidation if this guarantee arrangement is in place, or will it not? Yes or no? I think it is a question that can have only a yes or no answer.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take some advice, but I have answered that question. I will see if there is any additional information that I might be able to provide. The purpose of this bill is to enable the ANL to restructure and find a basis for continuing on, lessening its exposure to debt. On that basis, the answer to Senator Short's question is that we would be more at risk if the bill does not go through than if it does go through.

—We would be more at risk if it does not go through. Why is that, given that this bill puts in place a guarantee that the Commonwealth would have to meet? How could that possibly be the answer? It would seem to me that it would have to, at best, be the other way around.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I return to what I said. The purpose here is to provide a basis for restructuring the ANL, not for liquidating it. The intention is to restructure it and enable it to find a basis for continuing to trade.
—We all know that; that is not in dispute.
—Right. If Senator Short accepts that—
—Just give me an answer to the question that I asked.
—I did, but Senator Short does not seem to want to accept that answer.
—It has nothing to do with what you are rabbiting on about now.

—Thanks for the insulting behaviour but, with the greatest respect, I am not rabbiting on. I am giving Senator Short the answer that I have taken under advice. The answer to his question is that, should this bill be carried, ANL would be less at risk than it would be otherwise.
—But you cannot explain to me why that is so.
—I was beginning to explain to Senator Short why it was so before he started to interject.
—Well, I will be quiet and listen to your explanation of why.

—All right. The explanation is quite simple and straightforward. It is the government's intention to enable the ANL's board to come up with a plan to restructure the ANL so it can continue to operate. The purpose of guaranteeing the draw-down, and the loans that underpin the ANL in the meanwhile, is to achieve that outcome. I believe that the alternative to that is to create problems in the market and undermine the ability of the ANL to continue at all. This is a constructive option and, therefore, I think it is quite properly the one which is of least risk to taxpayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not pursue this any further. Senator Cook obviously does not have a clue what he is talking about. I will save him further embarrassment by not pursuing it. I have to say that the obfuscation that Senator Cook is showing in his handling of this matter, and his obvious lack of knowledge and understanding, is absolutely typical of what I said in my speech during the second reading debate: the government has handled this whole ANL matter during the last three years in a disgraceful manner.

PARA.TAB: Through its handling of this matter, the government has potentially caused a considerable cost to the Australian taxpayer. It has certainly caused grave damage to the shipping line and, therefore, to Australia's shipping industry. From the way that Senator Cook has conducted this debate today—and I accept the fact that it is not his portfolio; but he should be better briefed and know more about what he is supposed to be handling in this place—all I can say is heaven knows how this government has managed to keep its incompetence at only this level. I will not pursue that, because I am obviously not going to get any further.

I want to ask a couple more questions arising from an article in today's Australian Financial Review. I presume Senator Cook has seen it and, therefore, I hope he has been briefed on it because I think it is a very serious article. It states:
The global shipping company Sealand and local transport company Linfox appear set to finalise a consortium offer for the Federal Government-owned shipping line ANL by Christmas.
The consortium will be in a position to make the only union-blessed offer for the troubled ANL when tenders open next year, giving it a clear edge over other bidders.

SPEECH.PARA: That is an extremely serious report—if it is correct—because the tender process has not even opened yet. Expressions of interest were called only in the last four or five weeks. Is there any validity in that statement, particularly when it quotes from the Maritime Union's response? The union is reported as saying:

PARA.TAB: "The other consortiums aren't interested in having employee share arrangements—they've got a number of ideas which just aren't compatible to our way of thinking, or any good for ANL in the long term."

SPEECH.PARA: For those reports to be in the press before the tender process has even opened raises matters of very great concern. I hope that Senator Cook has been briefed on that, because it has a direct bearing on this bill. I invite the minister to comment on it, because the Senate obviously cannot be left in the dark on a matter of such concern.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not appreciate the gratuitous and insulting language that Senator Short just used to me.
—Well, if you were a better minister and better informed, you would not get it.
—Thank you very much, Senator Short. I had extended to Senator Short a considerable courtesy in this chamber—
—By trying to answer some questions?
—By trying to answer hypothetical questions.
—They were not hypothetical questions.

—They were hypothetical questions. I tried to answer them in a way which gave Senator Short the maximum amount of information. I am not obliged to answer hypothetical questions. If Senator Short wants to be gratuitous, I will slip back into my normal mode and answer what is on the record and is not hypothetical. If Senator Short wants to behave as he has, that is the way in which he will get answered. Let me make that very clear. It is getting a bit late in the day. I will turn—
—And you are getting hot under the collar.
—That is right, I am. Because I do not appreciate the sort of behaviour I just had visited on me. If people want to do that, I will get a bit hot under the collar.
—I cannot be bothered spending time here with incompetence oozing from the other side of the chamber.

—If Senator Short would ask competent questions, he would get competent answers. I will put the question of today's newspaper speculation into context. I just happen to have been up until 2 o'clock this morning on an estimates committee. I have been in this chamber since the beginning of the morning on legislation to do with two other bills, as well as being briefed on my own portfolio for question time and having a number of other major appointments for my portfolio since. So I have not read every newspaper in Australia today, which is a bit unusual for me I know. I have seen the article that Senator Short referred to, but I have not read it. I have been advised on it, and it is on the basis of that advice that I answer Senator Short's question.

PARA.TAB: It is my understanding that Sealand and Linfox have expressed some interest in the future operation of ANL. A number of other parties are also potentially interested, but it is premature to speculate on the form any sale process may take until the ANL board has provided its recommendations for restructuring the company. Any further consideration of a sale, which would involve an open tender process, will be dependent on the restructuring exercise. I would have thought that last part was axiomatic, but that is the answer to the question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for that. I ask whether the minister shares my concern with the report, particularly the reported quote from the union which says:

PARA.TAB: The other consortiums aren't interested in having employee share arrangements—they've got a number of ideas which just aren't compatible to our way of thinking, or any good for ANL in the long term.

SPEECH.PARA: Whether that is right or wrong is not for me to judge at this stage, just as it is not for the minister to judge. I would have thought the fact that that report is in the paper with that type of comment before the tender process has even opened has very considerable implications for the potential tenders.

PARA.TAB: It is for that reason that I raise the matter. There would be potential tenderers around, I would have thought, who would look at this and say, `A deal has already been signed before the tender process has even opened.' If that is the case, that is a matter of real concern. We may not be able to progress it any further at this stage today, unless the minister has anything further to add, which, it appears, he has not, but it is something that I urge the government to look at very quickly. I ask the minister to seek an assurance from the minister in the other place that there have not been any actions which have not been totally in accordance with due processes up to this point.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that the minister will read the Hansard of this debate with some interest and, if he needs to make a comment on this, will do so. I can assure the committee that the government's mind is entirely focused on what are the best interests for ANL, getting the process that the board is now conducting completed, and properly giving weight and attention to the recommendations it might make. We are not in the business of dealing with random press reports about what people say and think about this process and what they might do in certain circumstances. We are concentrating on getting this right and making a proper decision on behalf of the government and the Australian community. The fact that people go and say things is interesting, I suppose, but it does not drive us or affect the decisions that we are making here. The answer I have given before is the same answer to which I now draw to the honourable senator's attention.
—Has there been a similar bill to the one that we are now considering for any other asset sale undertaken by the Commonwealth? If so, which asset sales were they?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that in the Qantas sale there was a similar requirement.

PARA.TAB: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Cook) read a third time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: STUDENT ASSISTANCE (YOUTH TRAINING ALLOWANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: STUDENT ASSISTANCE (YOUTH TRAINING ALLOWANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1994STUDENT ASSISTANCE (YOUTH TRAINING ALLOWANCE--TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1994

TALK.START.PARA: —When we last attempted to deal with this, it was almost abandoned. The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) was questioning the minister in a very detailed manner about the government's amendments. I think it is right for me to be standing and attempting to fill some space with words while the minister is appraised of that situation because in the intervening time, I think, the parties have been able to at least discuss which amendments lead to where and which amendments are deserving of support.

PARA.TAB: I think it is also important to re-register that the government amendments which were under initial consideration are the amendments and new clauses which apply to the Student Assistance (Youth Training Allowance) Amendment Bill 1994, with the first section under the subheading `interpretation 5'. I say all this by way of clarification because a considerable number of amendments have been presented to us on behalf of the government, and it is important that we are clear.

I foreshadow that I have some questions about the youth training allowance amendment bill requests. I, on behalf of the Democrats, do not have any significant questions about the amendments, as distinct from the requests. I am really speaking only so that people can get themselves in order and be clear about which particular part we are concentrating on in the first instance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Senator Schacht will be here shortly.

—I thank the minister. It was Senator Schacht who was attempting to demonstrate that he was most familiar with this section when we left off. On behalf of the Democrats, I have no substantial questions at this time on the bulk of the first section that was in question.

—The Greens are also prepared to support the government's amendments and requests, but I foreshadow that most of our problems come in clause 18, as do the Democrats'. I foreshadow that, when I get to the point of moving my requested amendments, I would like to move them in batches, if possible, because some may be supported and some may not be.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Herron)—Yes, that can be done.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Bell, I was relieved that the amendments have been brought to the chamber in a slightly more workable fashion. I foreshadow that the opposition has one amendment, which has been circulated. I would like to ask Senator Schacht several questions about the other amendments. We certainly have looked at the amendments which have been put forward by the Greens and the Australian Democrats. I am happy to leave it at that for the moment.

PARA.TAB: Amendments and requests agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask Senator Schacht a couple of questions about the government amendments. We were told during discussion that the effect of government amendment A7 on page 7 of the explanatory memorandum would be to provide that the secretary must waive student assistance debts where a debt is less than $50 and it would not be cost effective to recover. The National Union of Students has raised that as one of the problems with this legislation.

PARA.TAB: In relation to social security debts, it is considered not cost effective to recover debts of less than $200. But, in relation to student assistance debts, it is considered not cost effective to recover debts of less than $50. I would like the minister to explain how it can be cost effective for one department to recover debts at one level but not for another department.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The information I have been supplied with in relation to this question is as follows: the $200 threshold was set in the Social Security Act in recognition of the overheads of the Department of Social Security at the time. The running costs profile has changed in the intervening period. What were salary overheads for the department do not apply to DEET, which has invested in interfacing payments and debt recovery systems. Does Senator Bell agree with that?
—Spot on.

—I can only begin to imagine what that means. In relation to overpayments, your advisers suggested in the briefing I had with them on these matters that somewhat of a detailed analysis was to be made of Austudy overpayments before the next budget. I ask the minister whether this will indeed take place.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just received more information. Social Security set its level in legislation some time ago. DEET has not set its level in legislation but has developed better computer systems so that it is able to handle efficiently and cost effectively debts down to the $50 level. That is why DEET has not taken the $200 level; it has been able to go down to $50. In the sense of public revenue, if it is a more efficient system we will get more of the money back. I am not representing Social Security, but perhaps we should send that department the message that DEET could advise it on how to do this. We have advised NUS that these issues will be looked at in the budget context anyway.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although there are quite a number of pages between the part of the bill that Senator Troeth referred to and that which I want to address, the two matters are pretty closely related. I refer the minister to the amendment to clause 18, page 181, which proposes to insert before proposed section 292 a new section under the heading `Application of Division'. In passing, I express the opinion that the proposal to insert this new section virtually proves the point that Senator Troeth, Senator Margetts and I made about the increased complexity which has been brought about by the government's decision to set up a whole new arrangement which will therefore need a whole new lot of cross-references. I really want to ask about amendment No. 29, which is on the following page, page 8. Again, the amendment refers to clause 18, page 181. For the edification of honourable senators who may be listening, the amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 18, page 181, proposed subsection 292(1), note, lines 34 to 39, omit the note, substitute the following note:

If a payment made under Part 8 is stopped or a rate of payment is varied because of the operation of a computer program there will still be a decision of an officer for review purposes. Section 159 provides that there is a decision of the Secretary if Part 8 operates automatically to terminate or reduce the rate of a youth training allowance. If the Secretary could have made a determination to suspend or cancel, or increase or reduce the rate of, a youth training allowance, section 164 provides that the determination is taken to have been made.

I presume by the secretary. Firstly, what is the effect of that? Does that mean that a recipient accrues the right of appeal—I suppose the right of appeal is the main right that is required—which can be exercised by appealing against the secretary's decision? Is that the case?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the client can appeal.
—I presumed that. Is this note clarifying that that appeal can be made against the secretary's decision if in reality the decision was made by a computer program?
—Yes.
—Thank you very much.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put on record responses to matters that were raised in the debate yesterday and also in the discussions that have taken place between my department and senators. In discussions outside the chamber, Senator Harradine referred to the fact that a departmental officer can be appointed to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. Senator Harradine suggested that the issue be referred to the Administrative Review Council for consideration.

PARA.TAB: The Administrative Review Council issued a discussion paper in September of this year. The paper is called `Review of Commonwealth Merits Review Tribunals'. The paper notes that there has been some criticism of the inclusion of former departmental officers on the Social Security Appeals Tribunal.
