However, the papers states that there is no indication that departmental members of the tribunal have not carried out their responsibilities in an appropriate manner. The Administrative Review Council is proposing to forward recommendations to the government by the end of May 1995. The government will carefully examine the council's comments to see whether changes are needed to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal.

Another matter I want to put on record—we might have covered it in part yesterday—is that, during the debate on the second reading, Senator Troeth and Senator Bell both referred to a concern by the National Union of Students about this issue of departmental members of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. As indicated during the debate, the minister, Mr Free, met with the NUS officers and reached general agreement on their concerns about the bill. It was agreed that NUS would monitor the involvement of DEET officers with the Social Security Appeals Tribunal and advise the minister if it considered that this was a problem. I put that on the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Schacht. That dealt with another comment I was going to make. I am very pleased that that point has been taken up, because it is necessary to monitor in that way. I would also like to ask the minister about amendment A33 on page 11 of the explanatory memorandum which would insert a new clause to provide that a person who has an adverse decision from the department must apply for an internal review within three months after the making of that decision.

PARA.TAB: I point out the coalition's concern that three months may not be a long enough time in this day and age for a young person, with no understanding of the system, to receive notification of the decision, to realise that he or she has the right of appeal and then to finally file an appeal. I know from the experience of my children that many children in a secondary or tertiary position living away from home often have a degree of difficulty in having their mail forwarded to them or in receiving other communications relating to their education. We believe that perhaps six months may be a more appropriate time limit.

At this stage, we will not be proposing amendments to the legislation. However, the coalition gives notice that we will be monitoring the situation very closely. Should it become obvious that, say, after six months, students are being disadvantaged by that short time limit, we will seek to amend the legislation at an appropriate time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that, first of all, we have actually extended the period. Thirty days was the limit to lodge an appeal; we have extended that to three months, which is what is operating in the Department of Social Security. However, the secretary to the department has the power to extend the period of appeal according to the circumstances. So we think that with that flexibility and by extending it up to the three-month period it is not an unreasonable adjustment.

PARA.TAB: Also as a parent with teenage kids at university, I take note of the fact students of a certain age may lack experience. We think that is reasonable. If over the next 12 months or so there are problems, obviously we will be happy to come back and have a look at it. We are not inflexible about this. But we think that three months, with the discretion of the secretary, is an appropriate balance between efficiency and giving a person the right to appeal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask the minister a question about request No. 2, clause 18, page 25, which is about substituting proposed subsection 75(9). There is a description there of what sort of commuting would not be unreasonably difficult. I ask the minister: is it seriously thought that 90 minutes worth of commuting each way is a reasonable thing to ask somebody to do to attend a youth training course? Surely that cannot be a serious consideration. From my understanding of South Australian geography, that is halfway to Port Pirie from Adelaide.
—I will tell you what: you would be breaking the speed limit if it was.

—My recent experiences give me great cause to stay well below the speed limit. Those who are on P plates would want to do the same. Whether it is travelling in your own car, being driven on a bus of some description, sitting on a train, or whatever the means, 90 minutes each way does not seem to me to be a reasonable request.
—What do you think would be a reasonable request?

—I would have thought an hour would be a much better limit, particularly when we consider that it is each way. Firstly, what is the basis for the 90 minutes and, secondly, is it consistent with any other measurement made in any other situation?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that we are basing this on the social security legislation, and the reference to 90 minutes has been there for a long time. So we are continuing with an arrangement or precedent that seems to have worked reasonably well.

—I find it hard to agree with that. But if that is the case, and because I have been arguing for consistency all along, I can hardly disagree with it. However, I hope that the minister at the table might find it easy to agree with me when I say that we think it would not be very fair if the secretary were to regularly make decisions to require people to attend training programs which were such a distance from home. It may be a fact that the social security legislation contains this figure. But I hope it does not relate to people seeking employment or people who are seeking to attend training schemes.

PARA.TAB: From my experience with youth training programs—not as a teacher, but with after-school and employment seeking training programs—placing that sort of stress on a young person at the beginning and the end of the day's program, as part of a program to encourage the young person to reach employability, which is one of the laudable targets of this activity, is enough to turn anyone off. While I do not seek to amend this provision, I hope the minister agrees that this power of the secretary is a power which, wisely, would be used infrequently.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Bell that we would always hope, in all areas of public administration, that such powers are used wisely and with discretion. I think 90 minutes is not an unreasonable time. In the metropolitan areas of Australia, people regularly travel 90 minutes each day to work, or even up to a couple of hours to work and a couple of hours back home. Senator Bell and I come from smaller states. We can drive from one side of Adelaide or Hobart to the other in a matter of 20 minutes or half an hour. To me, 90 minutes of travel from one side of Sydney to the other is a bit of a horrendous trip.
—It would put anyone off.

—It would put anyone off living there—they should come and live in Adelaide. I think Senator Bell and I are reflecting on our better lifestyles from living in smaller states. Clearly, the device of that 90 minutes should not be used to put pressure on people. If Senator Bell ever comes across an example, I would appreciate it if he would bring it to my attention and that of the minister and we will investigate it, because it is not the intent of the clause to put unnecessary pressure on the people involved. It is a matter of trying to get some reasonable rules that are understandable for good public administration purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:

SPEECH.PARA: 1Clause 18, page 31, at the end of proposed section 81, add the following subsection:
"(3) A person is not to be taken:

PARA.TAB: (a)to have failed to agree to terms of the agreement proposed by the Commonwealth Employment Service within the meaning of subparagraph (1)(b)(iii); or
(b)to be unreasonably delaying entering into the agreement within the meaning of subsection (1);

SPEECH.PARA: merely because the person is continuing, or seeking to continue, to engage in reasonable and bone fide negotiation of the agreement with a view to the free acceptance of such an agreement by both parties.".
2Clause 18, page 27, proposed subsection 77(1), line 34, omit "subsection (2)", substitute "subsections (2) and (3)".
3Clause 18, page 28, at end of proposed section 77, add the following subsection:
"`(3) Paragraph (1)(b) does not apply if:

PARA.TAB: (a)the person was employed by the organisation; and
(b)that employment ended on a day, but not later than 2 weeks after that day the person was engaged in full-time voluntary work for the organisation; and
(c)the person is a qualified beneficiary and was a qualified beneficiary immediately after the person started working for the organisation in such a full-time voluntary capacity.".

SPEECH.PARA: My amendments are actually requests for amendments. My first two requests for amendments are to amend the definition of an activity agreement by adding an extra clause at the end of proposed section 81 of clause 18 page 31.

PARA.TAB: The second request for amendment deals with the failure of a person to take reasonable steps to comply with an activity agreement in clause 18 page 27. The request requires the reassertion that a suspension of the youth training allowance should only be made after every attempt has been made to come to a negotiated agreement between two parties before and after the incident in question. Such an incident outlined in these clauses includes, first of all, refusing a job; secondly, misconduct in a job; and, thirdly, unemployment due to a voluntary act.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Margetts' proposed amendment seeks to loosen the obligation of an unemployed person to negotiate an activity agreement. The government is providing substantial funds to assist unemployed people and there is an expectation that they will be responsible in seeking appropriate employment. This expectation is reflected in the relevant provision, section 81, which applies only if the young person is acting unreasonably in refusing to enter an activity agreement. On this basis the legislation requires that activity agreements are to take into account the client's education, experience, skills, age and physical condition—see section 84(a).

PARA.TAB: The proposed amendment would place undue weight on young people's free decisions on whether they should continue to receive public funding if they refuse to enter realistic activity agreements. In any event, young people can appeal to an independent tribunal if they believe the department is being too harsh in its requirement that they enter an activity agreement. I emphasise that we have to get the balance right, as far as possible, between the obligation of public administration to ensure the public's money is properly accounted for and wisely spent, and the right of the individual to be well treated. In any area of public administration there are often grey areas of judgment. I think this legislation is about the right balance but we will have to wait and see how it operates.

I emphasise that last point: there is a provision for people to appeal to an independent tribunal if they think they are being harshly treated. Whatever else Senator Margetts may think, we have put an appeals provision into the act in this area. I hope it never is used but if young people are feeling harshly dealt with they can appeal to an independent tribunal.

TALK.START.PARA: —How would the minister rate the ability of 16-year-olds to utilise their resources to appeal to an independent tribunal? How would the minister rate their relative power in this particular arrangement?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an area of subjective judgment about what Senator Margetts or I or anyone else may think of the ability of a 16-year-old. I do not know how many 16-year-olds in this position would be living independently away from home and alone. I should have thought that the overwhelming majority of 16-year-olds would still have some contact with parents and relatives. If they felt they were being hard done by, I would be surprised if they did not raise it with a relative, parents or friends, and such discussions I am sure somebody would say, `Are there appeal provisions? We want to complain about this.' But nothing is perfect.

PARA.TAB: I have just been advised that if they disagree with the treatment they are advised in writing by the department that they have a right of appeal. Once they get that advice in writing we have fully discharged our responsibility to explain to them. I would be surprised if, other than in the smallest minority of cases, most 16-year-olds would not be able to work out, through consultation with friends, parents and relatives, that if they have this letter there is an opportunity to appeal.

TALK.START.PARA: —In support of Senator Margetts' position, I wonder whether the minister might not reconsider the rejection of these amendments. By accepting them there would be a reduced number of occasions when this appeal mechanism, which I acknowledge exists, would need to be brought into account.
—Which amendment, Senator?

—Looking at the first amendment moved by Senator Margetts in particular, I would remind the minister that the amendment actually proposes that a person is not to be taken to have failed or to be unreasonably delaying merely because the person is continuing, or seeking to continue, to engage in reasonable and bona fide negotiation. To me, that means that if the young person is not satisfied with the first proposition put forward by the case manager and seeks to vary it, or negotiate to have another go at it, then that person should not be taken to have failed. As I interpret it, this is just the first instance. This is just a case of wanting to have another go at it, or have a look at another arrangement. All that the amendment does is ensure that the person is able to take another step without being clobbered over the head and sent one of these letters, winding the appeal process up and getting it all official.

PARA.TAB: This set of amendments would make the administrative process much less formidable and much more workable. It does not extend it forever. It does not say anywhere that the person can continue ad infinitum, or anything else. It says that people have not failed just because they want to continue it and seek another opportunity. I wonder whether the minister would reconsider that because it makes it more efficient and less likely to result in these appeals that he speaks of.

TALK.START.PARA: —Might I add, it is much more cost effective.

—We will be supporting amendments Nos 1 and 2. We believe they allow just a bit more of a two-way negotiation process. The coalition's philosophical position has always been to make the person entering the system fairly rigorously accountable, but I am taking particular note of the age of the people involved in this procedure and I take the view that for a 15-, 16- or 17-year-old to enter the bureaucratic process would involve a degree of maturity that I suspect not many people at that age possess. I think that to accept these amendments would ensure that at the last resort people are not forced into an agreement which would be totally wrong for them. The wording allows that if the negotiation is not reasonable and bone fide they will be disqualified and I think this provides the flexibility that we would be looking for in amendments Nos 1 and 2. As I understand it, Senator Margetts' amendment No. 3 deals with the activity test—is that right?

—The request for amendment 3 is in addition to 77(1)(b), which currently says that the person must have been receiving youth training allowance for three months before starting voluntary work for an organisation. My amendment allows for voluntary work to take place at an organisation that a person may have had previous involvement with before receiving the youth training allowance. The way the legislation is currently written it could be interpreted that there can be no prior involvement with the organisation.

—I thank Senator Margetts for that explanation. The coalition will also be supporting that amendment. We have always held the view that voluntary work is to be encouraged and it seems fair enough to support this amendment. Otherwise, if people start voluntary work almost immediately after losing their job and then become eligible for the youth training allowance, they will have to stop their voluntary work for three months and start again. We do not believe that is particularly fair. So we will be supporting that amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —We believe that the last line of amendment No. 1 which says `with a view to the free acceptance of such an agreement by both parties' places undue emphasis on free acceptance. We think that our wording of `reasonable' is more appropriate to a proper balance between the rights of the government in running the program and the obligations on both sides, including those of the person involved.

PARA.TAB: Regarding amendment No. 3, which Senator Troeth has just spoken to, we believe the emphasis for youth training allowance is on helping young people to become financially self-supporting through paid employment. While it is recognised that voluntary work can help young people in the transition to paid employment, there are limitations on the extent to which young people can receive the youth training allowance while undertaking voluntary work. Although voluntary agencies are responsible and contribute significantly to the community, it should be recognised that the proposed amendment would create the possibility that an organisation could use the legislation to have the government pay for its young supporters to work for it on a voluntary basis which, of course, defeats the purpose of providing a training allowance and the training component. So the government opposes the amendments from Senator Margetts.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems that there may be the numbers to pass my amendment No. 1 but, if the problem is free acceptance of such an agreement, does the minister have any preferred wording that would make that acceptable?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had a brief discussion with my advisers. We are not unreasonable or obstinate about looking at a form of words. For example, if we delete `both' in the second line in amendment 1 and replace it with `the', so that it reads `by the parties', that is an amendment that we could live with. We are more concerned about amendment No. 3, which deals with voluntary work. We would like to discuss those issues further with the opposition and the minority parties because we are a bit concerned that we may open up a couple of loopholes and get some unintended consequences that we will all regret a bit later. This is often the problem when we do not have further discussion. We may be able to come to some satisfactory arrangement. As we have to adjourn shortly, we could arrange to have a discussion on this clause overnight. I do not think it would take long and I am happy that we do so.
—Could it be this evening rather than overnight?
—Yes, any time between now and 9.30 tomorrow morning.
—I thought you were asking us out to dinner.
—No, Senator Kemp would never be so lucky as to get a free feed out of me.
—We get a free laugh every day.
—Senator Kemp's former leader once said there is no such thing as a free lunch; well there is no such thing as a free dinner for Senator Kemp. I would like to report progress on the committee stage.

—Before we do report progress, I want to point out that in amendment 3 the proviso that voluntary work will not satisfy the activity test for more than 30 days in a year or if a reasonably paid job opportunity became available would stand as printed.

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Nursing Home Standards Review Panel annual reports outline the operations of the state review panels into nursing home standards. I do not wish to speak for more than a few minutes on these annual reports. However, there is one matter which I wish to bring to the attention of the Senate. By way of background, the Victorian Nursing Homes Standards Review Panel undertook two reviews in 1993-94; the Queensland panel undertook one review; and the New South Wales panel undertook four reviews. In all of these reviews, except the one in Queensland, the decision of the standards monitoring teams were upheld.

PARA.TAB: For the benefit of senators in the chamber who are not fully aware of it, there is a process called standards monitoring where nursing homes are subjected to a monitoring test by a standards monitoring team to assess whether they have adhered to outcome standards set down by the Commonwealth for the care of elderly residents in their nursing homes. There has been some debate about the standards monitoring teams as to whether they are uniform across the states, et cetera, but we have seen some improvements in those standards monitoring teams. In one case in Queensland a nursing home failed to meet the standards according to the standards monitoring team and the review overturned that decision. It is about that review that I want to speak.

The coalition received representations from the Denmora Nursing Home in Bowen Hills, Queensland, in which that nursing home complained that it had suffered financially following an adverse standards monitoring visit, the findings of which were ultimately overturned on the official review. The crucial point was not the initial adverse findings of the standards monitoring team but the fact that the then assistant secretary of the residential care, quality and rights branch of the Department of Human Services and Health wrote to all the local doctors on 25 November 1993 advising that on that day Denmora had been advised of an adverse standards assessment.

Naturally, such a letter had a dramatic and adverse effect on the reputation and financial viability of the nursing home, because referrals to the nursing home come largely from the local doctors. In January 1994 a review of the findings of the standards monitoring team gave Denmora the all-clear.

The review panel made a recommendation not to declare that the home did not meet the standards. The panel found that the seven objectives had now been substantially met and action taken to maintain them. When I asked in the estimates hearings on 18 November whether it was normal practice for the department to send out such a letter, given the obvious effects that such a letter would have on the reputation and financial viability of the nursing home in question, I was told by Mr Griew of the department that if a home is found to be in serious breach of standards it is a procedure that is sometimes followed to send a letter to local doctors.

Two points need to be emphasised. First, I see this as an unfair approach—to issue letters notifying local doctors of adverse monitoring reports before a review has been undertaken. If it is thought necessary to notify the local doctors, the doctor should be told that this is what has happened but that this decision is subject to a review. Then the doctors would be aware that the nursing home has a second chance.

Secondly, it was disclosed at the estimates hearing that there is no requirement for a second letter to be circulated to clarify the status of the nursing home once a review has overturned the standards monitoring team assessment. Further, the Commonwealth is apparently not liable at law if the findings of a standards monitoring team, which are subsequently overturned, have caused financial detriment to a nursing home, its proprietors or staff. It seems from answers given at the estimates hearing that if the department had acted in good faith and without malice, it would come under qualified privilege.

It is of concern to me, as it should be to other honourable senators, that we have to ensure that the department should not be in a position to ruin the reputation of a nursing home by circulating a letter to doctors advising of an adverse standards monitoring report before a review has been held. As I said, if the monitoring team thinks it is necessary then the doctors ought to be informed that that review is going to take place and the department ought to have an obligation to send a second letter advising that the adverse finding has been overturned. I believe this is an issue that the department and the government ought to address. If they tell the doctors that a home has failed the standards test, and the matter is then reviewed and that home is deemed not to have failed, there is an obligation on the department to advise the doctors accordingly.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the documents.

SPEECH.PARA: This illustrates better than anything I know the problem facing this chamber. The government has come in and put on the table 36 treaties which it has signed with various countries and international agencies. There it all is. I have five minutes to debate 36 treaties, many of which will have a significant impact on this country. The government feels that this is an appropriate way to do business.

PARA.TAB: I put it to my colleagues in the Senate, to Senator Harradine, to the Greens and to the Australian Democrats that something has got to be done. Of the 36, there is no doubt that the four or five that I have been able to quickly look at will contain issues of quite considerable public controversy. There has been no careful consideration of these treaties by the Australian public, no parliamentary debate on them, no committee has gone through them.

The government has gone out and signed these treaties. Undoubtedly, it has negotiated with the particular interest groups involved and, maybe if we are lucky—with the states. It may have sought agreement with those interest groups. This is the problem and this is the challenge that is facing the Senate. The only way to deal with this problem is for this Senate to establish a treaties committee so that controversial treaties can be carefully examined and public evidence taken on them.

These treaties have already been signed and ratified. Australia, under international law, is already committed to these treaties. Senator Collins may well come in to the chamber and say, `Senator Kemp, most people would not object to treaties on this and treaties on that,' and he is probably quite right.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most people would not object to treaties on this or on that.

—Most people, if they knew what was involved in the treaties, may well have a particular view which the government may wish to hear. This is the problem which is facing the Senate. This is no way to deal with documents of major importance which have an effect on this country.

PARA.TAB: The government has also tabled—this is some slight improvement—a list of multilateral treaties under negotiation or active consideration. So at least the Senate has been officially informed that this treaty making activity is under way. As I understand it, part of the problem is that we cannot get copies of these documents.

TALK.START.PARA: —How did you get them?

—We can get copies of the list but not the actual documents involved. The government has indicated that various departments can be contacted so that senators can get a briefing on particular treaties. I acknowledge that that is a step forward. I hope honourable senators will look closely at this list and obtain briefings on issues of importance to them. This is the very sort of treaty making activity in which this parliament should now start to take an effective role.

PARA.TAB: In looking through the list of multilateral treaties under negotiation, I see that many of them may affect your home state, Mr Acting Deputy President. Many of them may affect your constituents. I think we would both want to make sure that, if Senator Gareth Evans and his colleagues persist in their enthusiasm for a range of multilateral treaties, the Australian people will also have a role. The challenge is before this chamber to set up some treaty making committee to carefully scrutinise the more controversial treaties. If the government itself does not wish to establish a joint house committee, the onus falls on the Senate to get some order, some process into this particular issue.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, this is not the first time, nor will it be the last, that I have risen in this place to express my concern about the method that has been adopted by the government in bringing literally—
—Three reams.

—three reams of treaties before this chamber for us to deal with in five minutes. It is an unsatisfactory situation, particularly when the government is not averse to utilising its external affairs power to implement legislation overriding state legislation that is found to be inconsistent.

PARA.TAB: As has been explained, there are provisions for consultation with states. However, I am concerned to ensure, as I am sure Senator Kemp, the Australian Democrats and the Greens are, that there be an opportunity for people who are interested in particular treaties to be aware of the negotiations that are taking place and to have some input, either through us as their representatives, or through a Senate or joint committee.

This is a matter that has already been discussed and on which there were submissions to the Human Rights Subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. It is not for me to canvass what might be included in the committee's report, which will be brought down in both houses on 6 December but I have a notice of motion on the Notice Paper calling for the establishment of a treaty committee—a committee of this Senate or of this parliament—to examine treaties before they are signed in order to assess their possible effect on Commonwealth and state legislation.

I agree with Senator Kemp that we have here at least an improvement over what has previously taken place—a list of multilateral treaties under negotiation or active consideration for Australian government signature adherence. That is an improvement, and I acknowledge it. I hope that the government will give very serious consideration to the expressions of dissatisfaction from various members on all sides of the parliament with the treaty preparations, the treaty negotiations and the treaty making power of the executive government.

Indeed, I believe that the executive government is acknowledging that to a certain extent. If it takes that one little extra step, I think we will be working in harmony. I hope that will be so in the near future and I look forward to the government's response in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted: debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I make comment on the annual report of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, I would like to compliment my colleagues Senator Kemp and Senator Harradine on their very good speeches about the problems that this country faces with international treaties. I look forward to the adjourned debate.

PARA.TAB: Having said that, I now turn to the annual report of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, which I note was tabled approximately one month too late. Under the departmental guidelines stipulating the reporting dates for annual reports, this report should have been in this house by 31 October. I understand that it was presented to the Attorney-General on 17 October. It has taken all that time to find its way into this house. If the departmental guidelines established for the tabling of annual reports are not to be followed, with respect, the guidelines are quite meaningless.

This delay means that the members of the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee were not given a real opportunity to peruse the annual report before that committee's deliberations. Indeed, at that hearing the other day I was confronted with the situation of being presented with the untabled report of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission consisting of some 258 pages. I was supposed to digest that during the hearing and ask appropriate questions about it. I must say, that is not good enough, either from the departmental point of view or from a ministerial point of view. I hope that in the future these reports will be tabled by the appropriate date, enabling senators to make appropriate inquiries so we can ask appropriate questions.

During that committee's hearings I had the opportunity to flick through the annual report of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. Given that racial hatred legislation was a matter of public discussion, I turned to that section of the report and gave it some consideration. I noticed that in 1993-94, 458 complaints were accepted within the jurisdiction of the Racial Discrimination Act. Employment related complaints constituted the largest proportion, being 57 per cent.

Of most interest was the number of complaints lodged under the legislation specifically on the ground of incitement to unlawful acts. For the period 1993-94, there were absolutely no complaints for incitement to unlawful acts in relation to racial matters. I found that very interesting, given the fact that the government is trying to foist certain legislation on the Australian people. I thought that 1993-94 may possibly not be representative so I went back further. I have the table in front of me. In relation to incitement to unlawful acts, in 1989-90 there were only two complaints. Both of those were in New South Wales, which has racial discrimination legislation. In 1990-91, there was only one complaint—that was in Queensland. In 1991-92 there were no complaints. In 1992-93 there was one in Victoria—and Victoria is to have its own legislation.

Of the two complaints lodged with the commission in 1989-90 no explanation was provided in the annual report as to whether these cases were settled, resolved or withdrawn. No explanation was provided in the annual report as to the virtual non-existence of cases specifically lodged with the commission on the basis of incitement to unlawful acts. As a result, one has to question the government's motive in introducing such legislation as the Racial Hatred Bill when the statistics from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission suggest that the few alleged cases that do exist, exist in states that already have racial discrimination laws.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make a few remarks about the annual report of the Australian Fisheries Management Authority, the AFMA. I am pleased to see that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) is in the chamber. He knows I have some interest in fishery matters. As a person who has been interested in fishing all his life, over the years I have been concerned—like a lot of my friends—about what appears to be an overall reduction in fishery stocks right around Australia, particularly in areas where amateurs can fish. It is a problem. I am pleased to see that at last we have a body, the Australian Fisheries Management Authority, which has a plan not just for Tasmania, the area I am interested in, but for all Australia. I compliment the authority on its report.

PARA.TAB: When I looked at the report I noticed in the overview by the general manager that those people who have been acting illegally are at last being brought to justice. This is long overdue, although I was a bit disturbed to see that prosecutions for suspected quota-related offences under the 1992 plan were unsuccessful. That is most unfortunate. Let us hope that the AFMA can get its act together and start to apprehend these people who are rorting the system.

The part of the report that I was particularly interested in was the south-east fishery. If I ever had any doubt about the management of advisory committees they have been allayed. I noted in appendix 6 of the report that the chairperson of the committee is none other than the former Attorney-General of Tasmania, the Hon. John Bennett, whom my colleague Senator Abetz would recall. I do not think there could be a more honourable person to chair the South East Trawl Management Advisory Committee and make sure that it worked correctly.

When I was located in my former electorate office—it is now occupied by Senator Abetz—I used to park my car within 10 yards of the wharf. I was very disturbed to see trawlers coming in from New South Wales, South Australia and Victoria to feast upon the boom time of orange roughy trawling. Ships would come in almost under water. They had been out pillaging the aggregations of orange roughy, many of which are 50 years old. I thought then that this fishery would not last too long—and it has not. Over a couple of years we have seen what could have been a great industry for Tasmania being plundered by pirates from other areas of Australia. I am pleased to see from this report the AFMA noting that, because of declining stocks, measures have been taken to reduce the total allowable catch from 10,000 tonnes to 5,000 tonnes. I have to ask: is it a case of closing the door after the horse has bolted?

Further along in the report is another area I have been interested in for a long time—the Bass Strait scallop fishery. The minister, Senator Collins, told me last night how impressed he has been with scallops. We have a Victorian zone, an intermediate zone and a Tasmanian zone controlled by different state authorities. But the scallop fishery over some considerable time has been absolutely devastated. The scallop industry in Tasmania was once very great but the stocks have been depleted to such an extent that there are hardly any scallops left.

The southern bluefin tuna fishery is another example of overexploitation of what potentially could be a great industry. I am pleased to see that the AFMA is taking note of all these concerns and has plans in place. They are set out in the annual report. I commend this report to the Senate and commend the actions the AFMA is taking.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Office of Film and Literature Classification

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This report reflects on the work of the Office of Film and Literature Classification, the OFLC, over the last year. It is an ongoing saga in the area of film and literature classification. It really started on a new era in the early 1970s. At that time there were two balancing principles in the area of censorship: that people should have the right to read, see and hear what they like; and that children should be protected. An additional principle was that people should not be offended by material they did not want to see. We have about to operate—this is a matter the committee has recently looked at—a national system which has national legislation for the first time, a uniform system of classification across Australia that is agreed to by both federal and state governments. Such a move, we believe, is welcome.

PARA.TAB: Our committee on community standards has looked at this particular piece of legislation very thoroughly. We do not have any great concerns with the thrust of the legislation, but we do have a number of concerns about the way in which scrutiny applies in the area of film classification, particularly scrutiny by the parliaments of the nation, and we do have concerns about the staffing of the board and the people who operate the film classification system in this country. I want to dwell on those two points when I speak about this report today.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.20 p.m., under sessional order I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is hard to suggest that there are positive sides to a drought, but I think the story I am about to tell is a positive one. In September I was approached by a lady living in Canberra who had heard about the drought on ABC radio and `wanted to do something'. She told me that women and children were often the forgotten victims and she thought that perhaps she would be able to get some food parcels to them sent from Canberra. Even though Jenny Butt was eager, enthusiastic and determined, little could I have imagined that day in my office that she would have been able to mastermind and develop such a campaign.

PARA.TAB: The rural drought relief for women and children has targeted a sometimes forgotten group in the community—women and children. This campaign had no John Farnham or Ray Martin, no glitzy media stunts—just a genuine desire to help and a woman who refused to let people say no. She organised bins in supermarkets around Canberra, then enlisted Davids Holdings/Festival for warehousing. She got various community groups on side and transport to the most needy areas. She enlisted friends, and friends of friends, as packers and collectors of bins. One such person is Jill Manning from the Senate office.

The one place where Jenny failed to get a bin placed at the front door was, regrettably, parliament house. Again, regrettably, the bin she placed in the staff canteen was filled with wrappers and other rubbish. The parcels that have been collected have gone to 110 families in Rocky Glen and to families in Coonabarabran and Quambone. A truckload was delivered to families in Stanthorpe by more volunteers—the CWA and other rural based groups. Everyone has pitched in to help. She also is now going to Collie, Hermidale and Girilambone. These parcels have had no effect on shopkeepers in rural areas because where these parcels have gone there is no local story and the families cannot afford to travel to get supplies.
I would like to read into Hansard just a few excerpts from some of the letters Jenny has received. This one is from Coonabarabran which says:
I must admit I don't feel comfortable taking the goods but to be honest it is a great help. Thank you sincerely—the Rural Drought Relief for Women and Children Group are doing a wonderful job.

SPEECH.PARA: Another letter, from Stanthorpe, said:

Thank God for women like you with a vision and able to carry it through. May God bless you as we do, it must have been a marathon task but you can be sure its reached it's goal in blessing those in need.
Another letter, again from Stanthorpe, says:

I'm really glad someone has recognised the women and children in all this. So I'm writing to thank you very much for the tremendous work you and your organisation are doing. Sometimes it is hard to accept `hand-outs' but there is a lovely feeling of caring that comes along with every box of goods.
Another one from Coonabarabran says:

I have been known to say that this year is `the year from Hades', the big dry is only a part of it, marriage break-up, ill health and a grand balance of $2.21 in the bank. Feeling down and defeated is putting it mildly, but, this year is coming to a close, there are people like your good self who share my breathing space, so, a smidgen of faith comes creeping back.

PARA.TAB: I thank you, not just for the parcel, but for being who and what you are, bless you.

SPEECH.PARA: There are many letters, but I would like to read a few more of them because I think they are quite moving. This one comes from Purlewaugh and is also written to Jenny Butt thanking her for what she did:
Yes times are difficult at present it is nice to know that someone cares enough to do what you and your helpers have done for many rural families here.
Another letter from Coonabarabran states:

I guess when you and your helpers organised the relief parcels you realised how much they would be appreciated, what you may not realise is that as with me the `relief' would come from the feeling that out there is concern and caring, that feeling means as much if not more than the contents of my parcel.
Another letter from Coonabarabran says:

This is just a short note to thank you so much for the Drought Relief Parcel I received yesterday. After looking at the dry land day after day and hungry stock it was nice to have santa come early and put a smile on our faces. Thank you, once again you'll never know how much your parcel was appreciated.
Another letter says:
So comforting to know someone was thinking of us all during this dreadful drought. Still no relief as far as savings but hoping for good rain soon.
There are plenty more letters but the last I will quote from is from Stanthorpe again. It says at the end of the letter:

PARA.TAB: It is great to know that the cities do care about us here in the country and all of our 50 families join with me in thanking you once again for the help and compassion you have shown us.

SPEECH.PARA: I think this basically shows that city and country can work together through a problem, just as people did when the earthquake struck Newcastle—people got in and helped. This particular drought has hurt so many people. People in the city of Canberra have been able to lend a hand and are being ably led by Jenny Butt. This appeal has now spread through Queanbeyan, Tumut, Wagga, Griffith and Bega and is bringing country and city people closer together.

PARA.TAB: As I said at the beginning, there are good sides to every adversity. This aspect of the people of Canberra—of people such as Jenny Butt—deserves to be recognised and deserves our support. I applaud Jenny Butt, as, I am sure, the Senate does and, indeed, as, I am sure, do all rural Australians who have benefited from her determination and her concern for her fellow man. The world needs more people who care, and Jenny Butt is one such person.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the beginning of this speech about Port Hinchinbrook tonight, I really thank Senator Ian Macdonald for causing me to go back and read much more carefully a document today which I had read fairly sketchily this morning. Tonight I want to put some of that document on the record. I found it very interesting to read the same document from which Senator Macdonald quoted this morning and at lunchtime. I think we were reading the same document, but the information I got from it certainly is a very different interpretation, as I read it.

PARA.TAB: The document is the report of the group of scientists called together by Senator Faulkner to look at the seagrass beds and other matters relating to the Hinchinbrook development. The interesting thing, I think, that needs to be said at the very beginning is that the scientists operated within a very narrow framework and were looking at what they term in their document a reactive form of management of the development; in other words, they were given a task to look at what the impact of the development would be. They were never asked to look at whether the development was appropriate or those kinds of questions that I would want to address. Although the guidelines were rather narrow, it is certainly interesting to find that the scientists had many interesting concerns which parallel the concerns I have been expressing here in this place on many occasions.

I really would like to put all of the document on the record but do not have the time tonight to do that. Perhaps I will just quote from the conclusion some of the issues that I think are very important. The scientists say:

SPEECH.PARA: Seagrass beds in the Hinchinbrook Channel are a significant resource and a valuable feature of the Great Barrier Reef World Heritage Area. Scientific evidence indicates that turbidity is a significant factor affecting the growth and the distribution of seagrass communities. There is considerable evidence of tropical seagrass beds being damaged or destroyed by periods of elevated turbidity. There is also evidence that tropical seagrass communities can survive periods of elevated turbidity and recover from disturbance.
I want to put both sides of the debate because, of course, this is a document which tries to do that. The document continues:

Many of the activities associated with the Port Hinchinbrook development have the potential to significantly increase local turbidity levels. It is therefore vital that site management be of high quality if risks to World Heritage values are to be avoided. Short term risks of large scale sediment mobilisation should be minimised and the timing of various aspects of the construction in relation to the wet season must be carefully considered.

With the loss of mangroves the worst case situation would be a significant loss of sediment into the adjacent Channel waters. The Working Group view was that this gives a moderate risk of localised seagrass loss adjacent to the development. However, there would be a high probability of recovery (within about 12 months) if water and sediment conditions return to those existing prior to impact.
I think it is important to note that. The document goes on:

In the longer term, development of the foreshore requires a foreshore management plan that incorporates sustainable options that control all forms of sediment loss to adjacent waters and meet the needs of site development. It is noted that mangroves provide an effective means of stabilising such foreshores and that the two species that presently comprise the narrow fringe readily coppice and can be trimmed.
High quality site management is critical to avoiding damage to World Heritage Values. The present state of the site poses a significant erosion hazard with the imminent onset of the wet season.

That is all that I am able to read in the time available to me. But against that, there is an underlying need for high quality management, and that really is the bottom line in terms of the report and the parts of the report I have read to honourable senators.

PARA.TAB: I also want to place another document on the record. This is a transcript of an interview between Keith Williams, the developer, and Cathy Job last night on the 7.30 Report in Queensland. I think some of the exchange is very interesting because in at least one of the conversations I had with Mr Williams he claimed to be an environmental expert, particularly because of the fact of his development of the Sea World Resort at Southport and because he had kept dolphins there.
One of the statements Cathy Job made about the report in reply to Mr Williams was:

Actually what it does say is if the management is good, there'll be minimal effect, if the management is bad, it could create significant damage and goes on to say—to put down some guidelines to what should happen to ensure that management is good.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Williams's reply is interesting:

TAB.TAB: Cathy, that's just a cover up. The fact of life is the management will be good in any event, because I don't manage things badly. But quite aside from that, if you had no management at all it still couldn't cause any impact.

SPEECH.PARA: JOB:That's not what this report says Mr Williams, is it?

WILLIAMS:I don't care what that report says, I know what common sense says and I also know, I also know, Cathy, that that area is so turbid naturally at all times, that you couldn't do any damage. Its just impossible.
A little further on in the interview, this exchange took place:
JOB:But doesn't this report make it quite clear that mangroves shouldn't go.

WILLIAMS:Cathy, I don't care—I am giving the terms under which I will proceed with this development, and you know everybody can go jump in the creek, I don't really care. If they think mangroves are so bloody precious and so important why don't they insist the Cairns City Council remove every mangrove that pops up along the esplanade for three miles. They don't want them there, and I don't want them at my resort either.
JOB:I think the report actually says there needs to be a wider look at mangrove removal in the tropics in Queensland.

WILLIAMS:Yeah I think there needs to be a real wide look, because there's too many of them, and if they keep growing at the rate they are, there won't even be a Hinchinbrook Channel because they'll grow from one side to the other . . .

And so on. This is the man who is an environmental expert and who says that he is going to manage the development. I am afraid, if his replies to Cathy Job are any indication, I am not sure that he really cares.

PARA.TAB: Another exchange between them was:

SPEECH.PARA: JOB:Isn't the problem Sen Faulkner has, is he had to act if there's going to be damage, he only knows there's going to be damage if the work is done, and the State Government hasn't done the work—the baseline studies, to get the data together.

WILLIAMS:That's absolute rubbish. The State Government has gone over the top with their work. Your own program tonight is guilty of showing film of a dugong grazing in clear water, which doesn't exist at Cardwell. You're announcer made an absolutely stupid comment and said if the seagrass is going to take 12 months to regrow, and what are the dugongs going to do for 12 months? If all the seagrass off the Port Hinchinbrook site disappeared overnight, it would mean about one feed a year for one dolphin, and by their own figures, there's only been about 20 dolphins sited in the channel at one time—the channel's 40 kilometres long.
Of course, Mr Williams has got dugong and dolphins mixed up because dolphins do not eat seagrass. All I can say is that I rest my case.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Office of Film and Literature Classification

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to continue remarks on the censorship matters that I was speaking about earlier today. I mentioned earlier that we have an excellent classification system that has been in operation since the early 1970s and we have had recent moves to create a proper federal legislative framework. The whole aim of this system is to balance the rights of adults to see and hear what they wish and to protect children.

PARA.TAB: However, over the last 20 years, there has been growing concern about the way in which this system has been operated. There is a widespread feeling that some of the decisions of the OFLC and the film review board do not properly reflect the wishes of the community. I think this perhaps came out best in an example last year with the classification of the film Salo. Salo would have to be one of the most revolting films ever made. It has been banned in most countries of the world, and it was banned in Australia until last year. Seventeen years ago it was first submitted, and every time it has been submitted since the OFLC has banned it. Its recent decision last year to ban it was overturned by the film review board, and it was at that time that our committee on community standards became increasingly worried about why this sort of thing was happening.

One of the main reasons is that the people who are on the boards of these various censorship bodies are not, despite the claims of the Chief Censor, in any way representative of the community. The annual report that has just come out lists the people and their occupations. Let us see what people think about how representative this is.

The board consists of John Dickie, who was previously a journalist. The Deputy Chief Censor taught drama and media. The Senior Censor, Andree Wright, was a freelance writer. Peter Mackay worked with an adolescent support group—a little out of the mould of the others. Sarah Morton, however, was a freelance journalist. Sally Stockbridge was a senior tutor, lecturer in film and related studies. Douglas Stewart was a senior lecturer in media studies. Elizabeth Alexander was a public relations officer with the Film Finance Corporation. Jennifer Rae was a senior teacher in Intensive English College. Robert Hellmers was a specialist school counsellor, and Gareth Griffith was a lecturer in legal studies.

This is the body of so-called representative people that have been making decisions for the community in this matter. We have had the chief censor and his group claim before us on a number of occasions that their body is representative, but the annual report just laid down gives the lie to that. I raise this matter because the structure of the board has recently undergone review, and the number of members are to be increased from 10 to 20. That is most welcome. But given that the chief censor claimed that the board was previously representative, what will we get this time—more film critics? Basically, of the 11 people I read out, nine people were either lecturers in journalism or journalists of some particular description.

I submit that that is one of the reasons why some of the decisions of this board and the whole direction of censorship in this country have been out of kilter with community attitudes. It was, therefore, the right move by the community standards committee to suggest a reform of the process to get much better community input. We suggested at the time of our video games report that the whole organisation be restructured, that the chief censor become the chief executive officer of the organisation, that a more representative community board be appointed with membership of only three years, that the deputy chief censor be selected from that number and that there be a wide-ranging group representing the community to review the decisions of that board where there is conflict between the Office of Film and Literature Classification and the Film and Literature Board of Review. The government rejected those recommendations at that time.

In the committee's recent report on the classification bill, we have renewed such recommendations. I emphasise tonight the need for the government to do that because it is only through proper community representation that we will get the correct decisions made by this board. If we do not do that, we will continually find problems in the system. Our select committee was set up in 1991 for about three months to do a task and has now been running for four years. The problems are there because of the wrong structure. If we get the structure right, we will not have to keep setting up committees. I recommend very strongly to the Senate that we make such a change.

The other change that needs to be made, and this relates particularly to what will happen to this classification bill from this point on, is that there needs to be a lot more scrutiny of the whole process by the elected parliament. This report actually lists the guidelines under which the film review board and the Office of Film and Literature Classification work for the different censorship codes. Who makes up those guidelines? They come from the board. How is it scrutinised? It comes in the form of an appendix at the back of an annual report. There is no proper legislative scrutiny. There are no regulations to go through the regulations and ordinances committee.

We very strongly recommended to the minister in our report—we are not amending the legislation to do this—that, if there are any changes to the guidelines on the censorship matters, those changed guidelines lie on the table of the state and federal parliaments so that there is some scrutiny in the process. It is hoped in this way that the excellent system of scrutiny that we have in this country, the system that is set up under the Office of Film and Literature Classification which is taken worldwide to be a leader in the field, will be refined in the ways that I have indicated so that these matters properly reflect the true attitudes of the community and not just a vested interest group.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to alert the Senate to some more examples of fairly irresponsible union action, this time in the area of North Queensland where I live. North Queensland is well served and has been for many years by the sugar industry, which is a significant and integral part of the economy of the area. The sugar industry has its ups and downs. In recent years, it has been down. At the moment, it is experiencing very buoyant times. Generally speaking, there has been industrial peace in the sugar industry. However, recently at the height of the sugar season, at a most crucial time, the Federated Engine Drivers and Firemen's Association went on strike in Queensland.

PARA.TAB: This strike severely interrupted the sugar harvest, closed down the mills and caused losses to cane growers, harvesting contractors, workers and the mills. One might think that this strike could at least be considered in some light if it had something to do with the sugar industry or the conditions of workers. But the strike had absolutely nothing to do with coastal North Queensland and the sugar industry and everything to do with an inter-union demarcation dispute in Mount Isa, hundreds of kilometres away in a mining town. The FEDFA thought that the AWU or something like that—I do not understand the inter-union politics—was trying to take over Mount Isa mines. To show that the union still had some authority, it called a strike which affected not only Mount Isa but also the sugar industry. That shows just how rogue unions can disrupt the economy of an area, the livelihoods of people and workers for purely internal political reasons. That was of some concern to me.

Around that time when I made some comments on that matter in the sugar industry, a number of constituents from the Ingham area approached me regarding another issue which showed an arrogant and bullyboy attitude of unions—the AWU in this instance—in the sugar industry. Some cane harvesting contractors and cane farmers had said to their workers, `If you want to join the union, go right ahead, you have our entire support. But it is a free country and if you don't want to join the union, don't bother.' As a result of this, those cane growers and cane harvesting contractors were told that, unless they insisted that their workers took out AWU membership, they and their farmers would be black-banned, no bins would be delivered by the mill to the farm and therefore the farmer would be unable to get his cane off. Mr President, you would be aware that the cane has to be taken off at the time it is ready for harvest.

What further disturbed these cane growers and cane harvesting contractors is that they seemed to think that their own organisation of employers was party to that demand by the unions to have compulsory membership of field workers. It turns out on further investigation, so these constituents tell me, that an agreement had been made and an award signed between the cane growers, the cane harvesting contractors and the AWU providing for preference and, put in other language, compulsory membership for field workers in the sugar industry.

This issue has been running quite strongly in the community of Ingham, which is just north of Townsville and a very wealthy sugar growing area, since it came to the fore. Many letters have been written to and a lot of articles have been published in the local paper. The matter was raised in the Queensland parliament by my friend and colleague the National Party member for Hinchinbrook, Mr Marc Rowell. Petitions were lodged and statements issued by the cane growers and cane harvesting contractors who thought it inappropriate that they had to force their workers to take out union membership. They distributed quite widely a letter to friends and neighbours, as they referred to them. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: This issue is not against Unions or members of Unions. This is a sad story of betrayal by the people we entrusted with authority to represent us at the HIGHEST LEVEL to protect our rights and ensure the best conditions for all Canegrowers and their workers.

When an agreement concerning the free choice of Canegrowers and their Fieldworkers is made which eliminates those free choices then it is a Violation of the Charter of Human Rights sacred to the United Nations to which Australia is signatory.
THIS IS WHY WE ARE PROTESTING!

Canegrowers and Harvester Owners are hard working, peace loving people and when told anyone could pay the fees to avoid trouble, many of them did so, not realising that that too was a violation of the rights of their employees!
The Charter Of Human Rights guarantees that no person can be forced to become a member of any group or organisation AGAINST HIS FREE WILL.
THIS IS WHY WE ARE FIGHTING!

Some further work by a group of cane growers and, in many instances, their wives, who took a very strong line on this, resulted in getting a petition together which was signed by a number of people and I understand tabled in the Queensland parliament. It stated:
1. WE CONDEMN THE MISREPRESENTATION OF CANEGROWERS IN THE AGREEMENT BETWEEN EXECUTIVES AND THE A.W.U. TO IMPOSE COMPULSORY UNIONISM UPON WORKERS IN THE CANEFIELDS.
2. WE CONDEMN THE HARASSMENT, INTIMIDATION AND BLACKMAIL BY THE ABOVE AGAINST MEMBERS OF THE CANEGROWERS AND THEIR EMPLOYEES.
3. WE CONDEMN BONDAGE AS A MEANS OF UNION RECRUITMENT AND OBTAINING FUNDS BY EXTORTION FOR UNIONS.
4. WE CONDEMN THE VIOLATION OF HUMAN RIGHTS AGAINST THE EMPLOYERS AND EMPLOYEES IN THE AGREEMENT ENFORCED BY THE ABOVE.

5. WE INSIST THAT UNION MEMBERSHIP BE VOLUNTARY SO THAT NO EMPLOYEE IN THE CANEFIELDS WILL EVER BE SUBJECTED TO BONDAGE BY DECEIT, DISHONESTY, OR POLITICAL AGENDA—BY ANY PERSON REPRESENTING THE CANEGROWERS ASSO CIATION.

Those people were very concerned and, as you can tell, Mr President, quite angry at the way this happened. They were, as I say, very angry with the union. They were also annoyed with their own union of employers, which they thought was pushing the union membership. In fact, a number of letters were written to cane growers and cane harvesters by the cane growers organisation which indicated that the cane growers and cane harvesting contractors should insist that their employees take out membership or pay for it themselves. One of the letters which were sent to cane growers states:
The purpose of this contact is to make you aware that harvesting of your cane will be delayed unless your contractor takes immediate action to have his employees obtain Union tickets.
To avoid your cane being placed at risk, it is recommended that you immediately contact your harvesting contractor in regard to this matter.

A similar letter went to the cane harvesting contractors. Those people are quite concerned. I raise these matters at the request of the constituents in Ingham who feel that they have been blackmailed by the unions to the extent where they, the people who contacted me, had to give in. They went out and paid with their own money—they were not worried about the money—the membership to the cane growers organisation, which we understand then reindorsed the cheques for them to be paid over to the union movement. Those people were forced to do that or they would have lost their cane.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 23 June 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the continuing problem of piracy attacks on shipping in the South China Sea:
(1) What figures are available on the number of attacks on shipping in the South China Sea in the past 5 years.
(2) How many pirates have been captured over this period, and from what country do the pirate ships originate.
(3) Has the Australian Government been approached, either on a diplomatic basis or privately, by ASEAN nations expressing concern over piracy in their areas.
(4) Do the ASEAN nations believe the incidence of piracy may increase when the British Navy withdraws from Hong Kong in 1997.
(5) Has the Australian Government been asked to consider providing navy vessels to fill this void and/or co-operate with an ASEAN force to eradicate piracy in the area.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government does not have any figures on the number of attacks on shipping in the South China Sea in the past 5 years. The International Maritime Bureau estimate that approximately 100 incidents occur per year and many incidents are not reported.
(2) The Government has no figures on the number of pirates captured over the last five years.

(3) No; but at the ASEAN Post Ministerial Conference in Manila in 1992, I proposed an expansion of maritime cooperation and information exchange between regional countries over piracy. The creation of the ASEAN Regional Forum, the first Asia Pacific-wide security dialogue, which held its first meeting in Bangkok in July 1994, provides the region with a mechanism in which transnational problems such as piracy can be discussed and resolved cooperatively.
(4) The ASEAN countries have not approached Australia on the question of piracy in the South China Sea after the British Navy withdraws in 1997.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 5 July 1994:

PARA.TAB: While noting that it is presently impossible to implement telephone customers' ballot choice for Optus when they have an enhanced service such as Centrex, Faxstream, Integrated Services Digital Network or Virtual Private Network:

(1) Why can lines with an enhanced service not currently support automatic direction of calls through the Optus network, in particular, is the limitation imposed by exchange hardware or software, and what changes are required to overcome this limitation.
(2) How many of the ballots cast for Optus to date have not been implemented as a consequence of this limitation.

(3) Has Telecom intensified its marketing of these enhanced services in the lead-up to the commencement of area ballots; if so, does it always inform customers that purchasing such a service will prevent them from choosing Optus as their long-distance carrier.
(4)Will the ballot choice of these customers be implemented as soon as technically possible, or will they be forced to make their own representations to the carriers to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Telecom has advised that the limitation on pre-selection for enhanced services such as Centrex, Faxstream and Virtual Private Network is imposed by exchange software.
AUSTEL has advised that:

pre-selection for enhanced services requires integration of additional logic into exchange-specific and system manufacturers' proprietary software. This involves co-ordinated design activity by both Telecom and the various switching system suppliers;
such software changes must go through a design and testing sequence before being implemented.

Telecom has also advised that the changes required for the Centel product, which is a part of the Centrex group of products, have already been implemented. Telecom has further advised that the modifications for the Faxstream product are scheduled for December 1994 and those for the Virtual Private Network product are currently being tested and are scheduled for release in January 1995.

In the case of the Integrated Services Digital Network (ISDN), Telecom advises that there is currently no agreement between the two carriers on how the product will interwork between their networks. AUSTEL advises that implementation of pre-selection will require modifications to both carriers' networks. AUSTEL also advises it will require the interworking of complex features within systems provided by different manufacturers, in particular ensuring compatibility of complex signalling protocols working across defined points of interconnection. AUSTEL advises that failure to ensure compatibility may result in serious network problems.

(2) Telecom has advised that 5,426 lines contained in ballots cast for Optus had not been implemented as at 14 October 1994 because those lines have some form of enhanced service. Telecom advised that this amounts to 0.65% of all lines contained in ballots cast for Optus.
(3) Telecom has advised that it does not have a strategy of marketing enhanced services in the lead up to a ballot for pre-selection.

(4) Telecom has advised that, as the modified software is implemented in the exchange for each enhanced product, these customers' lines will automatically have their ballot choice implemented without any further action required by the customer. Telecom has further advised that the customer will be notified following the conversion process.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Finance: Grants to Trade Unions and Community Groups

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 23 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the department, or any of its agencies or statutory authorities, approved or made available any grants, or other forms of payments, to trade unions or community groups in the 1993-94 financial year; if so, in each case: (a) what is the name and address of the trade union or community group which received the funds; (b) what was the amount involved; (c) what was the purpose of the payment; (d) under what program was the payment made; (e) who approved the payment; and (f) what acquittal requirements are there pertaining to the payment, and are there any outstanding acquittals.
