TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 23 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many complaints has the National Transmission Agency (NTA) received regarding new installations and changes in broadcasting facilities since its inception.
(2) What was the nature of these complaints.
(3) Have all complaints been acted on.

(4) With reference to the fact that when the radio station 3GI was transferred from AM to FM several thousand people lost reception and it was necessary to transfer back, is the NTA taking action with regard to a similar reception problem in Swan Hill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The NTA does not keep a complaints register. However, the Agency does have summary records for some 9,000 enquiries which it has received during the last two years. Requests for information accounted for 83% of these (including enquiries about reception requirements [70%], extensions to the signal coverage of existing services [10%] and matters not specific to the NTA [3%]). The remaining 17% comprised more specific enquiries (including reception/signal coverage difficulties [8%], service outages [3%], delays to the commissioning of new facilities [3%] and other [3%]).

(2) In many cases enquiries or complaints about the performance of NTA facilities were actually the result of local interference or faults in the complainants' own reception systems. Where these contacts occurred on the NTA's telephone information line, they were responded to immediately; enquiries received in writing have been responded to accordingly. Other enquiries take the form of requests for improvements or additions to transmitted services, particularly in rural areas.
(3) Yes.

(4) The NTA provides transmission facilities for national broadcasting services, in accordance with Government approved programs to extend or maintain signal coverage. The ABC and the SBS determine which programs are transmitted on these facilities. The ABC has advised that there are no plans at this stage to vary the programming arrangements for the Swan Hill area.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 23 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Have letters, or copies of letters, received by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation from protesters against the broadcast of the Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras been sent to a university in New South Wales; if so, why have they been passed on to an outside organisation.
(2) What guarantees can be given that the privacy of the letter writers has not been breached.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am advised by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) that the ABC provided all letters received up until 10 March 1994 to the Australian Graduate School of Management (AGSM) to examine all comment and complaint about the telecast of the Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras.
The AGSM has developed considerable expertise in analysing issues of public policy and the ABC considered that the University's independent study would produce useful results.
(2) The ABC has advised that the AGSM gave a guarantee of privacy for all correspondence. Letters were not copied and all were returned to the ABC, where they will remain.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 5 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is Telecom presently in a legal dispute with mobile phone dealer Saja/Easyphone of Torrensville in South Australia.

(2) Does this dispute centre around Telecom MobileNet Telemarketing's alleged practice of contacting Saja/Easyphone's customers to recommend that they switch their service business from Saja/Easyphone to other mobile cellular dealers.
(3) Was the termination of Saja/Easyphone's resale contract with Telecom in any way connected with Saja/Easyphone's refusal to engage in legal action against the resellers of other carriers.

(4) Is Telecom MobileNet Telemarketing's use of customer lists for the purpose of leading customers from one dealership to another consistent with the recently established privacy guidelines agreed to by Telecom.
(5) Are there any restrictions on Telecom's use of these customer lists.
(6) Did Telecom consult with any alternative mobile dealerships in allegedly taking this course of action.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on information provided by Telecom:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am advised by Telecom that it is the plaintiff to an action in the Magistrates Court (Civil Division) of South Australia brought against Mr James Young and Ms Sandra Monnier, proprietors of SAJA/Easyphone.
I am advised by Telecom that it is also the defendant to an action brought by Ms Monnier in the District Court of South Australia.

(2) Telecom advises that in the proceedings commenced in the District Court of South Australia, Ms Monnier alleges that Telecom MobileNet Telemarketing has contacted the customers of SAJA/Easyphone to recommend that they switch the service of their mobile telephones from SAJA/Easyphone to a Telecom dealer.
(3) Telecom advises that this was not the case.

(4) Telecom advises that Telecom MobileNet Telemarketing is using its own customer lists, that is, lists derived from information supplied by its customers to Telecom MobileNet, for the purpose of contacting those customers.
Telecom advises it is not a breach of Telecom's Privacy Protection Policy for Telecom MobileNet to contact its own customers to advise them of matters pertaining to Telecom's mobile network.

(5) Telecom advises that it does not use details of its customers for any reason other than dealing with those customers nor does it disclose customer details to any person outside of that organisation except with the customer's permission or where legally required to do so.
(6) Telecom advises that it did not.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 12 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the Australian Government's position in relation to the decision of the Albanian Government to arrest a number of ethnic Greek Albanians on the basis of their membership of the Omonia political party.

(2) Has Albania fully complied with all international legal responsibilities including human rights conventions in relation to the arrest and subsequent detention of these people; if not, what action has the Australian Government taken to remind Albania of those responsibilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Albanian officials arrested six members of the ethnic Greek political party Omonia on 18 April 1994. The six were arrested on charges of treason, espionage and illegal possession of arms, irrespective of their Omonia membership. The most serious charge of treason was later dropped, and a further scaling down of charges was made in regard to one of the six who was accused only of illegal possession of arms. The Australian Government respects the right of Albanian judicial authorities to act independently but retains the strong expectation that, in line with Albania's declared espousal of democratic principles, all those accused of crimes will receive fair and open trials which comply fully with the international rule of law.

(2) The Greek Government accused Albanian officials of mistreating and violating the rights of the six accused. The Albanian Government has steadfastly denied these accusations, which were made against a backdrop of severe tensions in the bilateral relationship arising from mutual allegations of minority mistreatment and recriminations such as the deportation of 40-50,000 Albanians from Greece and Albania's refusal to allow Greece to replace the military attache at its Embassy in Tirana. From the outset, the Albanian Government declared that the accused would receive a fair and open trial. To this end, invitations were issued to Greek Embassy staff in Tirana to attend the trial and the Ambassador, accompanied by an all-Party Greek Parliamentary delegation, took up the offer. A representative of the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe visited Albania during the trial and declared that the trial procedure had been normal and independent of Albanian Government influence. During one of his regular visits to Albania in August 1994—while the trial was in progress—Australia's Ambassador in Rome (accredited to Albania) met with Albanian Foreign Ministry officials and outlined Australia's expectation that the six Greek/Albanians would receive a fair and open trial. During a previous visit to Albania in February 1994, the Ambassador registered in meetings with President Berisha, Deputy Prime Minister Kopliku and Foreign Minister Serreqi Australia's policy of global concern for the protection and observance of human rights and our strong hope that Albania's political and economic reforms would proceed in line with all democratic norms.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 18 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the cost of computer hardware and software purchased by the department for the 1991-92, 1992-93 and 1993-94 financial years, and what is the breakdown of the projects for the 1994-95 financial year.
(2) What is the average lead time needed between the decision to purchase, the order and the installation of computer hardware and software.
(3) What is the average life of the department's computer hardware and software before it is considered obsolete or superseded by newer, more advanced models.

(4) What funds were returned to the department through selling obsolete computer hardware and software in the 1991-92, 1992-93 and 1993-94 financial years, and what is the breakdown of the projections for the 1994-95 financial year.
(5) What was the cost of facsimile machines purchased by the department for the 1991-92, 1992-93 and 1993-94 financial years, and what is the breakdown of the projects for the 1994-95 financial year.
(6) What is the average lead time needed between the decision to purchase, the order and the installation of facsimile machines.
(7) What is the average life of the department's facsimile machines before they are considered obsolete or superseded by newer, more advanced models.

(8) What funds were returned to the department through selling obsolete facsimile machines in the 1991-92, 1992-93 and 1993-94 financial years, and what is the breakdown of the projections for the 1994-95 financial years.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)-(3) I am advised that the question is not in a form which would make the provision of meaningful replies possible. For example, computer hardware comes in a number of forms and the costs range from small to very large amounts, depending on the hardware in question. It would not be possible, without an expenditure of resources which could not be justified, to extract records of minor purchases.

Similarly, software may at one extreme be very inexpensive, and purchased over the counter, or at the other be very costly and acquired through major tendering processes. Much software may not be purchased at all, in the sense of legal ownership transferring from the producer to the Commonwealth, even though there is Commonwealth expenditure. Concepts like average lead times for decisions to purchase, and average life of hardware and software are imprecise and meaningless in this context.
In the circumstances, I am unable to authorise the expenditure of money and effort involved in trying to assemble the information.

(4) & (8) The department disposes of equipment which it no longer needs in a variety of ways, including by tender, auction and by trade-in, in some instances by item, in others by lot. It is not possible, therefore, to answer this question in its current form.

(5) The department maintains its records in a form which would not enable it, without an expenditure of resources which would not be justified, to establish these particular figures for years before the most recent financial year with the necessary degree of reliability.
The figure for 1993-94, based on a survey of functional areas which undertake such purchasing, is $82,885.
(6) The department does not keep records in a form which would enable it to answer this question. Machines can be, and usually are, purchased and installed very quickly after the need is identified.

(7) The department does not keep records which would enable it to answer this question. Facsimile machines are usually either replaced when they cease to function adequately, or moved to an area of lower priority when their capacity becomes insufficient.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 19 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the reason for sending the board of management members as well as the Director of the Volunteer Centre of Tasmania Inc. to Perth, WA, for a national conference.
(2) What was the cost of this decision.
(3) What were the reasons for the interstate visits of the director, Mr Nick Toonen.
(4) What were the costs of these visits.
(5) What are the current funding levels for the Volunteer Centre of Tasmania Inc. from the Federal Government.
(6) What are the future funding levels for the Volunteer Centre of Tasmania Inc. from the Federal Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) It was a requirement under the Volunteer Management Program (VMP), which provides funding for the Centre, that the President and the Executive Officer of each Centre and Agency attend a workshop in Perth before the national conference. Attendance at the conference was optional. Responsibility for authorising attendance at the national conference lies with the Board of Management of the Volunteer Centre of Tasmania.

(2) The cost of airfares and accommodation associated with the attendance at the Perth VMP workshop was in the region of $1,300. These costs were paid through a Management Support grant to the Volunteer Centre of Western Australia who managed the administration of the workshop.

(3) Responsibility for authorising interstate visits of the Director of the Volunteer Centre of Tasmania Inc. lies with the Board of Management. The Volunteer Centre of Tasmania is not required to inform the Department of travel they undertake or the reasons for such travel.

(4) The Board of Management of the Volunteer Centre of Tasmania is responsible for allocation of the individual items within their grant under the VMP. The Centre is not required to report on costs of individual trips.

Those centres funded under the VMP are required to provide quarterly financial statements and an end of year audited financial statement against line budget items. Quarterly reports against their national performance indicators are also required as part of the conditions of grant.
(5) The Volunteer Centre of Tasmania Inc. receives $75,036 per annum under the Volunteer Management Program.
(6) The VMP was announced in December 1992 as a limited term development program to cease on 30 June 1995. There is no commitment at this time to continue funding beyond that date.
A decision regarding the continuation of the program beyond June 1995, will be made following an evaluation to be conducted during 1994-95.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 18 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Government aware that the Victorian Deaf Society has been forced by financial pressure to withdraw its TTY relay service for the deaf outside work hours.
(2) Is it a fact that Federal Government funds appropriated in the March 1994 Budget to support a national TTY service will not be available until 1 April 1995.
(3) What is the explanation for the delay in making this funding available.
(4) What TTY services for the deaf will be available between now and 1 April 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. The Government is aware that the Victorian Deaf Society is experiencing financial difficulties in the operation of its TTY relay service. The Commonwealth has never, however, funded this relay service and the decision to reduce its hours of operation is one that has been made by the Society alone, on the basis of its own financial considerations.

(2) Yes. Funding for the national TTY service will become available when the service commences on 3 April 1995. Funds allocated in the 1994 Federal Budget were provided solely for the establishment of a National 24 Hour TTY Relay Service and to provide financial assistance for the purchase of TTY machines on a means tested basis. There is no scope, within this budget allocation, for funds to be used to support existing relay services prior to 3 April 1995.

(3) There is no delay in making funding available for the National Relay Service. The commencement of the service was always planned for April 1995. The period between July 1994 and April 1995 is being used to design the service and to put the service out to tender. Tenders are expected to close in January 1995, with the service to commence on 3 April 1995.

(4) There are a number of privately run TTY relay services being operated in Australia. These are conducted by community based organisations using voluntary resources. Their hours of operation vary from state to state and the service provided is constrained by the limits of their available funding. The Government is concerned to ensure that the users of these services are not disadvantaged by the establishment of the new national service. To this end, the new national service is being designed to enhance the quality of service available. The operators of the existing services are being consulted in the process of establishing the national service, so that they can plan their services and resources accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 18 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to a top level inquiry by the Inspector General in Defence into a contract by his department with a company called Malindoqueen which the Minister for Defence has directed should not be renewed.

(1) Was the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Evans) aware of the nature of this contract, which has been described by Mr Mike Waller, First Assistant Secretary of the Industry Involvement and Contracting Section of the Department of Defence, in a letter to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs supporting an Australian residency application by a director of Malindoqueen, as requiring Malindoqueen to `introduce the department to higher Indonesian defence circles and obtain information about priorities in Indonesian defence expenditure'.

(3) Was this an operation whose objective was to offer bribes or other inducements to Indonesian officials, and are such activities condoned by the Government and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.
(4) To what extent does this kind of activity put at risk our friendly relationship with Indonesia, and what is the Minister doing to prevent such diplomatically embarrassing events recurring.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I was aware, through my Department, that the Department of Defence had engaged for twelve months a director of an Australian company as a consultant with contacts in Indonesia. The knowledge that I and my department had of this arrangement was of the most general kind.
(2) and (3) No. No advice my Department ever received on this matter would support these contentions.
(4) Friendly relations with Indonesia are not put at risk by consultancies which openly and legitimately encourage the development of trade between the two countries.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 31 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the purpose of the Geraldton Satellite Communications Base, and how does its role fit with other intelligence gathering networks.

(2)(a) What is the nature of the information gathered through the Geraldton Satellite Communication Base, and how is the information used; (b) who is the information shared with; (c) does the Government agree with the comments of Director Tim James who said the information will be shared with the United States (US) (Geraldton Guardian, 18 November 1987); and (d) who in the US will be receiving this information, and how will it be used.
(3) What percentage of the information gathered is economic and trade intelligence, and what percentage is defence related.
(4) What information does the Geraldton Satellite Communication Base monitor.

(5)(a) What is the operating budget for the Geraldton Satellite Communication Base for the 1992-93, 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years; (b) what has been the total amount spent on the base to date, and what is the breakdown of that amount; (c) what was the initial cost of building the communications base; (d) were those figures revised up or down from initial projections; and (e) by how much did the costs differ, and why.

(6) Which Government programs funded the capital costs and the operating costs of the Geraldton Satellite Communication Base, and what is the funding per year by program for the 1992-93, 1993-94 and 1994-95 financial years.

(7)(a) How many personnel are employed to work at the communications base; (b) how many of these are local people and how many were drawn from outside the local community; (c) how many personnel are employed in military tasks versus civilian tasks; (d) how many personnel in military tasks were drawn from the local community; (e) how many personnel in civilian tasks were drawn from the local community; and (f) what are the different staff positions at the base and the number of personnel employed in each of the staff positions and their nationalities.
(8) Does the base have present any advisers from other countries; if so, what is the staff position, rank, authority over other personnel and nationality for each such adviser.

(9)(a) Was an Environmental Impact Assessment done of the area affected by the Geraldton Satellite Communications base; if so, is a copy available to all Members of Parliament; (b) who prepared the Environmental Impact Statement; (c) what were the recommendations of the report; and (d) what were the impacts on flora and fauna, surrounding water catchment areas and the coastal environment.

(10)(a) Is the Geraldton Satellite Communications Base declassified so as to have the support of the local community; (b) what steps has the Government taken to inform the community about the role, nature and operations of the base; and (c) has the Government produced briefing papers or reports of any kind to inform the Senate or the local community about the role, nature and operations of the base; if not, why not.
(11) What is the specific location and address of the Geraldton Satellite Communication Base.

(12)(a) What is the level of public access afforded to the base; (b) are public tours conducted of the base; (c) what areas are members of the public prohibited from entering, and why; and (d) what is the reason for and the role of the buffer zone.

(13)(a) Does the Government concur with the comments of Director Tim James, reported in the Geraldton Guardian of 18 November 1987; that the Defence Signals Directorate would hope to control any possible demonstrations at the facility by locating a viewing site in the buffer zone; and (b) is the role of the viewing site to keep out any dissenting members of the public; if so, why.
(14) Is the base a current or potential nuclear target; if so, why.
(15) Does the Government concede that there are contradictions in economic intelligence gathering for our own gain and sharing that information with our trading competitors; if so, why.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) to (15) It is a long-established practice of Australian governments not to comment on intelligence and security matters. It is therefore not my intention to discuss the specific functions and capabilities of the Australian Defence Satellite Communications Station at Geraldton. However, I can confirm that the station is operated by the Defence Signals Directorate (DSD) of the Department of Defence. DSD's role and functions were set out in the Prime Minister's statement of 22 May 1985 (Hansard, page 2886).

The full cost details of the station are classified and not able to be released. However, I can say that construction costs were $57 million for the buildings and $32.5 million for the antennas. The station is Australian owned, it is not a joint facility, nor is it correct to characterise it as a `base'. Staff are drawn from both the local area and elsewhere in Australia and include a very small number of US and UK personnel in support activities.

Prior to project commencement, an Environmental Impact Assessment was undertaken by Kinhill Engineers in accordance with Defence guidelines. The assessment included a study of the flora, fauna, Aboriginal heritage, European history and heritage and archaeological and ethnographic survey of possible sites in the Geraldton region. The final site selection and design incorporated all of the recommendations of the environmental assessment.

The station is located on 455 hectares of Commonwealth land 35 km east of Geraldton. A public viewing area has been established to allow visitors to see the station without impinging on the security arrangements for the site.

As part of the station's community relationship program, special arrangements are made from time to time to provide tours of the station for community groups. Visiting groups have included representatives of the Geraldton City and Greenough Shire Councils, the Mullewa Home and Community Care Group, the Geraldton Regional Community Education Centre and the Institute of Engineers.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Family Planning and Human Rights, Indonesia

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, these questions, on 20 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Minister see in a press report yesterday that the Bishop of Dili, Bishop Belo, has denounced the Indonesian authorities for conducting a programmed, systematic plan for sterilisation in East Timor?

(2) Has the Minister also seen the recent article in Inside Indonesia which described the Indonesian Family Planning Coordination Board's program as based on highly invasive coercive practices underpinned by extensive surveillance and control? What action will the government take to condemn these violations of human rights?

(3) I refer to an agreement between Minister Bilney and Haryono Suyono, the Minister for Population in Indonesia, which asserted that Indonesia's program was voluntary and effective. Effective it is; voluntary it is not. Does the Minister remember that this agreement said that Australian money would be provided for a UNFPA program which `will include scholarships for Pacific islanders to attend the Indonesian National Family Planning Coordination Board's International Training Program and field visits to Eastern Indonesian provinces'? Are the highly coercive practices engaged in by the Indonesian authorities and condemned by Bishop Belo the sort of things that we want to see happen in the Pacific.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: undertook to provide detailed answers at a later date. The answers are as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Australian Government is totally opposed to the use of coercion in family planning programs. We have indeed recently revised our procedures for appraising and evaluating population activities to ensure that they promote basic human rights. At the same time the Government would acknowledge that on some occasions overzealous local officials may engage in practices which are not sanctioned by the Australian Government. However, in such cases the choice for us is very clear. Australia either stays involved in the program to ensure that such practices are eliminated in favour of a more enlightened and humanitarian approach, or we withdraw completely, thereby ceasing to be able to demonstrate the efficacy of voluntarism. This Government has chosen the former approach.
In answer to Senator Harradine's specific concerns I have the following comments:

(1) I have now seen wire service reports quoting the Bishop of Dili, Ximenes Belo. The reports—run by AAP on October 19 and Lisbon Radio on 18 October—indicate that Bishop Belo may have confused the use of contraceptives such as Norplant and Depo Provera as equivalent to permanent sterilisation. This is not the case.

The Australian Embassy in Jakarta has advised that the Government of Indonesia recognises the following contraceptive options; injectables, condoms, Billings method, IUD, oral contraceptive pill, spermicides and Norplant. In East Timor, it is reported that the provincial government strongly promotes the use of "natural" family planning methods due to the predominance of Roman Catholics in the Province.

The UNICEF and UNFPA offices have indicated that they have no knowledge or evidence to support claims of coercive sterilisation or forced contraception campaigns in East Timor. UNICEF works in all districts in East Timor and is well placed to speak authoritatively on this matter.

(2) The article referred to by the Senator in the June 1994 edition of Inside Indonesia is titled "Family Planning: the Health of the State". The anonymous author is critical of the Indonesian family planning system in West Sumatra claiming that it is `highly invasive and coercive, and underpinned by an extensive system of surveillance and control'.

The National Family Planning Program (KB) was introduced in the area 12 years ago. Though the limited number of women quoted by this article appear to have had bad experiences with Family Planning authorities in the area, the author concludes that most women in the area surveyed were still interested in gaining access to high quality family planning services. Australia is keen to assist the Indonesian Government in achieving this goal—ensuring that services currently enjoyed by women who can afford to attend private clinics are extended to all poor women. It is through the provision of high quality services that women are guaranteed the right to information and autonomy called for in the article. It will not be achieved by withdrawing support for programs in Indonesia where maternal mortality is still estimated at 425 per 100,000 live births.

I also wish to point out that the author of the article is incorrect in asserting that Depo Provera is banned except for `experimental uses' in the US. Depo Provera is available legally in the US as a contraceptive. It is also available legally as a contraceptive in Australia and almost all western countries.
(3) Under the agreement between Minister Bilney and the Indonesian State Minister for Population, Haryono Suyono, Australia agreed to assist family

ANSWER.PARA: planning officials from Papua New Guinea and several Pacific Island countries to participate in Observation Study Tours (OST) of Indonesian family planning operational and training facilities. The objective is to improve the quality of family planning and safe motherhood services in Papua New Guinea and Pacific Island countries. It is up to the participating countries to decide on whether such visits are helpful.

PARA.TAB: The first of these OST's took place in May 1994. Australian Embassy staff attended some of the training sessions and noted that the Indonesian officials did not attempt to enforce particular views on participants. Our information indicates that South Pacific participants told Embassy staff that they found the program useful in forming their own views on the provision of community based family planning services.
